text:
The secret to any rice pudding is the timing of the sugar.  It must not be added until the rice is thoroughly cooked otherwise it will forever remain hard.  Those who did not like this recipe should test the rice for tenderness before adding the sugar in the final stage of the recipe.

text:
My daughter found this recipe on the site and decided to make it last night. Erica, I wish I could give this more than five stars because it was incredible! My dad worked for Tuscan Dairy for fifty years in Union, N.J. and they made an amazing rice pudding, which I've never been able to even nearly duplicate. Thanks to you, this is pretty close! I omitted the raisins and used skim milk because it was the only thing I had in the house. The next time Ty gets a desire to make this great dessert, I'll have her use evaporated skim milk as it really replicates a light cream or a whole milk. Thanks so much!

text:
Very easy. The first time I made this recipe I made it with long grain rice (not knowing the difference between long, med, and short) and half and half. Second time I made it with medium grain rice, skim milk and less sugar. The medium grain rice made a huge difference in the end product, do not make the mistake of using long grain rice the pudding will just not be the same! Also, no need to use half and half it was just as good with the skim milk---save yourself the calories! I liked it better with a little less sugar.

text:
Erica is my new hero! This is, without a doubt, the BEST and EASIEST rice pudding recipe I have ever made. I followed the suggestions of others and used medium grain rice and half the sugar called for. I didn't put the sugar into the pudding until it was the consistency I wanted. Remember to put some of the warm mixture into the egg and milk before SLOWLY adding it to your pot so you don't end up with "egg-drop" in your rice pudding!

If you've never made rice pudding before or are looking for an excellent, easy recipe, this one is for you! Thanks, again, Erica. :)

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was absolutely delicious! I never made homemade rice pudding before, but I had all the ingredients and some left over rice. 

First of all, I buttered my rice when it was cooking in step 1. This eliminates the need for it in the later part of step 2 and lends to a richer pudding. 

I generally watch the fat in my recipes, so I made mine with skim milk, which added another 6 or 7 minutes on to the total cooking time. I also increased the sugar a little, as I preferred it a bit sweeter (it's a matter of preference). But the main key is to add some of cooking pudding (from the pot) to a seperate bowl with the egg and milk mixture. This brings the egg and milk mixture to a warmer, more consistant temperature to what's in the pot and prevents the egg from scrambling. After about 3 minutes mixing them together in the bowl, slowly add the egg and milk mixture to the pot and continue cooking for about 2 minutes, until thickened.

Sprinkle it with a bit of cinnamon before serving. This pudding is delicious hot or cold. I will be making this recipe often. Thanks!

text:
Wonderful recipe.  My 3-year-old just loves it, and it turned out nice and creamy.  I was skeptical, as I've always made rice pudding by cooking the rice in the milk, but it came out great-tasting, and the big bonus is that it's a great use for leftover rice!  And it doesn't make too much.  One warning--3/4 cup uncooked rice yields more than 1-1/2 cups cooked.  I used only 1-1/2 cups cooked, and think that any more would've taken away the creaminess.

Simplicity in itself!  I've never made rice pudding (or any other pudding before), but found myself craving it one day, so I got the easiest looking recipe and here we are!  Now - I really abhor raisins so I left them out, and added half a teaspoon of cornstarch to thicken it up a bit since it needed to be a bit thicker.  But, I believe taste is subjective so, take my word for it, an excellent recipe.

(Oh, another thing, short-grained rice really makes a difference, at first I used long-grained and it just didn't taste right..the texture, etc.)
                               ~Angela

text:
Perfection. Simple as that! Just like the genuine Mexican style rice pudding I'm used to. I did add a pinch of nutmeg and about a heaping 1/8 tsp of cinnamon though and used 1 cup half & half, 1 cup milk.  I read some other reviews concerning the the egg but you probably don't want to add raw egg after the mixture has cooled since, of course, the egg will still be raw! Just mix the egg with the 1/2 cup of milk and let it sit at room temp while the rices cooks. Then add it slowly to the rice while stirring, this way you'll avoid getting any egg chunks but still cook the egg in the hot mixture.
UPDATE:: I Made this again and decided to add about 1/4 cup sour cream! It is unfathomable that this recipe could be any better but the sour cream just sky rockets it's flavor!

text:
Simple to make and awesome to eat! Why would anyone buy that junk from the supermarket that is just thickened goo with a few grains of rice floating around in it when, in under 45 minutes, you could be eating this?? Perfect in both flavor and texture, it's the ultimate comfort food. I used 1/2 cup Splenda (only because I'm diabetic)in place of the sugar, because 1/3 cup didn't give the requisite sweetness, and used dark raisins. Also added a dash of lemon extract, because that's how my mom made it, and the lemon points up the other ingredients. This is the first time I ever made rice pudding on the stove top (always baked it in the oven) and the texture is every bit as creamy. Much better when using a medium or short grain rice. However, if you only have long grain, increase the water in the initial cooking, i.e. with the 3/4 cup of dry rice, cook in 1-3/4 cup of water, and the rice will be less al dente, contributing to the soft creamy texture later on. You'll need to add a few minutes onto the initial cooking time in order for the additional water to be absorbed. Thank you for the easy, perfect recipe!

text:
Amazingly Good! Erica, You so Rock!!!
I made this recipe just as written with no changes to the ingredients. It is so yummy and best of all, easy enough for even inexperienced cooks. Since I am an experienced cook I know all of the tricks of cooking the rice with the salt AND sugar in the water for the initial boiling period so it will all be absorbed into the rice. I used aproximately 1/3 of a cup of the warm liquid of the second boiling to temper the beaten eggs so as to not scramble them. And lastly, I just used one pan for the entire process to save on the clean-up. This is probably the best Rice Pudding recipe that I have ever tried, and believe me I have tried a bunch!

text:
5/11/06---I used leftover white rice from chinese takeout. I will never throw any out, ever again....what a great way to use it up. I did add a bit of cinnamon & I didn't have any golden raisins so I used regular. Super easy to make but I made it in the afternoon & refrigerated until dessert...it gummed up a bit in the fridge. My husband, who was at work & hence didn't get to taste it warm, still loved it but I knew how much better it tastes when it is fresh. Don't get me wrong, it was still very good but it wasn't nearly as good as warm from the pan. UPDATE- 6/07/06---Made this again but I subbed chopped-up dried mangoes for raisins & added some ginger. I garnished w/ a small bed of brown sugar & then topped that w/ some chopped crystallized ginger. Wsa a wonderful dessert for Orange & Bourbon Salmon!

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
I have a serious weakness for Kozy Shack rice pudding.  I have been searching for a rice pudding recipe that even comes close to Kozy Shack...  and this one is pretty darned close!  I found that all of the water had been absorbed after about 15 minutes, and then after adding the milk/sugar it only took about 12 min for the consistancy to get pretty creamy.  It was still a bit runny at that point, and I poured some of the hot rice/milk mixture into the milk/egg mixture, to bring it up to a warm temp so the eggs wouldn't get scrambled.  Then I added it back into the pot, and stirred constantly for 2 minutes as indicated, albeit on a very low temp, not med.  I poured this into custard cups, and while the mixture was a little runny at first, it firmed up very nicely after about 15 minutes.  I used whole milk, but imagine nonfat or lowfat would work too.  I also used basmati rice, but since I know nothing of rice varieties, I don't know if there's a better alternative.  I believe almond extract in place of vanilla would be wonderful.  I didn't add raisins either, but not because I'm opposed to them, I just wanted plain unadulterated rice pudding.  It was fantastic.

text:
***Update to my review***  This pudding was nice and creamy while still warm, however as it cooled it became dry.  After a night in the fridge, it was really dry.  This might be because I used long grain rice, I'm not sure.  So I dumped it back in a pan and added about 1/2 c. milk.  Heated it up to a boil, added a couple tablespoons of sugar, then added another egg mixed with about 1/4 c. milk, tempered the egg mixture and then added to pan; cooked for 2 mins. stirring constantly.  The pudding-to-rice ratio seems better now.  So, if yours dries out, remember it can be "fixed"!  Next time I make this recipe with long grain rice, I'll add 2 eggs, more sugar and up the milk at the end to 1-1/4 c.

userID:
2871190
Display Name:
ellie
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674136.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This has to be the ultimate! My hubby loves rice pudding, but I've always made it as a baked custard, as did his family. Never again! I did, of course, make a couple of changes. I noticed right away it's basically vanilla pudding with rice and raisins, so...
First, for those of you who are new to making pudding, start with room temp eggs. If you don't have time to set them out, place them in a bowl of really hot tap water for about 15 minutes. Room temp will help keep them from cooking improperly later.
I did begin with all the milk- and I used half whole milk, half heavy cream. Yeah- but it's worth it- it's dessert, people! :)
I also added 2/3 of the rice and raisins, just personal preference.  I also doubled the eggs- like my vanilla pudding recipe. Just so you know it works fine.
Remember, your cooking time begins with hot ingredients. And you MUST temper the eggs. This means to a bowl containing the beaten eggs, add s-l-o-w-l-y about 1/4 cup of your hot mixture, beating constantly. Then add the egg mix to your pan slowly beating constantly. This will prevent the "scrambled egg"problem.
I also threw in some good cinnamon with the vanilla and butter. (sorry- didn't measure.) 
Next time I'll add the sugar half at a time and taste. Just a bit sweet for my taste, but still soooo good! Thanks so much, Erica and Erica's Mom!!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
With just a few changes, this recipe has become my ABSOLUTE favorite.  (Without the changes, it is still fabulous!!)  It is creamy in texture and not overly sweet.  My family loves it. 

I substituted 1/2 cup heavy cream for 1/4 cup milk.  Yes, there's a little more liquid going into the mixture, but the cream not only makes the pudding richer and more flavorful, but it helps the mixture set.  I also omitted the butter and raisins.  Using leftover rice from the previous night's dinner makes it a quicker process.

A previous reviewer mentioned that her egg turned to scramble eggs.  The fix for this is:  after beating your egg,   add a small amount of the hot rice mixture to it and mix immediately.  This tempers the egg and will keep it from "curdling" once it hits the pot.

text:
This is very good, but not great. Let me tell you how to make it outstanding.
   First off, double the recipe. Now instead of doing the two eggs, use three yolks instead. Use 1/2 & 1/2 instead of milk. After you add the rice to the milk mixture, throw in 3 cinnamon sticks.
   After pudding is done, let sit for a few hours. It will have set pretty thick. Add about another 1/2 cup of heavy cream warmed w/ about 2 Tbs of sugar. Mix well. Add about 15 marishino cherries halved. Finally, cover with some merangue and bake until light brown. UNBELIEVABLE!

text:
This really is good, old-fashioned tasting rice pudding.  It reminded me of the rice pudding I had as a kid at the 'Horn&Hardart" restaurant chain here in New York before they went out of business.  I tried for years to find a rice pudding that tasted like that one and this was the closest yet! Do use the short, arborio rice for this particular recipe and follow all the steps and the timing carefully.  I made many batches and tried all different milks: Whole milk, 2%, and 1%, but when I used skim (nonfat) milk, it came out watery, so don't bother trying that.  For a lower fat version, just use 1% milk and lite margarine and it will still come out creamy and nice.  I also experimented and tried one batch with almond extract instead of the vanilla and it was creamy AND dreamy! LOL   Play around with this recipe - it's a keeper!

userID:
3242280
Display Name:
Emery
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/142691.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
It is fantastic with the ratios as written, but the technique needed some tweaking. If you can, use short-grain rice; the texture will be even creamier, and you could probably omit the egg entirely if you wanted to. First, add the salt to the rice as it's cooking the first time. Second, add the vanilla (or scrape out a vanilla bean) and spice if you're using it, such as a cinnamon stick or even just plain ground cinnamon, to the rice with the milk; the rice will soak up the flavor. Third, temper the beaten egg and milk with little bits of hot rice mixture until it's about half and half, THEN add it to the pudding. Fourth, add the sugar with the egg, not before. Also, if you're adding raisins, try soaking them in hot water before adding them; otherwise they will soak up any remaining liquid. The butter really isn't necessary, but if you're going for rich it doesn't hurt it a bit! Thanks for offering this recipe up, Erica.
Review:
Rating:
4
dateLastModified:
2009-11-24T10:15:40.53
helpfulCount:

userID:
857169
Display Name:
MommyFromSeattle
isPro:

506

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/153638.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Good recipe, although it could be creamier. I made the recipe as written and although good, it was a little thin creaminess. Make sure to use a medium or short grain rice to achieve the right texture. Long grain is too firm for pudding. I tend to use Calrose Rice - readily available in all grocery stores. As for the recipe, I use all half n' half and 1 egg yolk. Omitting the egg white creates a more tender pudding. The amount of sugar is fine if eaten warm, but if you plan if eaten cold, sugar needs to be increased to 1/2 cup. Overall, a great base recipe with a few tweaks needed. I will make again with adjustments - half n half and egg yolk only.

text:
This recipe was awesome. It tastes great and is very easy to work with. At first I was reluctant to try this recipe because it recommends med-short grain rice for maximum creaminess and I didn't want to buy new rice when I have a lot of long grain at  home. So what I did was dump left over long grain rice into a food processor and processed it for a few seconds. Voila!!! short-med grain rice. To avoid cooked egg in pudding, I poured 1/2 cup milk into the beaten egg, so to  dilute the egg. I also took other raters advice and added few scoops of the hot pudding from pot into the egg mixture and then poured the whole mixture back into the pudding mixture in the pot. Next time, will try adding coconut milk and dried mangos for a different flavor.
Review:

text:
I've been using this recipe for years.I leave out the raisins and sprinkle cinnamon and nutmeg over the top before serving. To prevent egg from cooking I beat the egg into the remaining 1/2 cup of milk before adding it and whisk quickly into boiling rice mixture. The finished pudding has a very smooth and creamy consistency.You can use almost any rice, I use jasmine rice, but any leftover rice works well. I revised the recipe to change the pudding/rice ratio to make it creamier. I used 2c cooked rice, and doubled everything for the custard recipe.  I am really happy with the result.

When I made up this recipe I used Uncle Bens Instant Long Grain Rice, I believe that made an affect why it did not thicken, since it did not thicked I took about 1/4 cup flour and some water and made a past from it to pour in to thicken it, overall when it was finished it was a very tasty recipe and I would deffinently make it, so if you have trouble thickening yours try the flour and water, worked really great for me, but don't pour it in all at once as it may thicken to much and you don't want that.

Very creamy and sweet.  Excellent! The only changes that I made are that I used two cups of cooked long grain white rice (I like my pudding a bit on the thick side), and increased the vanilla extract to one teaspoon. In addition, I cooked the rice/milk/sugar mixture closer to one half hour on a medium-low heat rather then 15 - 20 minutes on medium heat. This is a keeper for me!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have made this recipe several times with different variations, including berries, spices, Splenda instead of sugar, etc.  It always turns out great.  I have found that mixing the egg and tempering the egg mixture will help prevent scrambling of the egg.  However, my best advice for preventing scrambled egg in your pudding is to use egg substitute instead of a real egg, mix it with the milk, then prior to adding to the pudding, stir the egg/milk mixture with the hot spoon that you have been using to stir the pudding while it is cooking.  While adding the egg mixture, pour very slowly and stir the pudding constantly while pouring.  This combination of easy steps has always resulted in a very creamy, very thick pudding without any bits of scrambled egg.

text:
this is the best rice pudding i've ever had.  i'm enjoying it as a write this review.  it's amazing that something so tasty can result from few ingredients and little time.  i incorporated the suggestions of others: substituted half and half for part of the milk (used about half cup), doubled the vanilla (i actually used leftover vanilla bean from another recipe), decreased the sugar by half, and tempered the egg before adding it to the recipe (stirred a bit of the hot mixture into the egg, then poured the entire mixture into the pan)to avoid scrambling the eggs.  thank you for sharing this recipe!

text:
While the pudding tastes good, once you get it done the right way, I don't think that these directions are correct as written. First, it never says whether you're supposed to cover the pot or not in step two. When uncovered and cooked on medium heat, it never got thick enough. When I tried it covered, the bottom of my pot burned even with very frequent stirring. In the end, I found that I had to simmer it with the cover on in order to get it not burn and to be thick enough.

text:
First attempt at rice pudding - delicious and easy recipe.  Used long grain rice, left out the raisins, doubled the recipe, used 1 can evaporated milk (1.5 cups) + 1.5 c water + another cup of lowfat milk to make 4 cups.  Tasted for sweetness after cooking the rice, milk, and sugar for a few minutes, and added an extra 1/3 to make 1 cup of sugar for a double recipe.  This was perfect for our tastes.  Used a large saucepan to cook the rice, and made the pudding in the same pan.  Loved that the recipe does not include cinnamon -  my family can add spices to taste.  This will be made again.  Big hit over here :)  Thanks for sharing.

Great Job whoever put this up and have fun : )

This was really tasty and easy. I used left over brown rice and it worked fine. I also used currents and a dried berry medley instead of raisins, since it's what I had on hand.

I did have trouble with it thickening at first but once I cranked up the heat a bit, it was fine. If you're having the same problem getting it thick and creamy, make sure the mixture is boiling, and then let it cook for 15-20 minutes.

text:
This is a great recipe. I have made it at least 30 times! My only suggestion to people making it for the first time is to measure exactly (although some times I do add more sugar when my sweet tooth demands it) and I have noticed different brands rice can change the cook time, quantity, and overall consistency. Make sure the rice is cooked completely, and add more water if necessary before preceding and the end product is incredible!

Great recipe.  An easy go-to for leftover rice.  Very comforting on a cold winter night. I really like this recipe and make it often. I add about 50% more sugar though, and I also add a little extra water to the rice. I have found that by doubling the recipe, the end product tends to be creamier than the 4-serving version (easier to cook in a large pot too). It tastes great re-warmed, especially with a little milk poured over it, so for me having leftovers is a good thing. Thanks for the recipe!

text:
A delicious, easy way to use up leftover rice. This was a great wintertime, gluten-free dessert. Just make sure you temper the eggs-- gradually stir in spoonfuls of the hot rice mixture into the eggs until it's heated through. Then add that to the pot. This will keep the eggs from scrambling.

country:
None
text:
I guess I have never had true rice pudding, because ours never had eggs in it when I was a kid.  I didn't much care for the egg in this recipe.  Next time, I'll just leave it out and it's perfect.  I like mine a little on the sweet side, so i think the amount of sugar was perfect.  I added half to begin with, per other reviews suggestion, and ended up using the full amount.  I also used pre-cooked cold rice--the key being to cook the rice with the milk for about 15 min before adding the sugar.  (It's supposed to be hot before you add the sugar.)  This worked perfectly and it was a beautiful texture I've never had with my previous attempts.

text:
This is my GO TO recipe for rice pudding and its my base for horchata too (mexican rice drink) Its my husbands favorite and is WAY better than Kozy shacks! I like it best with small jasmine rice but most of the time i use cheap bulk rice. I use about a half a can of sweetened and condensed soup in mine as well as i prefer using a can of evaporated milk for the milk it calls for and just adding the difference in reg skim milk. I decrease the sugar, sometimes increase it depending on my mood but even when i accidentally doubled the sugar once it was not too sweet at all! I have loved it with more cinnamon and only a fourth cup of sugar before too because thats all i had on hand! I always add nutmeg, allspice and ginger with my cinnamon, it makes the flavor so much deeper and makes me feel more decadent. I have made baked cinnamon apples to top it too with a dollop of whipped cream, same with peaches and strawberries...all if it to die for! wish i had more stars for this!! i have added ground flaz seeds too to get more good out of it and you couldn't even tell at a half cup!!

text:
In a nutshell, what other rates have advised: cook the rice well before adding the sugar. Mix the half cup of milk with the egg before adding and do it slowly and stirring constantly. Sprinkle some cinnamon and or nutmeg after cooking. I would also add: if you're not going to serve immediately, add more water and more milk in the first two stages or you'll end up with a very dry rice mixture just one hour after taking it from the heat.

text:
This is the best rice pudding that I have ever made, and I have tried quite a few recipes! I triple it (otherwise my father eats most all of it within the first day!), use slightly less sugar, and add about 3/4 tsp each of cinnamon and nutmeg when you add the sugar. Just make sure that if you make a larger yield you take into account that the instructions that appear on the site are still for 4 servings and you need to increase those as well. YUMMY!   ALSO, I don't add raisins and you can use any kind of milk, even skim, and it tastes just as great! And, I don't mind using long grain rice as it gives a texture to the pudding, but med. and short make it creamier!

text:
This was a delicious, easy rice pudding.  I think it's a shame when people don't give as many stars as the recipe deserves because they don't know technique.  The recipe doesn't mention it, but you MUST temper your egg before adding it at the end or you will have scrambled egg rice pudding!  This is basically a creme anglaise with rice added - delicious and simple.  I served it warm with some mango chopped up in it.  Very Thai!  Thank you for the wonderful recipe.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this tonight and was somewhat disappointed.  The rice stays too distinct from the pudding with this technique; when cooked in milk, it blends better, which makes the pudding creamier.

I used a mix of 2% milk and heavy cream, brown sugar instead of white (1/3 cup was perfect for me, but I tend to like my rice pudding only mildly sweet).  I used 2 teaspoons of vanilla and 1 or 2 teaspoons of orange zest instead of the raisins and butter.  I then tried the pudding and found it too thin for my taste, so I added a second egg and made sure the mixture made it to 160 degrees again. 

Bottom line: if you have the patience to stir for a while, look for a recipe that cooks the rice in milk.  Maybe crock pot versions will turn out creamier rice without being so hands-on. If you just need some easy pudding that tastes reasonably good, go for this one.  Try it with orange zest sometime, it's good.

For Easter my boyfriend wanted rice pudding. I myself had never even tried it. It turned out so well that he was able to eat 3 bowls after dinner! For a richer flavor I used brown sugar instead of white and (for extra sweetness) added a spoonful of maple syrup. Divine! I have always LOVED rice pudding, but my attempts to make rice pudding in the oven have consistantly been flops!  This stove top recipe is to die for. So creamy, and not grainy at all.  The only thing I'd change is to add less raisins (personal preference) I found that because they are added to the hot liquid they plump up quite a bit, giving the pudding that extra sweetnes that it doesn't really need.  Hats off to Erica for a sensational recipe...now I must go and enjoy another bowl!!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was perfect.  Very creamy.  We added cinnamon, and I didn't have golden raisins on hand, and so I boiled regular raisins so they were plump, and added them.  I also used brown rice, because it was what I wanted to use up.  Another time, I would add less sugar.  I thought it was a little sweeter than it needed to be, perhaps because of the addition of the cinnamon.  Hope to also experiment with cardamom.  For those having problems with scrambling the eggs in the pudding, I did what I do with other custards and spooned some of the hot pudding into the egg/milk mixture that gets added at the end to slowly raise the temp before adding it all back into the hot pudding, and didn't have problems with scrambling the eggs.

text:
This was a really good recipe. I've read that you should use a medium grain rice for rice pudding. I only had long grain so I used that. I can see how a medium would work better but the long grain worked okay. Like some other reviewers I added some cinnamon (around 1/2 tsp). I love raisins in rice pudding so I added more than the 2/3c listed - that was probably a mistake (it was very raisiny). I'd leave it as the 2/3 listed or maybe even down to 1/2c. I used almond milk and it worked well. To make sure I didn't get cooked egg chunks in the pudding I heated the last 1/2 cup of milk in the microwave until warm and then mixed the egg in that before adding the rest of the pudding.

text:
Tastes great, just like any good rice pudding I've ever had. I did some changes that didn't mess with the original recipe, just personal preference. I omitted the raisins, cause I've never had rice pudding with them. I used long grain brown rice cause that's all I had on hand & it took a lot longer to cook than 20 mins, more like 50 mins like it said on the rice package. Also I used my Silk soy milk, cause I dont drink regular milk & right there I made this rice pudding into a complete protein :)! That's exciting! I had to simmer it about 10 mins longer because I used soy milk & I also added 1/3 more sugar. Make sure the egg is beaten well & you add it slowly while continuously stirring it - very important! I topped each serving with cinnamon. Perfect & I like I made it even healthier. Why fix something that isn't broken, this is my go to recipe.

userID:
2632192
Display Name:
Philip Shores
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2882826.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is such a simple and sweet little dish that makes everyone feel warm, especially on those cool autumn or cold winter nights. It's good all year round.

If you follow the directions precisely, you'll get excellent results. The type of rice truly does make a difference. Long grain rice is a completely different texture than, say, short grain rice. I noticed a creamier and thicker texture with short-grained right as opposed to long-grained. It has to do with the starch content in the rice itself.

A small addition that I make to my rice pudding (and it is well loved) - Take 1/4 cup of dried, pitted cherries (you can chop them up if you want) and add to a small sautee pan. Take about 1/8th (2 tablespoons) cup of drinking sherry (I use amontillado, only because it's always in my house - slightly sweet, slightly dry) and pour over the cherries. Saute until the sherry is cooked off into a thicker liquid (or until the cherries absorb the sherry). Add your sherried-cherries when you add the butter and vanilla to the recipe.

Depending on the type of cherries you use, they add a different sweetness as well as a tartness. The sherry adds sweetness and a richness that cannot be matched!
Review:
Rating:
5

This is a great recipe for rice pudding if you are a lover of rice pudding like me!  I personally like mine a little sweeter so next time I will increase the amount of sugar.  Also, I did like others, I added the salt when I cooked the rice initially, I cooked everything in one pot and I also tempered the eggs prior to adding them so that you don't get scrambled eggs.  I left out the raisins b/c I prefer my rice pudding without and also more cold then warm.  No more kozy shack for me!

Would actually give 3-1/2 stars but since I can't I will gladly round it up to 4 *(see update below). Couldn't have been easier to make but needs a bit more flavor for my taste (next time I'll add a couple of cinnamon sticks starting in step 2) & I liked the texture much better before I added the egg (which I tempered with a bit of the hot rice mixture first) so I'll leave that out next time, & I'm still undecided on the butter...! I'm not reducing any stars for the raisins (which I do not like in my rice pudding) because I know these are a matter of personal preference. I am thankful to have found a recipe easy enough for me to mess around with though!***Unfortunately I had to change my rating to a 2 star (down from 4) because after being in the refrigerator for a day it's just a thick glob without a whole lot of flavor (except for vanilla). I hafta throw this batch out & try again now!

This tastes exactly like my Grandmothers double broiler method.  I used skim milk (Grammy swears to use nothing less than 2%) and it turned out just fine.
I do like my rice pudding cold, and after cooling it is no longer creamy.  So I made a second time and reduced to 1 cup cooked rice and the rice still sucked up all the liquid.  I will just keep reducing the rice until I get the consistancy that I like.
Thank you very much for this recipe.  It is excellent.

I'm 7 weeks pregnant and CRAVE rice pudding. I've used this recipe before and doubled it this morning. It will probably be gone by this evening. :)
I ended up using 3 cups cooked rice, 1/2 t salt, 3 cups milk, heaping 2/3 cup sugar, 1 egg, 1/2 t vanilla, and 1 T butter. I also cooked everything longer than recommended but that's because I'm paranoid about under-cooked egg.

text:
Wow!!  This is great!!  Just like my Grandma used to make.  I've been trying to find something to come close to hers and I've finally found it.  As mentioned by others here, don't add the sugar too early.  Make sure the rice is cooked thoroughly, first.  Also, adding the butter during step 1 does make a richer pudding.  And it's always ggod practice to temper the egg mixture before adding it to the hot pudding. 
This is fantastic right off the stove (let it cool for a few minutes), cold from the fridge, or warmed up the next day.  Thanks for a keeper!!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/3055.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
A great way to use up your leftover rice and can be made for breakfast or dessert.I followed the ingredients but my cooking procedure was different.What I did was I poured all of the milk,sugar,and salt into a saucepan and let it heat up for at least 5 minutes.Reserve 1/2 cup of the milk mixture for the eggs.Then I added the rice.I then added the raisins so they'll plump up with the rice.While that's thickening,I whisk together the eggs and the reserved milk until it's well-blended.Once the rice is nice and creamy,turn the stove off.Slowly add the egg mixture,then stir everything so it's all incorporated.This keeps the eggs from becoming scrambled.Cook for another 2 minutes,then add a dash of cinnamon before serving.I might leave out the raisins next time because my daughters didn't like them.This is a simple and delicious recipe.

city:

country:
None
text:
I've made this as directed, but this morning I found 1/2 cup of leftover cooked rice in the fridge and experimented with making rice pudding for one in the microwave. I simply cut the proportions in my head (though using a whole egg worked fine). I used my 4 cup pyrex measuring cup, and cooked the rice, milk, sugar & salt for on high for one minute at a time, stirring after each minute (3-4 minutes total). Then, I stirred some of the hot mixture into the beaten eggs first, to make sure I didn't cook the egg. After adding the egg & raisins back in, I cooked it just another 45 seconds or so, then added vanilla & butter.

A nice breakfast & diet friendly : )

Delicious seasoning and flavor, but missing one star because it was a thinner and soupier than I'd like the first time I made it. A dash of corn starch thickens it right up though. Just try about half a tsp to start with and add more to get the consistancy you want while the rice is soaking into the milk and sugar.

I just happened to come along this recipe today and it  was AWESOME!!!!...I have only ever made rice pudding from a mix once before and it was nasty grainy and gross!  But this recipe was easyand it soooo creamy, reminds me of what my Grandma (nanny : )  )   would make.  I loved it!!!  This is definitely a keeper. Thank you previous reviewers for the great advice!  Awesome recipe!!!

I am on a sugar, dairy, and wheat free diet. So I made this recipe using brown rice and coconut milk. Instead of butter I used coconut oil. This is definitly a good option for those who can't have white rice or sugar!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
OH MY WORD! If you want know the KEY to getting that Kozy Shack, prepared pudding texture, here it is: THE RICE. You need to have short grained rice. And don't go to your store looking for " short grained rice" cause you won't find it. It's called Risotto or Arborio. It is a bit more expensive( I paid about $6 for 36oz tub)but so worth it. It's made to cook much creamier. Make this recipe with long grain it and it will be good, short grain it will be great, Risotto it will be AMAZING! I used 1/2 cup of Splenda and tasted it and felt it was sweet enough. Delicious even w/o sugar

This was the perfect way to use up my leftover Steamed White Rice from the other night! I doubled the recipe. So doubled the cooked rice amount to 3 cups, doubled the milk and used whole to make it creamier. I used 2 small eggs. Cooked it for the full 20 minutes before adding the milk/egg mixture. Added the butter and vanilla at the end but omitted the raisins and sprinkled with Pumpkin Spice, as suggested by some reviewers. Everyone LOVED it! We all wanted seconds. Except my 5 year old son, who wanted THIRDS!  ;) I will definitely keep this recipe in my arsenal! Thank you!!!  :)

text:
This came out perfect on the first try. I followed the recipe but used some common sense: my rice was short grain brown, and wasn't going to cook in the time given, so I just cooked the portion until the water was absorbed. Then I stirred the milk, sugar and salt in together and cooked *until it was creamy*! I blended my beaten egg into the remaining milk, and drizzled into rice while stirring (no problems). Added the rest of the ingredients and presto! Perfection. So, I think that my rule is make sure you have reached the desired results before going on to the next step. That avoids problems in the end and having to find shortcuts to accommodate the error.

text:
The pudding is quick and simple, but I must stress that the instructions must be complete. My daughter found this recipe, and even on medium-low to low, the rice-milk-sugar-salt mixture continued to scorch. Following my instincts, I stirred constantly until thick and smooth. If you let the milk stand in the pan for even a few minutes, it will burn. Stir constantly!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/18.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Good, solid, rice pudding recipe. A few tips: 1)quick rice is ok if you don't have time for the slow cook variety. 2)salt your rice in the water 3)temper your eggs before adding to the hot milk/rice mixture. Do this by adding a little of the hot milk to your eggs to bring up the temperature. If you don't, you may wind up with scrambled eggs in your pudding. 4)Use evaporated milk for cooking and baking; it's creamier and makes for smoother baked goods and cream sauces. 5)season with sugar after you get the pudding to the right consistency.   For a grown up "kick", soak your raisins in brandy, drain and then add to your pudding.  Good winter dish!

text:
This works very well with soy milk too! It's still very creamy that way, and there's no strange taste to it; you wouldn't know that it wasn't real milk. (I used Silk Brand, which isn't overly sweet but has a little of its own vanilla flavor too.) I used to think I didn't like rice pudding (the idea scared me when I was a kid for no good reason) but after trying a bit in a restaurant, I wanted to make my own, and this was wonderful.

text:
This was my first attempt at making rice pudding.  I was looking for a cheap dessert and I have to say that it was AMAZING.  I made it with long grain brown rice, half reconstituted nonfat powdered milk and half skim milk, and I used regular raisins.  After reading the reviews, I was afraid with all of the changes, especially the long grain brown rice, that it wasn't going to turn out right but boy was I wrong!  It took longer than the 15-20 minutes to thicken up, but I wasn't surprised with the brown rice.  I mixed in a little cinnamon with the vanilla and butter and WOW.  So good I was licking the spoon!

text:
Just like I remember as a child!  I skipped the raisins on personal preference.  I have made this with skim milk, 1% milk, and combinations including half and half - it always works!  Also, be sure to incorporate your eggs by slowly adding a little of the hot rice/milk to the beaten eggs while stirring before adding the whole mixture into the hot pot. This will keep your eggs from cooking into little bits!

I've feel it's important to rate a recipe after several attempts, and I'm not disappointed.  I've made my best batch when sugar was decreased to a little less than 1/4 cup.  As suggested, I added salt to the water for cooking the rice and made everything in the same pot.  Once done, I seasoned with cinnamon, nutmeg, and about 1/8t of fresh ground/crushed cardamom.  Great flavor and creamy texture yet not too sweet!

text:
Homemade rice pudding is a comfort food from heaven... and I’m thankful for this simple way to make it. This is the recipe I have been searching for and the best way to make use of that left over rice sitting in the fridge. Using Arborio rice makes for the creamiest of puddings. I use brown sugar (instead of white) as it has a richer taste. Even more decadent is using maple syrup to sweeten it. My one child loves it with raisins and cinnamon and my other likes it plain with a dollop of tart raspberry jam on top. Served warm or cold, this recipe is so versatile and always delicious. Thanks so much for sharing, Erica.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674157.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is really good and creamy. I've made it a few times and like other reviewers have stated, the 20 minutes in the first cooking stage to cook the rice isn't enough. When I did that the first time it was a little crunchy. Now I cook it for 30 minutes and add just a touch more water, and now it's great. Also when you add the egg, mix it with the milk (when you add the milk at the end) and that will prevent the egg from making scrambled eggs.
Sometimes I use half milk and 1/2 half and half or cream to make it even creamier. 
It's delicious and easy and I usually always have the ingredients, so it makes for a nice treat once in a while!

text:
This recipe is great!  I found it one night when trying to figure out what to do with all that leftover chinese takeout white rice.  Its great, because sticky rice is perfect in this recipe.  I've determined 2 things about this...one, you can easily half the whole recipe and it still comes out great.  The second thing is if you choose to serve it warm, which I do, adding an extra egg makes it really rich and creamy and slightly more custard like.  Also, I used all our leftover milk products - fat free half and half, light cream, heavy cream, 1% milk - together to make the 2 cups and it was still fantastic!

None
text:
I am a huge fan of rice pudding and this recipe is great! I used leftover Chinese white rice, because I am not the world’s best rice-maker! It saved a lot of time and turned leftovers into an amazing dessert! The first time I made it I didn’t feel it was thick enough so I cooked it on medium a little longer than it called for. Once I took it off the stove and let it sit the rice absorbed more than I would have liked. So the second time I made it and took it off the stove after 20 minutes, still a little soupy. After it sat it was much more creamy, and kept better over night. I sprinkled cinnamon on top. Serve warm or cold. It was a hit both ways! Thanks.

After a few months of cooking what everybody else wants, I will treat myself to warm rice pudding.  (No one else here likes rice!)  This recipe, by far, is the best that I have tried yet.  It makes a very comforting and rich rice pudding.  I would suggest, however that you use only half the sugar--you could add more individually if you like.  Also, do temper your egg before adding so you won't get scrambly bits.  Excellent recipe.

country:
None
text:
Oh, this is wonderful, had it for dinner - creamy, filling and comforting. Like the Kesari Pudding which I adore (using semolina) and similar to farina pudding, I did this the same way. I doubled the batch; melted the butter in the pot and adding about 1/3 cup chopped pecans (no raisins at hand) until fragrant and then covering the rice with it b4 doing the rest as per recipe. I used evaporated milk (not condensed), jasmine rice, dashes of nutmeg and cinnamon and also brown sugar; such a comfort food. Thanks very much Erica. Luscious. Oh, and the reviews helped much too, thanks all.

text:
Pretty good. A word of warning if you make this with leftover rice that was cooked with salt, leave out the salt when you make the pudding. I didn't think about that when I  made the puuding tonight. Other than being a bit too salty, the pudding was very good. Soft and creamy, not hard and dry like many baked rice puddings.

text:
I am a rice pudding fanatic and this pudding is sooo good!  I used one can of evaporated milk to mix in the cooked rice and finished it with a little more than a half cup of whole milk.  I noticed after I had put it in the fridge to chill that I forgot to add the melted butter, but that didn't take away from the taste.  The only thing I would change when I make it again is to use a little less rice....but that's not a flaw in the recipie, just my personal preference.  I am so glad I found this recipie!  Next time I make it I may add some cardamom pods and slivered almonds to give it a more Middle Eastern feel.  Thanks Erica!

text:
This recipe is wonderful, thanks so much for sharing this, Erica!  I just made it tonight and my two teens ate it all up immediately; it was that good!  I used long grain rice (making sure it is cooked fully in the first step) and had no trouble at all.  I kept having to turn down the heat while cooking down the milk & sugar so it wouldn't cook too quickly.  Mixing the beaten egg into the milk just prior to adding it is a step in similar recipes, so I did that here too.  The results were better than expected and smelled heavenly too.  A real keeper!

text:
This is the most delicious rice pudding I've ever had. It's easy to make, even for me!(I'm 12). I used short grain white rice,and it tastes amazing. Even though I cooked the rice a bit long, and ran out of milk (I had to use a 1/2 cup of half and half), it tastes amazing. The reason the person who made the recipe with brown rice didn't have it turn out was because you can't use brown rice! It won't have the same flavor! I highly recommend this recipe for a quick and easy treat.

text:
This is delicious rice pudding. I used cooked jasmine rice and dark raisins since they were what I had in the fridge. I beat the egg with the 1/2 cup of milk and when the hot mixture was cooked I tempered the egg mixture with a little of the it, beating it so as to not curdle it. Then I added the egg mixture back into the hot mixture mixing rapidly.

text:
For anyone that has an issue with the chunky egg, the key is to add small amounts of the hot rice to the egg and stirring to slowly warm it before adding it to the rest of the rice. Love this recipe. Very simple and very tasty.

text:
What a fabulous recipe!  I made this to serve 40+.  Followed the recipe exactly, except that I did as others and used only the one pot, both for the trial at home for my husband and myself and for the 40+ at our Senior Center - although next time I'd split it off in to two pots rather than the one - because it got too thick at the bottom of the pot. When reheating, it definitely requires more milk to return it to a desirable consistency but the quality remains the same.  I've detested Rice Pudding but once I tasted this pudding, I kept taking another spoonful, and another spoonful and ....

text:
My husband is being treated for cancer, during the treatments he developed a bad case of Thrush.  He could hardly eat anything. Nothing taste good to him.  I was pulling my hair out trying to find something that appealed to him when I ran across this recipe.  I did modify it a bit. For obvious reasons I left out the raisins(choking hazard) and for the 1/2 cup of milk I subbed half and half.  I beat the eggs into the half and half and then tempered it with the hot mixture before pouring it into the hot rice and milk.(This is for Jackie, I did this to keep the egg from curdling like yours) The results was a beautiful, creamy rice pudding that my husband was able to enjoy. Thank you Erica G. This is going into my recipe file to be made again and again.

text:
Whipped this up during my lunch break in preparation for a "Comfort Food" dinner party. Doubled the recipe and achieved a perfectly creamy and balanced rice pudding. Added ample raisins (red) and a DASH OF RUM at the sugar/salt stage to allow PLUMPING time (oh, so luscious). Upon reheating, I will add the butter -- or allow the guests to add a slim pat at their discretion and cross my fingers they will! 

Save this to your box, ladies and gents, and teach it to your children. A worthy staple recipe for "wow" on a shoestring. 

TIP: Combine the beaten egg to the milk before adding to the recipe at the end to avoid any unpleasant scrambling of the egg!

text:
Oh, my! This is SO good! Love the light creamy flavor. I followed a few other reviewers suggestions: I made sure my rice was cooked to tender before I added it to the milk/sugar mixture. For some reason, my rice took about 25 minutes to cook. I must have had the temp down too low. And, thank you to Shaz for the advice of adding a little rice mixture at a time to the egg and milk before adding it to the pot so it wouldn't come out as “egg-drop” rice. I did make 3 slight changes. First, I used Lactose-free 1% milk because of my dairy issues. It came out nice and creamy still. I used just a little less than the 1/3 cup of sugar just to cut back a little. I think it would be fine with the full 1/3 cup of sugar, but I personally don't like things very sweet. And, I didn't put the raisins in it because I am not overly fond of raisins. I will definitely make this recipe again. Thanks!

text:
I really love rice pudding so I was looking forward to trying this. Consistency was great but was a little disappointed - was very bland/unsweetened.  I wanted to try this as a "healthier" version so I followed the cook's notes and used Splenda (1/3 the amount, as stated).  Moral of this story: healthy isn't always better. Lol Needless to say, I won't be doing that again.  I don't usually put raisins in my rice pudding but added them after to get some sweetness. I think this addition saved the day! Although the end result wasn't as sweet as it was super simple and had a great consistency making this worth trying again. Next time I will use sugar or more Splenda though.  UPDATE: after refrigerating I had to reduce my 3 stars to 1. Although it did sweeten up a tad, it completely dried out!!!! There goes any points for consistency.  I will try adding some milk to "water it down" & hopefully this helps - I'm determined. Plus it would be a shame to see good ingredients go to waste (I even made a double batch).

Very good and simple way to use leftover rice!  To keep egg from curdling, add some of the rice pudding slowly to the egg while quickly stirring the mixture.  Then add the egg back to the rice pudding and stir for the two minutes instructed.  Great recipe!

text:
Excellent!! I didn't have any raisins so that will come the next time I make it. The only thing I changed was in the instructions. I mixed the first part exactly as written, the second part after the simmering for 15 or so minutes, I mixed the remaining ingredients all in a measuring cup making sure to beat the egg very well. I then tempered it with the hot by very large spoonful's in measuring cup, then added to pot and cooked for another 5 minutes. NO SCRAMBLED EGGS, simply the best creamiest rice pudding!! Thank you for the recipe.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe turned out amazing!! It was my first time making rice pudding, I've made it a couple times since. It is great as long as you follow the recipe and use short or medium grain rice, as Erica states. I substituted coconut milk for regular milk and it turned out really well. If you like coconut you will like this. Also for anyone having trouble with the egg. You have to add egg to rice pudding to thicken it. If you don't want your egg to cook into chunks break the egg into the cup of left over milk. Mix the egg and the milk mixture until the egg is essentially dissolved into the milk and the mixture is an off yellow colour. If you warm the mixture up for 30 seconds - 1 min in the microwave and then stir the mixture one more time before slowly adding it you are guaranteed to have no egg chunks and amazing rice pudding.

None
text:
With cinnamon this is a great recipe! I do not use 2 pots to cook this, instead I temper both the milk and eggs when adding them to the pot of rice, just add a few spoonfulls of hot rice to the milk and egg before adding them and it will not curdle or leave chunks of cooked eggs like some reviewers stated. I also like to add a pinch of nutmeg (more than a pinch will ruin this recipe, I learned that the hard way). The second time I made this I significantly reduced the sugar and replaced it with baking Splenda, I couldn't tell the difference.. In the end this recipe is pretty good the way it is, but adding cinnamon makes it a 5 star for me.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is truly excellent rice pudding! It's so easy to make and it comes out tasting perfect. I used 5 teaspoons of Splenda instead of sugar and I used 1% milk. I am lactose intolerant, so I used Lactaid milk, which is a little sweeter than regular milk because of they way they remove the lactose. So if you're using regular milk, you might want to add a teaspoon or so more Splenda than I used. Also, the recipe doesn't remind you to temper the egg before you add it to the hot rice. Don't forget to do so, or you'll likely end up with scrambled egg in your custard.

text:
Just for background, I'm a guy with too many years experience to remember in professional cooking environments- saute, broiler, hot/cold apps, pantry, desserts…I've done it all and forgotten most of it! Bored tonight, I just slapped this recipe together with what I had laying around the kitchen- long grain rice instead of med/short, imitation vanilla, barely paying attention really- guess I still have "the touch"- it  came out *much* better than expected…better than Cozy Shack brand prepackaged by far.  Great easy recipe and prep.  Next time I'd use a tad less sugar- my kid gets too much already.  Kudos!

I'll add one more 5 star review...this is just like my grandmother used to make when I was growing up!  Didn't have raisins so omitted those.  I also mixed my egg and final 1/2 cup milk together very well and then poured it through a mesh strainer to avoid any eggy strands.  Will definitely make this again and can't wait to try it with raisins!  Served with whipped cream and a dash of cinnamon on top.

text:
This recipe should be kept in a safety deposit box.  i've made it using the exact recipe, and also using brown rice with evaporated milk.  The best tips are to add the sugar when the rice is fully cooked, and to temper the egg before adding to the mixture.  The only warning i have is to not prepare this recipe at night, because you will have a restless sleep knowing what a treasure there is in the fridge...it is that excellent.

text:
Love this! I followed other reviews that said to wait a little before putting the sugar in, so the rice would get softer. I also put some of the hot rice mixture into the egg and milk before pouring it into the rice, so the egg wouldn't cook in chunks in the rice pudding. I leave out the raisins because sometimes I just want the creamy rice pudding taste with whatever spices I feel like at the moment (cinnamon and nutmeg right now). Very good recipe!

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
I'm a huge fan of rice pudding and this is one of the best recipes I've ever had. It's so creamy and soft! I've never made homemade rice pudding before, just semi-homemade using Jello's cook & serve pudding. It was very easy to make and in total took me about 30 minutes. I had a huge bag of rice we bought at an Asian market, kinda like sticky rice, and used this short grain rice. It came out so soft and tender. The only modifications I made were omitting the raisins and adding 1/2 tsp of cinnamon. It tasted great warm but I prefer my rice pudding cold, so I put it in the fridge and I think it tasted better once it had time to sit. My husband loved it and he's not the biggest fan of rice pudding. Will definitely be making again!!

text:
So simple and so delicious! I made it with nunaturals stevia instead of the sugar. Also before making it tempered the egg by putting it in a glass of hot water (in the shell)while I made the rest, then at the end turned stove off then add the warm egg, but leave on the burner (turned off)while you stir it 2 mins. This prevented it from leaving egg floaties.

text:
I've never been a fan of rice pudding but my fiancee loves it.  I made this for him this weekend & even I enjoyed it!  I omitted the raisins & added cinnamon & nutmeg to it, also because I didn't have milk in the house, I used 1 c. whipping cream and 1 c. half & half.  Using Italian Style Rice (High starch) it had a wonderful creamy texture & a great vanilla flavor.  I used Splenda as he's diabetic & for once he couldn't tell!  We've found that the Splenda usually goes salty in baking, but this time it didn't.  This has been added to our recipe collection! Thank you for sharing such a wonderful recipe.

I had some left over rice in the fridge, so I decided to make this recipe as an alternative to breakfast cereal on a Tuesday morning. As long as you're planning for it, there was plenty of time to cook and eat it before work, especially since my rice was already cooked. I loved this recipe! It cooked up nice and smooth, very creamy and delicious. It took a while to start thickening, but it was done within the 20 minutes stated. I would probably reduce the sugar in the future just to match my own tastes, but otherwise this recipe is a keeper! Add some nuts and berries and you've got a great new breakfast option.

userID:
5073915
Display Name:
ginny005
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3805559.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I had been looking for a baked rice pudding recipe, but the ones I have tried to date have all been a bit disappointing.  So I decided to try this stovetop recipe.  I used short-grain rice and followed the recipe almost exactly.  I doubled the ingredients as we are a large family, but omitted the raisins as we have never been fans of raisins in rice pudding.  I added the sugar nearer the end of the cooking time and I decided to start with just half the quantity and add the rest as required. I found that half the amount was sweet enough for our tastes.  I will also reduce the amount of vanilla next time.    For the second addition of milk, I replaced regular milk with evaporated milk to try and make the pudding more creamy.  Overall, this is a great recipe.  It's very easy and makes a good pudding.  But I would have liked it to have tasted creamier, so I will probably try cooking the rice in milk next time.  I will say tho, that the leftovers heated up the next day tasted much better.  The pudding thickened, so I added more evaporated milk while heating and it was much closer to the creamy texture I was hoping for.  If you are looking for a good rice pudding recipe, I would definitely recommend you try this.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
LOVE this recipe. My family is constantly asking me to make this ever since I tried it out.  Definitely take one of the other user's advice and make sure not to add the sugar until the rice is thoroughly cooked/ to the softness that you would like it at!  One of my other tricks is to plump the raisins.  To do this:
Place the raisins in a small saucepan, and add just enough water to cover them.  Put the heat on low until it comes to a light boil, then turn off heat and cover for 20 minutes or so.  Drain and add raisins when the pudding is ready.

I also add a small dollup of whipped cream and sprinkle some cinnamon over top when complete... DELICIOUS! - Thank you for this recipe!

text:
Oh my goodness, I have made this recipe twice and let me tell you, this second time making it I could not WAIT to review. I was going to wait until my batch had cooled in the refrigerator but this is just TOO magnificent.
The first time I made it as the recipe called. Maybe I added a little more sugar. It was not very fantastic. It was "okay" warm and bad after it had cooled at room temp (and been in the refrigerator)
This time, however, I made a few changes. 
First, I boiled 1 cup of water with 1/2 cup of milk. I put the rice into that and I added 2 tablespoons of butter and let it cook as is called. Then I added 2/3 cup of sugar (I like my rice pudding sweet). I added another tablespoon of butter and two teaspoons of vanilla extract and I swear to God this is the best rice pudding I've ever had. It's pretty yellow (from all the butter haha) but man, is it good!

text:
For those of us living in hot climates, this stovetop version is fantastic, because it doesn't heat up the kitchen with a hot oven.  I did not make this recipe as written.  After reading other reviews, I added more milk (a cup more) and a whole tsp. of vanilla.  The texture was rich and creamy - totally delicious!  I also want to note that I had no problem using long grain rice, but I do know that shorter grain rices will make starchier rice.  I'm saving this is as my go-to rice pudding recipe.

country:
None
text:
This was delicious! The moment I tasted it, it reminded me of home, it's just how rice pudding should be. It was thick, rich, creamy and had JUST the right amount of sweetness, perfect texture, it was heavenly! I only made slight changes to the method. I added the salt when boiling the rice in water, and I took the advice of one reviewer and did not add the sugar until the end with the egg. I mixed the egg with the remaining 1/2 cup milk and the sugar, then mixed in a few spoonfulls of the pudding to temper the egg before adding it to the pudding. I used arborio rice, the kind you would use for rissoto. The cinnamon and nutmeg sprinkled over the top really makes it! Thank you for this recipe, it will be the only one I use for rice pudding!

text:
Although I made a few of my own adaptations, this recipe I'm sure would taste excellent exactly as it is presented to us. My modifications were as follows: I used Basmati rice instead of regular white. I used skim milk. Instead of white sugar, I substituted 3 tbsp of organic wildflower honey (add a little bit of honey at a time until its sweetened to your liking, I often find desserts are too sweet, so I cut back on that, plus honey is sweeter than sugar). I soaked the raisins for 10 minutes in about two cups of warm water and strained them before adding them to the pudding. I added a handful of toasted cashews at the end with the raisins. 'Twas delicious!

text:
I highly recommend this rice pudding recipe because it's very tasty. It turned out extremely well compared to other recipes I've tried. I added more raisins (almost 1 cup) and I added 1 tsp of vanilla instead of 1/2 tsp. The only issue I had was the cooking of the rice. I boiled the water, put the rice in and then simmered it for 20 mins. but some of it browned and stuck to the bottom of the pot. I think I might have simmered it at too high of a heat, didn't use enough water, or just cooked it a bit too long. Next time I might put in 2 cups of water to boil the rice and cook it for only 15 minutes. I also used short grain white rice which made it very creamy and thick. I would have tried medium grain rice, but I couldn't find this type. I will definitely make this again because it's great!

text:
This rice pudding is delicious. Even my avowed rice pudding hating husband liked it. I made it with arborio rice, half and half instead of milk and used only 1/4 cup sugar. I also made it in one pot - just poured the milk, etc. over the rice once it had cooked. My one comment is that it thickened significantly when it cooled. I will have to stir more milk to get it back to a creamy consistency before serving.

text:
This recipe gets five stars.  Okay I did everything in one pot.  Make sure you boil the water before adding the rice to cook, then cover with lid and make sure you lower the heat way down and leave it alone.  The next step, I added the milk, sugar, butter and cinnamon to get creamy for the time it said to cook on med heat.  Last step, I lowered the heat way down again when adding the egg with milk.  Make sure you are stiring and don't stop.  I ate it warm topped with cinnamon.  It was great.  We will be making this over and over.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674169.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
VEGAN/VEGETARIAN version.  I cooked this using canned coconut milk (it's what I had on hand).  I also used jasmine rice (again it's what I had on hand)  I added the sugar to the coconut milk while the rice was cooking so it would dissolve.  Add the egg (skip for vegan) to the remaining milk and beat.  I also tossed in some cinnamon and clove.  Tossed in the raisins (regular, not golden, on hand).  When the 20 minute cook time was done (the one with the coconut milk added) I took a spoon full of the rice mixture and added right to the remaining milk, egg, raisin, spice mixture to temper a bit and popped it all back in the big pan and cooked for an additional two minutes.  EXCELLENT and creamy!  I'm going to try this recipe again using vanilla almond milk next time. (oh and I skipped the butter)
******Made it a second time using vanilla flavored almond milk and I also forgot the egg but it turned out just as good!!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've made this twice in about a week and a half. It was my first time making anything like this. My first attempt i used long grain rice (all i have) i cooked it separately (1/2 cup dried rice to 1 cup water cooked up 1 1/2 cups of rice) Used the same pan and added milk (fatfree). I took the tip of waiting to put the sugar in till after your rice is tender. It took a bit of time and stirring alot. The fat free milk thickened quite well. I used splenda (it was ok in the recipe) but when it came down to adding the egg. I did temper it but i guess i didn't do well enough. I had bits of egg in the pudding. The second attempt. I made sure i beat the egg and milk together well and kept it in a pot on low heat to help make sure i had no eggs in the pudding. I used regular sugar its awhole lot better (imo) but it is sweet so it might not be good for some people. It did cook awhile but ended up with perfect pudding. I also used margerine instead of butter. and no raisins to to preference.

text:
The only thing i did different is seperate the egg yolk and white.. I mixed the yolk in first  and then I beat the egg white until stiff peaks formed then I folded the stiff egg whites at the end.(last 3 mins on cooking stage). it make the rice pudding much more creamy. and light.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674160.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great recipe, followed a few suggestions of others as far as timing.  First, I used short grain brown rice as that's all we had and it turned out great.  Used one large stock pot, not two as instructed.  Cooked rice a little longer until most of the water was gone (brown rice takes a little longer), added butter at this time.  Once butter was melted, added the 1.5 C. milk and salt, and cooked over medium heat for 15 minutes, then added sugar, cooking for 5 more minutes.  Mixed egg & .5 C milk and stirred in about a cup of the hot rice mixture to warm up the egg.  Slowly poured the egg mixture into the large stock pot as to avoid having cooked pieces of egg in final product.  Fished out recipe as directed, cooking for 2 minutes and added vanilla when done.  Turned out perfect!
Review:

text:
I bought some rice pudding at a farmer's market recently and enjoyed it so much that I immediately came home and looked up this recipe. When I made it, it turned out almost exactly like the pudding at the farmer's market. I made some changes based on others' review: I reduced sugar to 1/4 cup and added it after the rice mixture was at a desired thickness, I also stirred some rice mixture to the egg mixture before I poured the egg mixture into the pot. I also eliminated the butter because the farmer's market pudding didn't include butter. Recipe was creamy and delicious. I made it a second time and forgot the vanilla and it was still just as delicious.

city:

None
country:
None
text:
First of all - you MUST use short grain rice. It's the standard risotto rice and it makes this super creeeeamy. I've made with whole milk and skim.  honestly, fantastic either way. So if you want to spare the fat and calories, it really doesn't matter. The short grain rice - I used Arborio - this is the CREAMY factor. You MUST cook the rice until tender, and feel free to add a dash of vanilla flavoring and plenty of spice when throwing in the milk and sugar - I added extra sweetmess with a touch of dark brown sugar WITH the white sugar and plenty of "apple pie spice." OH. So good! I've read about making chocolate rice pudding, I'm on a mission to incorporate this recipe with CHOCOLATE. I've read you can also use BROWN rice for rice pudding. Might be a tasty alternative. TRY IT! YUM!

text:
My husband likes the Kozy Shack brand of rice pudding, so last holiday season I made a recipe I saw on a celebrity chef cooking show.  I thought it was okay, but the hubby howled in disapproval making it clear that it was not okay to serve this to him again.  The message - do not mess with a classic and make it something high falutin'!  Budget's a little too tight this month for a Kozy Shack indulgence, so I persuaded the man that I should try again and do it *right*  ;-) I chose this recipe, and because I was using up pantry extras I added a couple of tablespoons of cream, and a package of vanilla sugar.  I had some giant raisins and I soaked them in water first.  To top it off, I sprinkled on a light dusting of nutmeg.  I have redeemed my rice pudding reputation from the dust bin of Christmas past!  Thanks for the great recipe - easy and just right for the picky guy.

None
text:
Awesome recipe. Here are my modifications. 1: Let the raisins sit in a bowl of boiled water. This will help rehydrate them, and plump them up. 2: The egg and 1/2 cup of milk should sit out to warm up a bit. You never want to dump cold milk and egg into a warm bath. 3: When it comes time to combine the egg/milk with the rice, add some of the warm rice mixture to the egg/milk first to ease the temperature up, then add back into the rice mixture. 4: Use whole milk. Skim milk or 1% just doesn't cut it.

text:
I have made this recipe dozens of times,  and it turns out perfect every time.  Sometimes I make it as written,  sometimes I change it up a bit by adding nutmeg,  or pumpkin pie spice,  or extra cinnamon.  Sometimes I add raisins,  or Craisins ,  or other dried fruit.  Sometimes I don't. I always use leftover medium grain rice and  1% milk. Sometimes I cover it when I put it in the fridge d it stays creamy on top.  Sometimes I sprinkle liberal amounts of cinnamon and don't cover it and it develops a bit of a film on top.This recipe has never let me down.

city:

country:
None
text:
This was a really good recipe, but quite bland without any seasonings. I added a pinch of allspice (maybe 1/8 t) and about 1/2 t cinnamon, along with a dusting of cinnamon over the top when served. I substituted fructose crystals for the sugar, and followed the suggestions of others not to add the sweetener until the pudding was the consistency I wanted with just the rice, salt and milk. One thing to keep in mind is that it will REALLY firm up as it cools, so you may want to stop simmering while it is still on the soupier side. By the time I got to the event where I was serving it, the pudding had thickened a bit too firmly. Still a wonderful recipe that I will be making again! Thanks, Erica!

text:
I changed this up only slightly. I used soymilk instead of regular (soNice, organic, original) and left my rice (jasmine) slightly moist.  I omitted raisins (can substitute with dried cranberries), as well.  Oh, and with fake extract, I used 1tsp, but with organic extract I would stick with 1/2 tsp as real vs fake flavour is very different.  (real, organic is a stronger extract as opposed to the fake flavoured stuff).   Another tip: warm the milk, sugar, salt in pan while the rice is cooking.    This is just delectible!  Absolutely keeping this one on file!

country:
None
text:
Very nice, particularly for Americanized pallet.  'Not the baked, more austere Celtic sort at all.  Hence only 4 stars, although my family enjoyed it, as will my friends from the southeastern states.  It's a totally dependable recipe if what you want is a rather sweet, wet, creamy pudding.  I substituted 1t stevia for sugar, added 1/2 t nutmeg to the flavorings and omitted the raisins as a nod to my guys' preferences.

text:
Before I give my review, I should admit that I've never had rice pudding before and was totally clueless on what the end product is supposed to be like. So I read the reviews before making this and did two things: used 3/4 c Half and Half with 1 1/4 c. Skim Milk, and tempered the egg first with some of the hot mixture. I am now wondering why I've never had this delicious dessert before! It was perfect! It was very rich and creamy, with the perfect amount of sweetness. Even rice pudding virgins like me will find this very easy.

None
text:
Yielded to 8 servings. Used skim milk because that's what I had in hand. Didn't stir in sugar until it was at the right consistency. Used 1/2 cup of white sugar instead of the 1/3 it called for. Then added an additional 1/4 cup of brown sugar. Tempered the egg mixture with the warm mixture so it would blend easier. Used half amount of raisins. Added 1 teaspoon cinnamon powder. Let it simmer for a little bit longer to have a thicker consistency. This tasted better than the store-bought rice pudding I always get! Thanks!

text:
Fantastic - even with my numerous changes. I used skim milk, and half white rice/ half brown (both long grain and it was still super tasty). I also used 2 packets of stevia (the actual pure stevia, not one of the new hybrid brands) instead of the sugar. Added the vanilla to the egg mixture, and took another reviewer's advice about warming it with a spoonful of the rice mixture before stirring it into the pot. Topped it with raisins (instead of cooking them) and cinnamon. My husband was very happy :-)  Important note: during the 2nd step, when cooking the rice in the milk, I recommend leaving the pot uncovered, and stirring occasionally.

None
text:
I absolutely adore this recipe. It's my go-to recipe for plain rice pudding. I do change the ingredients a bit, though - I double the amount of egg and vanilla, because I like my rice pudding really custardy. I've also come up with a chocolate variation - increase the amount of sugar to around 1/2 cup (more or less, depending on how sweet you want it), then add 1/4 cup baking cocoa to the pudding after adding the egg. This makes a deliciously chocolatey version of rice pudding.

text:
"THE Best" I found this recipe 4 days ago and have made it 3 times since then. It's so easy and you can change it with no ill effects to suit your mood/pantry. If your pudding wasn't creamy enough,chances are that you're using the wrong type of rice. What's even more easy and foolproof then tempering the egg is just beating the egg yolk with the 1/2c milk then adding slowly to the rice mixture.

text:
This is GREAT!!!  I made a few changes based on what I had in the kitchen to work with, and it still came out perfect!  I used long grain rice dispite lots of other reviews saying that medium was the key...it didn't make much difference to me.  I also added a little bit more sugar, and used a mixture of skim milk and heavy cream because I didn't have enough milk and I'm actually glad I did...it gave it a rich creamy taste!  I don't care for raisins so I left them out.  I also added a little bit of vanilla (on accident) into the mixture with the eggs and then I added it again with the butter at the end and I think that also gave it a nice flavor. I will be making this again ...and again and again, but will most likely double the recipe in the future!  Thanks!

city:

None
country:
None
text:
My husband & I loved it!  Will make again & again..... excellent served with cinnamon &  whipped cream.  As suggested by others, I made a few mods.:   1. For extra flavor, I added a touch of vanilla extract to the water when I cooked the rice in microwave rice cooker.   2. Added the sugar (1/2 cup) after the rice, milk & salt had cooked for 10 minutes (about a 1/4 cup extra milk too) then cooked 10 mins more.  3. Made sure to beat the egg & then wisk in the milk before adding to rice/milk mixture(you won't end up with egg pieces in pudding).   4. I doubled the vanilla & left out the butter & raisins. Love it!!! Thanks for sharing this recipe.

country:
None
text:
Try it BEFORE knocking it. This is an EXCELLENT recipe! Produces a nice, creamy white rice pudding -- very similiar to a name brand product in the grocery store. It is not "eggy" at all. I followed the recipe as written, with the exception of adding the eggs. Be sure to temper your eggs before adding them to the hot rice mixture -- or you will end up with scrambled eggs in your pudding. Thanks for sharing Erica. If you are using leftover rice, be sure to watch your measurements! You'll need to double the amount of rice.

text:
I'm not too familiar with rice pudding but I think this turned out great. I omitted the raisins and added cinnamon. This is one of my husband’s favorite childhood treats and this is how he remembers it.  I was very careful to temper the egg before mixing it in and the consistency was nice and creamy with no hint of stringy egg. To temper, I whisked the last 1/2 cup milk with the egg and gradually added about a cup of the hot portion a spoonful at a time while continuously stirring. I then  dumped that back in, kept stirring and it did the trick.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
Thanks to the previous reviewers who mentioned to temper the egg first--I probably wouldn't have thought to do it until it was too late otherwise!

Other reviews mentioned that to get the recipe creamy, you should use short or medium grain rice. Well, since I have bags and bags of long grain, I wasn't about to go buy more for just one recipe. I don't know how much creamier it could be with the shorter grains, but mine turned out great. I did cook only 2/3 of a cup, and *still* had 2/3 of cooked rice left over that I had to pull out; 3/4 C. of long grain would make too much for the recipe!  
For those who like cinnamon in their pudding, I added mine right in the water with a pinch of salt to infuse it right into the rice.
I also soaked my raisins while the rice was cooking (something I do whenever I bake with raisins so that they don't end up dried up, crunchy, or worse, burnt mounds.)  
Very tasty!

Display Name:
emin8r
