https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614284.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This pudding turned out creamy (as everyone else is saying).  It is a recipe for creamed rice rather than rice pudding.  I left out the butter and added 1/4 tsp cinnamon instead.  

The sugar is added too soon.  Once you add sudar to a creamed rice recipe, the rice will not break down further.  Test the consistency of the rice about 10 minutes after adding the milk to make sure that it suits, othersie the texture will not be great and the rice won't really be assimilated.

Another suggestion is to whisk the egg and final cup of milk before adding, and to whisk once added.

You can make this recipe in the rice cooker - a big bonus for busy mums. 

This is a good recipe to try, I would suggest you modify it to suit your tastes.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2008-05-15T17:28:41.857

country:

text:
Simply yummy.  Read reviews because other cooks do offer good suggestions.  I did add salt to my rice while it cooked.  I also started heating up the milk and sugar before the rice was done cooking. I microwaved my rice because frankly it always turns out the best for me that way.  Make sure your rice is the consistency you want before you add it to the milk.  It does not change too much, so don't count on too much additional cooking.  I added cinnamon to the egg mixture.  I liked it, but it still needs some tweaks for me.  Of course I tried it really hot.  I was so disappointed in the firs rice pudding I tried, I had to redeem myself.  It is creamy.

text:
YUM YUM YUM!!!  I LOVE rice pudding but finding a sugar free variety in the store is a challenge and expensive.  This was SO easy.  I used Splenda instead or sugar. 
In an effort to keep it super figure friendly I also substituted eggbeater for the eggs and used 2% low carb milk.  I left out the raisins and let hubby and kids add them if they wanted.  It was just such a yummy basic plain rice pudding.  I liked it warm with a generous sprinkle of cinnamon.  Hubby had a cold serving with raisins.  Both of us couldn't get enough.
And for a HUGE 1 cup serving mine only cost about 170 calories.  What a deal!!
I'll be making this a LOT!!!

This is a great recipe. I used basmati rice because I find it to be the easiest white rice to cook. (1part rice:2 parts water, put over heat until it boils and little holes start to form in rice/water, cover and turn off heat leaving on burner, done it twenty minutes.)I also omitted the raisins and added coconut instead.

We give it a 5!  It's delicious, quick and flexible... can't ask for much more!  I made quite a few changes but I think this deserves a 5 for flexiblity too ... doubled recipe, doubled vanilla, used minute rice (3 c. water, 3 c. rice), used what we had for milk (3 c skim, 1 c 1%), added lots of cinnamon and skipped the raisins. It definitely needed cooking longer... maybe 25 mins, but came out creamy and delicious!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674153.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was my first time making and tasting a rice pudding. I didn't have any trouble with the rice pudding thickening; it came out really thick and creamy. However, I was expecting the rice to break down more into an oatmeal or rice porridge-like consistency. I even added a bit more liquid and increased the cooking time by an extra 30-40 minutes to try to break down the rice grains even more but, in the end, the rice still retained its shape and texture. The taste was all right but it was like someone had dropped some cooked rice into my vanilla pudding. I was expecting it to be lumpy since I've seen rice puddings before, but I guess I was looking for something a little more uniform in texture. (I used fully cooked short-grain rice straight from my electric rice cooker which always cooks my rice to perfection) I also thought that 1/4 tsp salt was too much (I used table salt); if I were to make it again, I would reduce or leave the salt out altogether. Maybe this would've been better baked in the oven the traditional way.

text:
This is good if you don't have a lot of time, but I found out why most recipes call for baking it.  The milk bakes into the rice for hours, making the rice softer.  It is very hard to get the rice soft enough when you cook it on the stove.  The flavor was good, though.

text:
My sister-in-law and I got a craving for rice pudding one night last week while I was at her house for dinner. So we logged on and found this quick and easy recipe! This is an excellent rice pudding. We doubled the vanilla, what it calls for just simply isn't enough, and we also sprinkled it with cinnamon and then topped our servings with a scoop of vanilla frozen yogurt. The cold frozen yogurt (or ice cream) on the warm pudding is awesome! The only complaint came from her husband who said he liked it, but he likes baked rice pudding better.

CAMCHES

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674140.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
It was very good; it wasn't too sweet or too heavy.  I had some left over coconut rice I'd made earlier in the week, so I used that.  I didn't want this to be super super rich, but I didn't want to use skim milk (which is what we drink in the house), so I used a can evaporated milk.  Rather than adding the raisins straight from the box, I heated them on the stove with some rum in a separate pot to add flavor.

Someone complained about bits of egg in their pudding.  One thing you should know is you can't add eggs to a hot dish; they'll cook.  So before adding the egg, I tempered them by adding some of the rice mixture.

text:
I have been looking for a baked, yet creamy rice pudding like my gram used to make.  Tonight, I had a taste for rice pudding, but really didn't feel like waiting for the whole baking process, so I gave this one a try.  It is delicious! Reminds me of the brand you can get and the grocery store in those little containers, but much richer.  I used canned evaporated milk, which made a very rich dessert.  I don't like raisins, so I didn't add any of those.  I followed the exact directions and added a little cinnamon and nutmeg at the end.  I had to try some warm.  I thought it could have used a touch more sugar, but even without it it was great and may not be meant to be all that sweet.  Another addition to my recipe box.

Yum! I omitted the raisins and used short-grain rice. I also added a little nutmeg. I served it with a sauce made from peaches and nectarines, and half their weight in caster sugar (about 250g of fruit). The fruit were skinned, diced and cooked over a low heat until all the sugar had dissolved, with a little lemon rind added. Perfect combination!

text:
Ah the perfect rice pudding recipe!  But temper the eggs before putting them into the hot rice and milk  or you will end up with cooked eggs and chunks.  Tat goes without saying, but some people dont know to do it who arent used to quick custards. .  

Just take some of the hot mixture out in a bowl, add some of the milk to it to cool it a bit, add lightly beaten egg to THAT quickly and SLOWLY add it to the pot of rice and milk while constantly stirring it .

country:
None
text:
This is a delicious recipe. Creamy, warm and comforting. Especially, with a sprinkling of cinnamon.
To Jackie. The recipe said to use white rice. You decided to use brown rice. Naturally brown rice is chewy. I don't see how it's the OP's fault when you changed the recipe. 
Whenever adding raw egg into hot mixtures, you must temper them 1st to keep them from scrambling.
I'm guessing you don't cook much not to know about tempering eggs and the fact that using brown rice instead of white rice will change the texture of a dish. Sometimes trying to make desserts healthier just turns out to be disastrous. It's dessert. To make it a healthy dish defeats the purpose, doesn't it? It's no longer a dessert.
So, I don't think the OP deserves 2 stars since the substitution was your mistake.

I made it exactly like the recipe called for but double.

city:

country:
None
text:
Making any custard or pudding is as much art as skill and chemistry! Like Peggy says in her review, you add sugar later if you want the rice to be a good consistency. I disagree with MANY methods that Erica G. tells you to do in this recipe: I've never heard of anyone using the egg whites (I only use the yolks,), and she doesn't tell you to TEMPER the EGGS yolks before adding to hot milk! THIS IS KEY!!!  I'm HIGHLY disappointed in the person who shared this recipe for not explaining that you need to TEMPER EGG YOLKS by mixing 1-4 or more (slowly)Tablespoons of the hot milk to the eggs 1st to warm them while stirring eggs  constantly, THEN add to the milk, while stirring constantly -VERY IMPORTANT! Also, the recipe should mention several things: 1) the type of white rice that works best (some people need specifics like this & mention if 1 type works better than another) Note-I use JASMINE rice because it's fragrant and a nice grain size, but you should try Basmati or another, but NOT Minute Rice!  2) This pudding is not going to thicken after 20 min. on the stove! WHAT??!! If you mix 1 Tablespoon of corn starch  (1T per 2 cups milk about) with a few tablespoons COLD milk and add to the pudding exactly like you did with eggs (temper 1st), then stir constantly as it thickens in about 5-8 minutes. 3) Cooking milk with rice and sugar will NOT thicken and it needs to be stirred! 4) Erica G., I don't know why you tell people to add 1 cup COLD milk and whole eggs (including the white
Review:

text:
My first time ever making rice pudding!! It turned out delicious! I did,however, change some things. I used no sugar, I instead used about half a can of fat free sweetened condensed milk added when the directions say to add last 1/2 cup milk! Also, the raisins I prepared the same way you would for raisin puff cookies; add 1 cup to 1 cup water in saucepan with 1 tsp vanilla, slow boil til all water is absorbed.. makes delicious plump raisins! Added some cinnamon and voila! Creamy, delicious rice pudding =)) definitely recommend these tweeks !

text:
Very sweet, thick, and creamy. I followed the recipe, but I had about  1 1/3 cup rice cooked medium grain white rice. It turned very thick before I added the egg and the rest of the milk (I added 1/2 cup of cream instead). Added a drop extra vanilla.  Full sugar, which was fine when the pudding was warm but 1/4 cup would have been better for when cold. I followed the rec of adding some warm milk/rice to the beaten egg before adding it to the whole mix. The egg blended in very well and cooked very quickly. I skipped the raisins and added shredded coconut at the very end. Should have given the coconut shreds at least 5 min to cook and soften... Would have liked it even thinner (maybe an extra 1/2-1 cup of milk at the end. Maybe skip the cream or the butter? Don't eat too much!

text:
very good not too sweet. some advice to keep egg from curdling when you add it. take some hot milk from the pot and gradually add that to the egg while continuing to whisk. When the egg is warmer it wont curdle from adding it to the mix too quickly. I did not have raisins (husband doesn't like them) but that didn't hurt this recipe at all

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a nice every day sort of dessert and a great way to get lots of low fat milk into the family.  I have made this many times and it is always a hit.  Whenever I make white rice for dinner, I cook extra and make pudding the next day.  Works well with the pre-cooked rice right out of the refrigerator.  Stir a little butter into the rice while it is still hot to keep it from forming chunks while cooling. 

Some notes on the versatility of this recipe: doubling or tripling the recipe works fine & so does using low fat milk.  I like to grate a little fresh nutmeg on the top or stir in some cinnamon with the vanilla and butter.  I have also soaked the raisins in rum or orange juice, then drained.  I've added cumin pods to the first batch of milk, then removed them before adding the raisins.  Great with either long or short grain white rice, but don't use brown rice in this recipe.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
I've made this several times over the years, but today is the day I've decided to leave a review. It's really good.

I was worried about which grain rice to use, but to be honest, I think any of them do just fine.  I also streamline many of the steps. I use the same pan I cooked the rice in, as I'd rather not have as many dishes. I combine the sugar, salt, milk and egg altogether, then pour it straight in and stir. It's never taken me the full 15-20 minutes to get a nice thick pudding. Maybe six at the most.  After I've finished adding the butter and vanilla, I cover the pan and let it sit until just warm. Then I sprinkle some cinnamon over the top. Yummmm.

Edit 11/6/2016 - It's wonderful as is, but I made a few tweaks today that have made it even better. 

I let the rice sit for about a half hour before adding a room temperature mixture of milk/sugar/salt.  I also tossed the egg in and beat it in the mixture. Then I brought it to the thickned state. I increased the milk by another 1/4 c, bringing the total to 3/4 c . Then I increased the vanilla to a teaspoon. Much creamier and vanilla-y.

text:
This was my first time making rice pudding.  I found the recipe simple and easy to follow.  My results were lovely.  Very creamy and sweet (I love sweet!).  I used basmati rice, whole milk (3.25%), and placed a cinnamon stick in the pot while the rice cooked.  And like other reviews, I tempered my egg to ensure it didn't scramble.  My only complaint is the raisins did not become full & plump.  Next time I'll try either adding the raisins earlier or cooking it longer after they're added.  I really feel fully plump raisins are much better than semi-shriveled. 
I look forward to experimenting with other flavors using this recipe.  Like perhaps orange zest or using other dried fruits and/or nuts.  I know the Spanish use cinnamon and lemon zest, Hungarian: raisins, cinnamon and cocoa.  In Turkey, they broil the top similar to a creme brulee.  They're are so many variations to try.
Thanks for sharing this recipe!

text:
Absolutely amazing. I've been married 47 years, on and off I've tried so many different recipes for rice pudding but never got a nice creamy one like this. I used alborio rice for mine and sprinkled grated nutmeg on each dish. Thank you very, very much.....with your help I finally cracked it!  I must add .....don't make it too much in advance because it congeals and becomes dry.  If that happens add lots more milk to make it creamy again.
Serve with ice cream or cream.

country:
None
text:
This is a pretty much foolproof recipe!  If (like me) you sometimes have any chunks of impossibly hard brown sugar-- I use them in this recipe.  While the rice is cooking, I soak the chunks in the milk in the saucepan--they soften and melt, so all is ready for the rice when it's finished.  It does make the rice pudding a caramel color, so I don't do that for company.  I don't like raisins, but have used dried cranberries, dates etc.

Absolutely Awesome !!!. I have recently tried baking a Southern Style Rice Pudding in the oven and it was good, but this recipe calls for making it on the top of the stove, which in my opinion is no comparison. 
If you make it exactly as is, and use the right ingredients you'll be in HEAVEN.

REMEMBER to use the short gain rice and the best ingredients. Again, this was great, the best i ever had.

text:
This recipe is a religious experience! I'm glad I saw that this recipe makes more rice than 1 1/2 cups though, so measure the cooked rice. I followed a reviewer's suggestion to use flavored creamer. I used 1c milk, 1/2c flavored creamer. (Creme Brule). I also used less sugar because of this. I also put the cinnamon & nutmeg in while I was cooking the rice with milk. It becomes infused with the flavor! I tasted it when done, & my eyes rolled into the back of my head!! I didn't expect it to taste so heavenly, as this is only the second time I have made homemade pudding. You will LOVE it!

text:
I never knew it was so easy to make incredible tasting rice pudding!  I made some yesterday and am making a  double batch today.  If you love rice pudding, give this a try.  I left out the raisins.  I used long grain white rice and it is much better than my favorite store bought.   Just need to watch closely while the rice and milk is thickening ... i added the second half of the milk first then slowly with the beaten egg... I think this would prevent the problem one reviewer had of the egg cooking quickly and creating chucks...that didn't happen to me... give it a try, you and your tasters will thank you.

Woke this morning craving rice pudding for breakfast. text:
The recipe is delicious and I altered it a bit to suit my taste. And yes, I too used the same pan for completing the recipe once the rice was cooked. Don't be afraid to cook the rice longer for best texture. 

 I cut the sugar in 1/2 and used skim and regular milk combination. By doing so it is  important to add 15-20 minutes more cooking time after adding the milk. This allows the pudding to thicken. I also used fewer raisins. Thanks for this great recipe as I am trying to cut back on gluten. I eat it  morning, noon and night. LJ

text:
Great recipe for rice pudding. I omitted the raisins as no one here eats them. I also used Mexican Vanilla extract and cinnamon to try to achieve the flavor of rice pudding I had before. This was my first attempt and we really enjoyed it, as did my boys. The only reason I omitted a star is it doesn't specify which type of rice. I only had long grain and while it was OK, I really think medium grain rice would be a much better choice. I slowly stirred in the egg and had no issues with it cooking too quickly.

text:
This is so YUMMY!  I've never made rice pudding before and decided to try it out tonight with some left over rice.  I did use 1cup milk and 1/2 cup half n half to start with.  After reading some reviews I used a little less sugar and  poured some of the rice mixture into my egg and milk mixture so the eggs wouldn't cook too fast in my pan.  I didn't realize I was supposed to add vanilla when I was done cooking.  I put the vanilla and a little cinnamon in with my egg/milk mixture. It turned out just fine. I had made blue ribbon extra long grain rice for dinner so that it was I used.  My rice pudding turned out nice and creamy and not to thick and delicious.  Perfect.  I will definitely make again!! Thanks for a great recipe.  *I did omit the raisins b/c I didn't have any.

text:
this was really good and easy to make for a 15 year old. I love rice pudding and decided to make it one day. So, i googled rice pudding recipes and this was the first one. I read the reviews and of course there were many great reviews. also, there were very many bad reviews. I have to say it was a success, at least for me. I have made it  twice and was great in flavor, and consistency as long as you make sure the rice is cooked properly. I added 3/4 of a cup of milk towards the end because i found that it got really thick and stifflike, i like it creamy so thats why i added the extra milk. Overall this was great recipe, very simple. I really liked it and so did my little sister(:

text:
You may be thrown off by this recipe's simplicity, but I assure you it's as good or better than any I've tried.  Due to being out of regular milk, I used Meyenberg's Goat Milk (powdered) and it was AMAZING!! Much creamier and a richer flavor than cow's milk and as I understand easier for some to digest.  Also, I rinse the rice 3-4 times with water and prepared in the usual manner as white boiled rice then proceed to step 2.  I think you will love the GOAT MILK!!

This is spot on. As a former pastry chef the one suggestion I can add is I added some of the sugar over the raisins then a bit of water and ran in microwave two 40 second cycles which allows the fruit to plump up a bit more. text:
This is an amazing recipe and is the same as my Mom's recipe for rice pudding. But you put the rice in with the water, you should not let the water boil first because when it will finally boil half or more of the water will evaporate, then you won't have enough water for the rice to soak it up and become the right size and will be hard ans stale.

Other then that, I love this recipe

text:
I had never made rice pudding before but I have always loved it. After reading a comment about someone saying to use evaporated milk for a creamier pudding I decided I would try that. I used a 12oz can for the initial 1 1/2 cups you boil and used 2% milk for the other 1/2 cup. That is the only change I made to this recipe and it is amazing! Since first trying it 3 weeks ago, I have now made it 3 times and it comes out perfect every time.I actually joined this site just to make sure i could leave a good rating for this and make sure i could save the recipe to share with others.
Review:

text:
Great recipe. Have actually made this many times. Not really much to change. I tend to add a little nutmeg which gives it more of a warm taste. The best I ever made this though was due to the quality of the butter. Choose real good butter with loads of taste and it will make all the difference. I also add a little cream with the milk at the end. Forget the diet! If you want the taste. Gerry In Italy

None
country:
None
text:
I have tried many rice pudding recipes with never the desired results. Something was always wrong. After making this I think I was never cooking the rice/milk mixture long enough. After 15 min I could see it start to thicken. It is very tricky with the egg, although I tempered it I still had a big hunk of white not incorporating with the milk. I just removed it. Next time I will make sure the egg mixture is well incorporated in the milk. I might use a mixer but still temper. I am an experienced cook and could never understand why I couldn't make rice pudding.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674139.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have made this rice pudding three times now.  Twice with Arborio rice, which is very soft when cooked and used for risotto; and once, this morning, with short grain brown rice, which gives it wonderful chewy texture.  I love both.  I use maple syrup instead of sugar, and it makes the rice pudding even creamier.  I don't use raisins, but I do sprinkle some ground cinnamon on top.  Fantastic.  The only rice pudding recipe I'll ever need.  Reminds me of childhood, but this is even better.  I didn't think that was possible, but it is. Make sure you make a double batch.  I can assure you that you will want to eat a double portion!

This is fabulous! Love It. There is a couple things that I did differently. I cooked the rice with a special rice cooker I have, to make sure it was cooked FULLY. I only used 1 1/2 cup of cooked rice, which it a little confusing in the directions. Wasn't sure if she was referring to the uncooked rice amount. region:

country:
None
text:
A wonderful recipe! This is my go-to recipe when I am making a special treat for my father. I generally use 1% milk and pearl rice, but it's hard to mess up this recipe.  A few of the other comments posted mention bits of cooked egg in the finished dish, so I just want to mention that tempering the eggs will prevent this from happening.  Tempering refers to the process by which the temperature of the mixture with the egg is increased gradually by pouring some of the hot (rice, sugar, milk) mixture into it and stirring it vigorously before pouring it all back in the hot mixture.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a great recipe, however I always make the recipe my own, so I changed it a bit. My husband hates rice pudding & he enjoyed this recipe. Here are my alterations. Please give this a try, it is delicious. I used 2C. Cooked Rice - 1C. Pumpkin Creamer - 1C. Half  & Half - 2T. Sugar - 1/4t. Salt ( I cooked as directed for this recipe ) I mixed 1 Beaten Egg to 1/2 C. Half & Half, I added this as well as 1/2C. Raisins to the rice mixture ( I continued following the cooking directions ) I removed the rice mixture from the heat & stirred in 2t. Vanilla, 2T. Butter, 1t. Cinnamon & 1/4t. Nutmeg. I refrigerated the rice pudding until cold & served it with
 a dolop of whipped cream ( not whipped topping, the kind in the plastic tub, it is too sweet for this)

userID:
3528461
Display Name:
L.y.n.n.a.r.d
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674137.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Tips for people trying to use brown rice, you can't make rice pudding with brown rice. It will NEVER turn out the same as white rice. Brown rice will always be more chewy, it wont dissolve and mush up like white rice will. You wont get the same starch to thicken it either. As for the egg, you can't really just dump it in.... Egg+heat=scrambled eggs, you need to quickly mix it in a bit at a time or temper it in a separate bowl by mixing a little of the hot mixture in at a time until it matches the pots heat. Also, nice recipe, very tasty if you follow the directions:)

text:
I used leftover rice from a Chinese restaurant. Since they use short grain rice, the pudding turned out very creamy. I used fat free half and half and 1% milk. I also added 1/2 tsp of freshly ground cardamom (in a double recipe). If you like cardamom, it makes it wonderful!

Be careful adding the egg. I mixed it with the second batch of milk and poured it in VERY SLOWLY so it wouldn't turn to scrambled eggs.

text:
This is a great creamy recipe.  I used long grain rice and 1% milk.  It just takes a little more cooking to get it a softer consistency.  I also left out the raisins as my wife doesn't like them.  I don't ever cut the sugar...it's a dessert for goodness sake.  I added cinnamon and nutmeg to mine because it's not a rice pudding without them.  

My family loved it and as a bit of a dessert snob, I must say I haven't had one as creamy as this ever.

Just tried this as written. It is the BEST rice pudding I have ever tasted. It was easy to make. I have tried many recipes taking much more time and ingredients that can not come close. A must try. Just a note. Make sure to use a medium or short grain rice for rice pudding. The end result is much better. And for the novice cook, remember to temper your egg before adding to your pot or you may find scrambled egg in your rice.

None
text:
I prepped about 6 cups of long grain white rice and had about 2 cups that wouldn't fit in the container. So I found this recipe. I used a rough measurement of 1.5-2 cups of rice, simmered with the milk stirring often. When it was the consistency of a risotto and the bottom of the pan shown through during stirring I added the rest of the milk, egg and raisins. Then stirred constantly for more than the 2 minutes. I added a dash more sugar after the vanilla and added cinnamon to the whole batch, tasting along the way for sweetness and flavor. SOOO good! I will use med grain if I have it next time but with enough stirring the long grain is creamy too. Perfect use of leftovers, will be making often!

This recipe was really easy and MUCH tastier than I even expected.  I used fat and lactose free milk which I think actually made a difference. Lactose free milk is a little bit thicker so it seemed to help with the creaminess (I'd be careful with Lactaid the brand as it seems sweeter than other lactose free milk).  I also used Jasmine rice which made the pudding a little lighter.  DE-lish!  My boyfriend loved it too!  I will definitely be making it again.

userID:
6958161
Display Name:
Georgianna Elliott Guthrie
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4085795.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My husband's grandmother used to make him rice pudding.  Since she passed, he's only had my two or three prior attempts.  While good, they were not "it".  Well, this IS IT!!  He was so pleased- transported back to when he was a child!  Follow the directions!  It always frustrates me to see poor reviews, then you read them, and the reviewer has changed EVERYTHING!  GRRR!  My only suggestions are: add some cinnamon- YUMM!  DO NOT rehydrate your raisins (I know, it doesn't call for that, but if you do, this will be a lovely soup- not a pudding!)  Finally, when adding the second part of the milk, mix your egg into the milk, then add enough of the hot mixture to bring the milk/egg to just over body temp- you eggs won't "scramble"!  This grateful wife says a BIG THANK YOU to Erica for posting this recipe!

text:
This is a wonderfully creamy rice pudding. I didn't have a problem putting in the sugar when the recipe called for it. If it's on low heat, there should be no problem. Of course, tweaking the recipe to suit you is much better. I doubled the recipe and used powdered milk mixed with water for half the milk in the recipe; the other half I used evaported milk. I think this doubled the creaminess. I don't like raisins much so I only put in a sprinkle. I also used one pan and it worked just fine. It was fabulous and easy to make, and I would definitely recommend this to anyone looking for a yummy rice pudding recipe.

userID:
5066240
Display Name:
kerrbeark

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674135.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Super easy.  Fantastic taste.  I omitted raisins because we don't like them in our pudding.   I doubled the recipe and had plenty of rice left over that I put in the fridge.  

TIPS: KNOW YOUR RICE!  Rice comes in many different forms, short-medium-long-extra long grain.  The type of rice you use will GREATLY AFFECT your outcome.  USE MEDIUM GRAIN RICE when making rice pudding.  Short grain is very high in starch and will likely produce a very heavy, sticky and overly thick pudding that is mushy after cooking.  Long/extra long grain rice while much easier to make and with less starch content, will not give you the same mouth feel your use to in typical rice puddings.  Medium grain is the way to go.  

Temper your milk and eggs before adding them to your cooking pudding.  In a bowl on the counter add your smaller divided portion of milk and your beaten eggs.  After cooking your mixture on the stove for the 15-20 mins, add some of that hot liquid to the milk/egg bowl STIRRING CONSTANTLY for a few minutes and finger test for warmth.  When you think its hot enough add to your cooking mixture and stir to finish pudding.  Tempering like this ensure your eggs don't cook and become scrambled.

I have never made rice pudding but I had some leftover rice that I did not want to just throw out so I came across this recipe which sounded easy and good. AND IT WAS! I followed the recipe exactly except that my rice was long grain but I simmered it for 30 minutes. I mixed the egg, milk, and raisins together and let them sit while cooking the rice mixture. I also let the butter and vanilla sit on the counter as well. I used only one saucepan and I tempered the egg mixture before adding it to the rice mixture, just in case. I will definitely make this again as I still have more leftover rice to use up and this is DELICIOUS!

Thank you Erica for a great recipe.

wow! amazing and exactly what I wanted in a rice pudding!  I followed the steps of the recipe exactly, but thought the times were a bit off. This is a wildly delicious recipe! Definitely a wonderful comfort food. The first time I made it was for company so I doubled the recipe. The only change I made was that I used 1% low fat milk. It got raves, and I had plenty left over for my friends to take home and leftovers for myself. It thickens so much after sitting in the fridge that I like to reheat it with a little low fat milk. And we all liked it with a little Reddi-whip on top.

text:
No doubt, this is an amazing recipe and an incredibly easy one too. I’ve been on a quest for the PERFECT rice pudding for 10 years now: I tried everything… But this version got me the closest to the phenomenal rice pudding I’ve always (only) dreamt of. So, thank you so much for sharing. In my version, I do use more milk and sugar than suggested, and the last 1/5 cup of milk becomes 1/5 cup of heavy cream. It comes out really creamy as promised… but only as far as it’s still hot/warm/room-temperature. Strangely, this recipe advises to serve warm—I think of rice-pudding as a cold, out-of-the-fridge dessert. Warm is certainly delicious! However, and this is my question to the larger community of cooks and eaters out there, WHY DOES IT SOLIDIFY INTO A BLOB OF CONCRETE ONCE I PUT IT IN THE FRIDGE? How can I keep the moist and looseness also after a night of refrigeration? Any suggestions or ideas would be immensely appreciated. Thanks again. And bon appetit!

text:
I have never had rice pudding before but have a sense of how pudding should be like. This is a very simple recipe. I used broken jasmine rice (can be purchased in Asian markets) and put all the rice in pudding. I used 1 can (13 oz) of coconut milk in the pot and used 1 cup of 2% milk to mix with the egg and raisins. The cooking time was cut down to 5-7 mins instead of 15-20 mins since broken rice makes it thick quickly. It turned out really good. My husband couldn't believe this was my first rice pudding. Thank you for the easy recipe.

text:
This was an adventure. I made the pudding as directed. Used skim milk and honey (a little less than a quarter cup). Cooked it as directed, tempered the egg mixture. However is was still kind of watery. I chalked this up as a failure. I put it in a 300 oven to keep warm 'til dessert time. And lo and behold when I took it out (about 20 min. later) it had set up! 
It tasted fantastic. Oh, did I mention that I soaked the raisins in spiced rum? That might have helped some :-) I will admit I was flying blind. I've never seen or eaten rice pudding. Only made it 'cuz my SIL was coming over and she loves it. She gave her kudos to this effort.

text:
This recipe is amazing!  Erica, thank you so much for putting your mom's recipe on here for all of of us to enjoy!  I ended up turning it into "Vanilla Bean Rice Pudding" by using 1/2 of a Madagascar Vanilla Bean as opposed to vanilla extract and left the raisins out as well as the butter.  I too salted the water that my rice was going to get cooked in as opposed to adding salt later.  One thing you should do: temper your egg before you put it into your milk and rice mixture.  Enjoy this recipe, it's an absolute keeper! Thanks again

Awesome recipe to work with. I used basmati rice and cooked the rice according to the package. Then I added 1 cup of milk and substituted the other half with heavy cream. (Thanksgiving leftover.) I left out the raisins. Also added a teaspoon of speculaas spices. (A dutch spice mixture consisting cinnamon, cloves, nutmeg, white pepper, ginger, cardamom and mace.) This added an very nice flavor to the pudding.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/712337.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've never actually made rice pudding before, nor have I even tried it, but as far as pudding is concerned, it's delicious! With the rice, it's quite filling. I used leftover short-grain brown rice, but next time I have some leftover short-grain white rice, I'll try this again and see how the texture changes. Brown rice was a bit too chewy.

While simmering, I added about 1/4 cup extra milk to compensate for the drier brown rice. To make chocolate pudding, I substituted 2/3 cups  chocolate chips for the raisins and cut the sugar by about 1/3, adding the chips just before turning off the heat to add the butter and vanilla.

For good measure, I tempered my beaten egg with some of the warm mixture before adding it to the pot. I didn't want to risk having scrambled egg in my pudding!

text:
I made a lactose-free version using skim lactose-free milk and lactose free margerine. I used long grain rice (leftover in fridge). My 1/3 cup sugar was a rounded scoop to make it a little sweeter. I would stir the pot and walk away but towards the end of the 20 minutes I had to stay right there stirring it to prevent it from sticking. To prevent egg scrambling, I did as others suggested, and added 2 spoonfuls of the hot mix from the pot to the egg/milk.  Once I stirred that well, I added it into the pot. Since I had used margerine when I originally cooked the rice, I left it out. As for the vanilla, I added it to the egg/milk part of the recipe. The end result is tasty but I can really taste the vanilla. I think I will use a tiny bit less next time.

Great basic creamy recipe overall.  I suggest cooking the rice with a dash of salt and replacing a cup of milk with heavy cream.   I happened to have raisins mascerating in agave nectar and rum so I put a scoop of them in the finished pudding.  The rum added a certain something nice.  I made a batch tonight, it's setting in the fridge now.  When I serve it tomorrow, I'll whip some heavy cream and give it a dollop with a pinch of cinnamon.

text:
Honestly, I'm not sure why this has gotten such great reviews.  Yes, it's easy to make ~ I made it exactly as written and the cooking times and measurements seem fine.  It comes out thick and creamy as other reviewers have stated... but I found it seriously lacking in flavor.  It absolutely needs some nutmeg, cinnamon, cardomom, or all 3 to have any flavor at all.  Otherwise, it's just rice cooked in milk with egg, sugar, salt, vanilla and butter....nothing special there.

text:
I love this recipe. This is the second time making it and it was so yummy. This time, however, I ran out of eggs so I substitute 1TB of corn starch and dissolved it into the 1/2 cup of milk. I didn't have short grain rice this time around so I used long grain. I think the starch kept its thickness. The biggest mistake I made was not cooking the rice long enough. So, make sure you fully cook the rice before adding the milk!

text:
I am a professional cook so I used this recipe in my kitchen at work.  It was very good, but does not double well.  I had to use some corn starch to thicken it up a bit.  Also I wanted to use leftover rice and it was long grain which doesn't do well in rice pudding so I put the rice in a food processor and processed it a bit which broke it up some and it was fine.  All in all a pretty good pudding.

text:
O.K...I completely botched the directions & it still turned out excellent!!  I should not be cooking late at night!!  I cooked my rice, as directed, but added my egg to the sugar & first 1 1/2 cups of milk!  I figured, oh well....dumped the milk/egg mixture into the cooked pot of rice....GENTLY simmered & stirred for about 10-15 minutes...added last 1/2 cup milk & vanilla & VOILA!  Turned out just fine.  Great flavors, good consistency, not too sweet, egg didn't "scramble".  Will definitely make again, but next time I will follow the directions a bit more carefully.

text:
This was the first time I'd ever eaten/made rice pudding but it will NOT be the last! My family was almost disgusted by how much of this I ate- I could NOT STOP!!!   I used short grain rice which made it extra thick= yummier! The butter was left out, a touch of whipping cream was added to finish off the pint before it went bad  and I added extra vanilla and a bit less sugar per the other ratings. I'm extremely opposed to soggy raisins, so I added them afterwards. The cinnamon, however, is absolutely necessary! Soooo gooooooood!! AND!!! I thought the cold leftovers were (prepare yourself) EVEN BETTER!!!  Thank you Erica!!!

text:
Fantastic results, tastes incredible. As a dairy-free alternative (my wife is allergic to dairy), I used vanilla-flavoured almond milk. This required more cooking time with the milk to get a creamy consistency. More like 25-30 minutes rather than 15-20. I also used Earth Balance dairy-free margarine instead of butter. And since my wife isn't a big fan of raisins, I used chopped dates (same amount). This is now one of my favourite desserts.

text:
this is a great recipe, but if i were you id use 2 egg yolks instead of a whole egg,  using the egg white gives too much of an egg flavor, but using the yolk will give you a much more creamy finish, also as milk can burn very easily you could use a simple bain marie (pot of boiling water) when cooking with the milk,  tasts great tho :)

text:
mmmmmmmmmmmmm.  I just made this.  I am eating it as I write this review.  It is, in a word, great.  A really easy recipe.  I was terrified that my milk would burn, but it turned out in the end!  I added 1/4 cup of sugar instead of 1/3, and I found this to be plenty sweet enough.  To simplify, I mixed the egg, milk, and raisins in a bowl and added it as a mixture.  I melted the margarine in the microwave.  I used "sticky rice" which was a medium grain.  It didn't quite make 1 and 1/2 cups of cooked rice, but it came out great nonetheless!  Thanks for a wicked recipe!

city:

country:

text:
I first have to say that I have never tasted or made rice pudding.  So this was my first!  This recipe sure lived up to its great reviews!  I only had the 10 minute rice on hand, and it didnt say if it was short, med, etc.  I could tell after cooking that more than likely it was the long.  Even with the long it was still great tho.  But for sure next time I will make sure to pick up some short rice at the store because I could tell it would be so much creamier with the short.  I read thru others reviews and came upon that I would change it around a bit.  I added the salt in with the water.  Then when it came to the milk mixture, I added the sugar, along with cinnamon and nutmeg to cook into the rice instead of adding at the end.  I didnt do the raisins and I added a touch more sugar near the end of cooking.  Probably an overall total of a 1/2 cup went in since we like things sweet.  I also tempered the beaten egg before adding so I didnt end up with scrambled eggs.  I served warm with sliced peaches over top and more cinnamon and sugar sprinkled.  We ate this as dessert and soon found out how rich and filling it was!  I thought this would be perfect as a breakfast meal with sliced fresh fruit over top.  So I cant wait to make again and again!  Thanks for the wonderful recipe!

I absolutely love rice pudding, but have never found a recipe that suited my taste. That is, until today. This recipe is absolutely perfect in every way...it is deliciously creamy and thick, with just the right sweetness. It is definitely not easy or quick to make, but the results are so worth it. The only changes I made were to omit the raisins (personal preference) and to add some ground cinnamon to the finished pudding. It's absolutely wonderful served warm or cold. One error I found in the recipe is in the cooking time...I found that the rice/milk/sugar/salt mixture had to cook for at least five minutes longer in order for it to become remotely "thick and creamy". Other than that, it's wonderful! My family all loved it. Thanks so much for sharing the recipe...I'll be making this one again.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2010-09-06T13:45:22.57
helpfulCount:
1

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Rich and creamy! Thank you for this recipe.     Here's how I modified the recipe for my family: (1) I doubled the recipe; (2) I used 1/2 a vanilla bean, slit it open to let the seeds out and boiled it with the rice - I took the bean out right before I put into serving bowls; (3) I skipped the raisins; (4) I used unrefined sugar and 1% milk; (5) I used short grain, sticky rice; (6) I added a dash of cinnamon while cooking the rice with milk;(7)I put in the zest of 1 lemon at the very end, right after I added the egg & last bit of milk - I let that cook while stirring for roughly 2 minutes; (8) I skipped the butter; and (9) added a dash of cinnamon to flavour and decorate each serving bowl (did not stir in).     Thanks again!

I think the shorter grain would go a long way to making it delicious.

This was super good! Works fine with leftover rice (I used Basmati). Just do everything else the same. I only had 1 1/4 cup cooked rice so just decreased everything a tad. Omitting the raisins is fine, too (I just don't like em). I recommend having cinnamon on the table so folks can spice it or not as they choose. Yummy!!! And so nice not to throw out the rice. This was easy to cook (for the 15-20) while eating dinner, was expecting it might burn but it didn't, then right after dinner I did the 2 minutes then butter and vanilla and Presto! Dessert! Love this recipe.

text:
Outstanding! I made this using leftover long grain white rice and skim milk, followed the directions exactly, only skipping the butter at the end as my rice was already cooked with butter. A little sprinkle of cinnamon at serving time and it was the best pudding I've ever tasted! Thank you for an outstanding recipe! UPDATE: I have now made this with brown rice, jasmine rice, all sorts of leftover rice and it is perfect every time. It does, indeed, thicken some as it cools after the eggs are added. I always double this. Thank you!

Very quick and easy stovetop recipe.  Great for leftover rice.  I decreased the sugar to 1/4 cup, use skim milk and have added cinnamon and nutmeg on some occasions, but it is only about preference.  This recipe is superb on its own.  One last thing, like other reviewers, I beat the egg with the last 1/2 cup milk and add a spoon of rice mixture to milk before SLOWLY adding it to the pudding.

Coming from a girl that has ruined rice on numerous occasions.... this recipe is virtually impossible to screw up. Follow the directions to a tee and you'll be fine. To repeat another users words of wisdom...once the sugar is added the rice stops cooking. So check that the rice is the right texture first.  Many thanks to Erica G for a great recipe. :o)

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
Delightful! As always, I read the reviews before making this. I already had everything but I did have to make some substitutions. I used jasmine rice since I didn't have short or medium grain. I used truvia (all natural no calorie sweetener) instead of sugar, so 1/6 of a cup of truvia and skim milk. It was SO creamy and tasted great, even with the lower calorie substitutions! Even my chef husband loved it! As someone suggested, we did temper the eggs and milk before adding it to the hot milky rice to prevent scrambled eggs in our pudding. We then calculated the calories and portioned it out into 8 small bowls for 100 calorie snacks! Satisfies that sweet craving without wrecking a day of hard work! LOVE this!

country:
None
text:
This recipe reminded me of my grandmother's rice pudding I used to eat as a child.  I left out the raisins, because 1) I didn't have any, and 2) I prefer no raisins.  I also let the rice/milk/sugar mixture simmer, which thickened it right up.  For those who said their pudding did not thicken, try simmering it, but watch closely or your milk will burn.  Also, be sure to use whole or 2% milk.  This recipe will be added to my collection and I'll continue to make it for years to come!

text:
Excellent recipe! Only changes I made were: Instead of just milk, I mixed 1 cup skim milk with 1 cup heavy cream and divided as necessary. Omitted the raisins (don't like them). Also, instead of using a separate saucepan after cooking the rice, I just did it all in the same one as this keeps all the starch in the mix! (makes it a tad creamier) :) Thanks for sharing!

I wanted to try a rice pudding recipe for my hubby since he loves it. Once a year I make 'arroz con dulce' and it's delicious, but it takes long and requires a lot more ingredients. This recipe was very easy and tasty. My husband liked it very much! I used all the ingredients stated. https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/229115.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great recipe!  Very adaptable too... Somebody suggested using the leftovers ('sludge') from Lola's Horchata (on this site) so here is what I did: left sludge with 1/2 c. milk in fridge until I was ready to use.  Added another cup of milk and cooked it in a saucepan until rice is tender.  (Make sure it is actually tender! Water could also probably be used for this step.) Added another cup of milk and stirred until warm.  whipped together another 1/2 c. milk (yes, 3 total cups) and 1/2 c. sugar, and the egg, and added it to milk.  Cook until thick.  Add vanilla.  (I left out raisins and butter.)  It was good, just be sure to cook the rice enough!

text:
Great recipe!  I used rice milk in place of regular milk and had no problems with consistency or creaminess (but thats personal tastes).  Only had left over basmati rice which worked alright too.  I will make this again using short grain rice and a little less sugar as it was very sweet when warm. (the portion that was left in the fridge over night and that was not too sweet) so it depends on how you plan on serving it and what sweetness you prefer.  also cinnamon is a highly recommended addition.

text:
Soooo good!!!  I used 1C Minute Rice (Cooked in 1C boiling water) & 1/3C + 1 Tbsp Sugar.  I also used the full 2C milk, as directed.  This was very tasty!!  After the pudding was cooked, I put it into 4 sundae cups, sprinkled with some cinnamon sugar.  They were awesome!! (For extra cinnamon/sweetness, fill each cup 1/2 way with pudding, sprinkle some cinnamon sugar, then fill the other 1/2 with pudding, and sprinkle with cinnamon sugar).  My entire family loved it!!!  Thanks for a great recipe!!

text:
I used whole grain brown rice for a more wholesome version of this pudding. I cooked the brown rice in the rice cooker with a little more water than I normally would (1 cup rice and 2 1/2 cups water) in order for the rice to be softer. I also used soymilk which added creaminess. I only used half the amount of sugar suggested and it was plenty sweet (soymilk adds sweetness as well). Added cinnamon, nutmeg and walnut pieces on top, just prior to serving. YUM!

text:
This is awesome!  I just realized I forgot to put the butter in, but it didn't matter... still so good. I used 1-1/2 cup cooked day old rice. The only changes I made were to put the raisins in the 1st cooking to make them soft and plump (used regular, brown raisins). Also added about 1" vanilla bean, split & scraped in, and put the pod in the mix for the entire cooking time and then fished out the pod at the end (and skipped the vanilla extract).  Also added a dash of cinnamon.  This was so good warm and I think it'll be even better tomorrow cold with sliced banana for breakfast! On that note, in the past when I've made rice pudding with other recipes and then tried to reheat it in the microwave later it became a nasty consistency, I think the egg cooks in there and makes it weird, so just eat leftovers cold!

This recipe is really great and produces a really creamy and yummy rice pudding! Love it!!  So easy and delicious.  I made this with some leftover rice that I had.  I used skim milk and fat free half & half (1 cup milk 1/2 cup fat free half & half) to simmer rice in and in the last step just used 1/2 cup more skim milk. city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Absolutely delicious! I been wanting to make rice pudding for a long time and finally decided to bite the bullet and make one from scratch (that is; with uncooked rice and not leftover cooked rice) I have to admit, I was so tempted to leave out the egg as some other reviewers did (because I have had curdling issues with another recipe) but I didn't. The only change I made was use half the amount of raisins called for in the recipe (which turned out to be just right for my tastes) I actually took the half cup of milk which was to be added closer to the end, heated it up a bit and slowly whisked it into the egg to make a custard and then slowly poured the custard into the rice pudding bit by bit. This technique worked like a charm! This is really good sprinkled with cinnamon or nutmeg, but I think it would also be great all alone, yum! The sweetness perfect for my taste and I also got no eggy aftertaste. Thanks for sharing!

text:
This is delicious!  I made a few changes :  I used Japanese rice grains....which is shorter and thicker when cooked.  This basically cut the cooking time by a lot, because Japanese rice tends to come out very thick, creamy, soft and moist when cooked.   I also added condensed milk with the milk, so I didn`t need to put sugar and it just made it creamier, with that perfect hint of sweetness.  I added nutmeg and cinnamon in the mix and it was perfect.  I like mine chilled, rather than hot or warm....!  It only took me 10 minutes to make.  ( mind you, I already had Japanese rice prepared, cooked in a rice cooker, bc I eat rice everyday ).

text:
I've made this twice.  I made it the first time exactly as written (well I did add some cinnamon and almond extract).  The second time I made rice for dinner using 2 cups of rice instead of one.  Whatever was leftover I used for the rice pudding.  There was more rice than the recipe calls for, but all it needed was a bit more sugar.  I used medium grain (Calrose) rice and that makes it so creamy and yummy!  If you add some of the hot rice mixture to the egg and milk before mixing it into the pot you won't get scrambled eggs in your rice pudding.

userID:
2105058
Display Name:
CNBryce
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614247.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Its probably a great recipe as it is but like everyone else, I had to put my own twist on it and I love, love, loved it.  I doubled and used 2, 12 oz cans of skimmed evaporated milk and 1/2 cup of 2% milk.  In cooking this on my glass electric stove top, I remembered why I baked rice pudding because I was starting to scorch it which is really easy for me to do and especially with electricity.  So I put the doubled batch in the large glass mixing bowl that pampered chef makes and microwaved it for seven minutes(but that was after it was already warm-make take twice as long), put the eggs and 1/2 cup milk in and microed for 2 min more then finished it up. The mixture came up over the top of the bowl when microwaving but it didn't boil over.  If it looks like its going to go over, then take it out and stir it down.  I used sticky rice-a short grain with a really good flavor.  I don't think you can get it in regular stores but got mine in an Asian market by just asking for "sticky" rice.  It works really great with this recipe.  Used cinnamon and nutmeg to taste.  Used reg dark raisins but just one cup.  If you don't use raisins, you might want to put a little more sugar in because a lot of the sweetness comes from the raisins.  The vanilla is a must.  I'm going to try brown rice next time.

text:
Excellent - creamy and delicious. Used a short grain rice (Arborrio, which is used for risotto and such) which makes all the difference. Do not use a long grain rice for this recipe because you want the texture to be creamy and a long grain rice will not give you this texture.  I also used lowfat milk and the pudding was still uber creamy.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Good as is. I especially liked a second vamped up version with 1/4 tsp cardamom and 1 can light coconut milk + 1/2 cup cow milk. Topped with pistachios and toasted coconut. I used leftover brown rice. I'll make extra rice forever! :)
By the way, my egg curdles every time. It isn't a big deal since this isn't a smooth custard dessert, but still a bit unsightly. I tried stirring in a bit of the hot rice mixture into the egg/milk mix and always add slowly, stirring CONSTANTLY, but no good. Just a fair warning. Maybe allow the pudding to cool a bit before adding, then slowly heat back up after having incorporated the egg? It's worth a shot!

text:
I was reading "The Pokey Little Puppy" to my little girls the other day and had a craving for rice pudding.  I had no idea it required so few ingredients or was so simple to make!  I always thought you had to add about a gallon of half and half and all I had in the house was 1 percent but it turned out super creamy.  Just the right amount of sweet.  The ultimate comfort food.  My girls wouldn't even try it...I don't know why since they eat rice often with their dinner.  Oh well, at least I got to eat the leftovers for breakfast the next morning.  They got pretty gluey in the fridge but a splash of milk and a minute in the microwave brought it back to the perfect consistency.

text:
Very Good Recipe, although made a few changes. Instead of cooking rice in a saucepan, I used my rice cooker to cook it and Voila, perfectly cooked rice. When adding the milk, sugar and rice I used 1 3/4 cup of milk instead. I took the advice of others and whisked the egg and milk together and adding a bit of the hot rice, then slowly added into the rest of the rice. I tasted a little bit, it was a little bland so I added about 1/3 cup more sugar and about 1/4tsp of cinnamon and cooked a bit longer. Tastes delicious now!

text:
5 stars and more!!
This is the BEST "riisipuuro" recipe I've ever tasted...that's what Finnish people call Rice pudding. It's just like my Grandma's.
I used Calrose rice and left out the butter and raisins, and added nutmeg and cinnamon...heavenly! I ate it with milk and it was an instant hit with my picky 2-year-old. It's also great with "kiisseli" which is for example strawberry juice (with fruit added) boiled and thickened with corn starch...yummy! Thanks a million for posting this recipe.

region:

country:
None
text:
Wow! Erica THIS is a keeper!  My family LOVES rice pudding, but in the past they never quite turned out that great at home.  However, I made a few changes and it came out delicious.  After reading many posts I decided not to use an egg raisons or butter at all.  I also decided to use brown rice as it is healthier and Vanilla Soy milk.  It did take a little longer to get creamier, but I kept stirring it and it set up perfectly!  Oh, I also used the suggestion to wait to check texture of rice BEFORE adding the sugar in.  I finished with cinnamon!  The texture will be a little chewey with the brown rice, but very yummy!  I also thought it was the perfect sweetness.  My toddler will love it IF there is any left for him tomorrow as he has already gone to bed!

WOW!!! I don't even know what to say! This is an awesome recipe! I grew up on cozy shack rice pudding, and didn't think this was going to be close. It was soooooo good! Turned out exactly like the picture. I was afraid of scorching the milk, so, I tried to cook it at a lower temp on my stove. (cooked it on 4 on my electric range.) It did take longer than the recipe says, but, I just kept stirring it until it looked right. It was great warm, but, even better cold the next day for breakfast. I made it exactly as the recipe says. No add ins. Great recipe, blast from the past.

This is fabulous!  I used 2% milk and the instant 5 minute rice, as per the box (without the butter).  I also omitted the raisins and added nutmeg and cinnamon and WOW!  I do want to caution you . . .don't add the beaten egg to the hot mixture because it will scramble.  Try adding the milk first, letting it cool a bit then add the beaten egg.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Easy, delicious recipe...  I follow it exactly, and it comes out perfect every time.  3/26/14 update:  I've been making this with Jasmine rice for the past couple of years, and we like that better than making it with long-grained white rice because it stays creamy after refrigerating it.  It's great made with long grain white rice if you are eating it fresh and hot off the stove, but the rice hardens if it's refrigerated so the left-overs are not as good.  Also, this recipe says it makes 4 servings, but it makes plenty for 8 reasonably-sized servings.

country:

text:
A+++  I was looking for a stove top recipe because I wanted to end up with something as close to what my grandma makes as possible.  I followed this recipe exactly with the exception of the fact that I didn't measure out 1 1/2 cups of cooked rice, I just used the whole amount and I omitted the raisins since my husband and I both don't like them.  It couldn't have been any easier to make and the taste was fantastic.

Next time I make it I think I'll add a little extra vanilla just because I really like it.

As a tip for those of you wanting to eat leftovers but finding them a bit dry:  spoon as much as you want in to a bowl, poor a little bit of milk over top, mix and throw it in the microwave until it has reached the desired temperature.  You should find that it tastes just like it did the first night.

None
text:
Great recipe!  I've always liked rice pudding, but never imagined I could make it at home (I'm a new cook).  But this was very easy and very good -- even my family members who don't normally like rice pudding ate it up.  As suggested here, I did stir in some cinammon, nutmeg and honey.  Then today I decided to be brave and try my own version, and give the recipe a "Caribbean" twist: instead of two cups of milk, I used one cup of regular milk and one cup of coconut milk.  Then I replaced the 1/2 tsp of vanilla with 1/4 tsp vanilla and 1/4 tsp orange.  Still stirred in the honey, but left out the cinnamon and nutmeg.  Success!  A nice twist on a standard.

Next time I'll try it without the egg, though.  I think it would be just as good.

This is great!  I didn't like rice pudding before trying this one.  It can be made using leftover rice easily because the rice is cooked in water instead of milk.  If you use regular raisins, the color will bleed into the pudding if left overnight.  Really easy to reheat: just add a little milk!

Display Name:
Kristine

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614260.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made a couple changes to the recipe: I added the regular raisins a couple minutes before indicated to make sure they're hydrated and plump.  On the last addition of skim milk, I added about 1 tsp of cornstarch for thickness, but unless you want it near sticky rice thickness, I suggest you adhere to the recipe.  As a personal preference, I would have liked to keep the white color of the rice (I added 1 tsp cinnamon and 1/2 tsp nutmeg) and just dust the spices to taste before serving.  Lastly, if you are having problems with the egg scrambling, temper it.  That is, gradually add a little bit of the hot mixture into the egg until about 1/2 of the hot mixture is mixed in, then add it back into the heat with the rest of the pudding.  Aromatic, easy, and customizable with a nice texture! Not too sweet!

I made this recipe again with some changes, and it turned out so delicious! I used a rice cooker for the first step to speed things up.  Instead of the 2 cups milk, I used 1 cup light vanilla soymilk, ~1/2 cups evaporated milk, and 1/2 cup sweetened condensed milk.  I put a cinnamon stick and a few star anise seeds in for flavor and omitted the butter, raisins, and vanilla.  Sprinkled a little cinnamon on top and it was perfect!

text:
Just jumping back in on top of my old review to state how much this is still my absolute go-to recipe for rice pudding. Making up another batch this afternoon, probably several years after my first review (and definitely almost a decade since I first tried it!). 

--------------------------------------------------------------------


I didn't even like rice pudding until recently, when I tried some kheer rice pudding at the Indian Restaurant. Ever since then, I can't get it out of my mind, so I thought I'd try this. It's different from kheer because I'm using regular white rice, but I'm going to try it with some Basmati and see if it's closer.

It was just really, really good, with everyday ingredients I had around the house and extremely simple preparation. After I made the first batch Saturday night, I made the second one Sunday night. I ate the last of THAT batch for Monday morning's brakfast. And, the baby loves it, too!

text:
For now on, I know what to use that extra box of rice from Chinese takeout for!  This rice pudding had a nice creamy texture to it.  Not too sweet either.  I added 1 tsp of nutmeg and 1/2 tsp of cinnamon as suggested by a previous reviewer.  I was hesitant about all of that nutmeg and should have followed my gut feeling.  It came out a bit too spicy.  Next time around I will add 1/4 tsp of nutmeg, and the same amount of cinnamon (1/2 tsp).

userID:
13767663
Display Name:
Alexandra
isPro:
False
followersCount:
2
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
8
favoritesCount:
30
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1161516.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great rice pudding recipe! After making this a few times, here's what I've learned: Firstly, the reason for using a new saucepan  to heat up your milk, sugar & cooked rice , is because your pot you will first cook your rice in will create a film on the bottom. This is not ideal for heating up your milk & sugar to make your pudding. You need a clean surface.  The hardest part of this recipe timing of adding the egg. I read somewhere to add some of your cooked rice mixture to the egg & milk mixture first, then adding the rice/egg mixture back into your pudding while AWAY from the heat. For me, this ensures my egg won't scramble. . I've made this recently with COCONUT milk- Can you say decadent?

text:
This is so yummy and I love it. I cooked the rice in my instant pot so I had rice all ready to go. I think a couple of people were complaining about the egg cooking when added. I did it as the recipe said first and the next day when I made it, I added the milk with the beaten egg before adding to the rice mixture. The egg was fine both times, but maybe if you add the milk to the egg, it will be less likely to become scrambled! This will definitely be my go to rice pudding! Easy to make and very tasty!

17986102
Display Name:
Mel
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674156.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I used medium grain white rice and it was perfect! I prefer to soak my sultanas in water overnight first (you could add rum or sugar if you wanted). I also used only the egg yolk.

The good thing about cooking rice for rice pudding is that you WANT it gluggy. So there’s no harm in taking the lid off & giving it a stir to see how it’s going. I ended up having to add an extra cup of water so I could cook my rice for longer as it wasn’t quite soft enough (you want to make sure the rice is 100% cooked and soft before adding your milk & sugar). Better to be over cooked than undercooked.

I lightly rinsed my rice before cooking but not afterwards. Next time I won’t rinse it at all as the starches help to gluggy up the pudding.

Amazing recipe. Will never use any other for rice pudding!
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2019-12-22T01:04:42.98
helpfulCount:
0

text:
I have made this recipe three times now.  The first two times I microwaved a cup of rice with two cups of water in a four-cup measuring cup and used the required amount of rice for the recipe and I needed the plain cooked rice leftover for other meals.  The third time I used bulgar wheat instead of rice. I measured a cup of bulgar to two cups of water and let it.cook.  I then followed the recipe exactly and now I have a perfect bulgar wheat pudding which I will eat for breakfast.  I added some pecans as well.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6807733.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I don't even like rice pudding, however, my wife is pregnant and was craving something sweet at 12:00 am. So, in a pinch, I followed this recipe almost word for word. I added 1-cup of sugar after slowly simmering the rice and milk to a desired consistency. Afterwards, I followed the tips left in other reviews and put the hot mixture into the beaten egg before adding it to the rest of the rice. I did use long grain rice and reduced it's starch content by rinsing in cold water then putting it into boiling water with salt for 2-min and rinsing a second time before finally cooking it again in salt water.

It turned out divine almost like a warm ice cream. Just take your time.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Rich, thick, creamy, delicious! Just what I was looking for on this cool first-day-of autumn morning. Thank you, Erica! Marvelous recipe! Just a reminder to those having trouble.. tempering your eggs with a bit of the warm rice is a must if you don’t want scrambled egg in your pudding.. take it slow & easy. You don’t want to rush this - trust me, it will be worth it!! I added a couple of sticks of cinnamon to the second step (just as my mom used to do) and, to cut a bit of the sweetness & add more depth of flavor, topped the finished pudding with ground cinnamon and ground cardamom. Yum!!

Display Name:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6765540.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
When my favorite little Greek restaurant closed down, I literally cried. The food was good, but honestly I cried because they made the BEST rice pudding I ever tasted. Rich and creamy, with cinnamon and nutmeg, filled with soft raisins, served warm the way I like it, and topped with a crunchy caramelized sugar top like creme brulee. Oh my goodness, it was heaven in a bowl, a warm hug from the angels. I have been trying to recreate that pudding for 15 years with no luck. Fast forward to now...my teenager will be having her wisdom teeth removed next week and she requested creamy rice pudding for her recovery time. No raisins for her and she wants it cold, but this recipe totally nails what I have been searching for since my favorite restaurant closed. I used evaporated milk as some other tips suggested as well as medium grain Calrose rice, plus I added cinnamon and nutmeg,  but otherwise all was the same. I'll miss the raisins, but I'm sneaking off to "test" it a little more precisely while it's still warm. Shh..don't tell on me!

text:
I made this recipe for my husband before and it was delicious. The second time I made it, I didn't have all the milk required so used 1/2 and 1/2 for some of the 2 cups called for and it turned out well. The success of my second batch encouraged me to experiment with other kinds of milk and I'm happy to tell you all that using flavored coffee creamer really kicks the pudding out of the ballpark.  Use whatever flavor you like in the same quantity listed and you won't be disappointed!

text:
When I was in school, our cafeteria made something they called “creamed rice”.  It was served with a large ice cream scooper and almost always served as a side dish with chili for some reason. I would add sugar to it to make it a dessert and a little milk to make it more pudding-like. This is the first recipe I’ve ever found that tastes exactly like that creamed rice.  It’s so delicious and it’s the ultimate comfort food. I try not to make it more than twice a year because once I make it, I can’t stop eating it!

I had some extra white rice in the fridge so I set that boiling with some milk and water while I looked for a recipe. Eyeballed the quantities. Didn't have Raisins. Keep stirring over a low heat while pouring the in the egg mixture a little at a time. DH was very happy.

text:
Made this for the first time ever after I bravely asked my boyfriend, "What's your favorite side dish?" He told me his mom's rice pudding, and I thought for sure I was doomed to fail. However, I tried this recipe and didn't change a thing. I made sure to buy medium grain rice and add a little bit of the hot mixture to the egg and milk mixture so the egg didn't turn into "egg-drop soup." Those tips worked great. I also used heavy cream instead of butter, but only because I was short on milk. :) Overall, awesome recipe that I will make again. Oh! And the boyfriend's review? "Better than my mom's." BOOM. Thanks, Erica!!

text:
This has been my go-to recipe for the last three years. I finally found a recipe that my husband admits is better than his moms??. The changes I made are just personal preferences, the recipe is good as is. I used 1-3/4 cup of milk for the second addition of milk, because I like the rice pudding a little looser. I also added cinnamon and did not add any raisins.
After it’s cooled, you may have to add a little milk and stir it in, to loosen it.
Great recipe, Erica-thanks!

Display Name:
Christina Rangel

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6491720.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Love this recipe. Turns out perfect every time.
For those saying their rice turned out chewy after using brown rice-brown rice is chewier than white rice to begin with. If you find egg whites in your pudding it's because you aren't beating the eggs long enough. I have not had a problem at all.  

One thing I DID change was I used a rice cooker-and I added vanilla and cinnamon to the water that I added into the rice cooker to cook the rice. It made the house smell fantastic for 20 mins and the rice came out already seasoned and yummy before I moved it to the stove and  added the milk and other ingredients. I also sometimes use a tiny bit more milk at the end just for a creamier texture. But I haven't Always had to add more. Sometimes the 1/2 cup at the end is just right, other times I add a little more. Either way the recipe is a hit with my family who do not normally care for rice pudding. This is a new favorite.

region:

country:
None
text:
I had made coconut rice the night before (replace half the cooking water with coconut milk; I used canned) and thought to make some kind of porridge or something from the leftovers then found this recipe. I had just enough rice to not need to modify the amounts and went with it. Using leftover coconut rice and milk for the first reduction stage, I subbed Truvia baking blend according to the package. With the egg, I used the remaining coconut milk from the can of the night before, which ended up being 1/2c and about 1 tbsp. Butter and vanilla the same. 
It tasted great warm from the pan and the coconut was very subtle, just a little bit *extra*. DH is the rice pudding fan in the house, but I’d make this again just for myself even if he doesn’t care for my changes

text:
Never made rice pudding before, but made it for someone who needs soft foods for a bit.  Kicked it up a bit with the zest of one orange when cooking the rice, 1/2 t. of cinnamon and a dash of nutmeg.  I'm not a fan of rice pudding, because it is pretty bland, but these additions really make it flavorful!  Tempered the egg with the warmed milk and added just a touch more salt.  After the first bite, I got a fist bump, so it must have hit the spot.

userID:
24673685
Display Name:
Mike Morrison
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
1
favoritesCount:
1
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6069058.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a very easy recipe for a great rice pudding. Those who had issues seemed to have deviated from the recipe (used brown rice, which takes much longer to cook) or maybe didn’t think when adding the ingredients (added egg directly to hot rice).
I  use “broken rice” from the Asian mkt. it’s smaller grained so makes a creamy pudding. Also I beat my egg into the milk and let it sit while the rice was cooking in the milk stage. Then add when instructed.
Also for,those who seem to not add all of the cooked rice, I think if you don’t use all of the rice, it will be thinner. I like mine thick, so I used all of the rice.
Last tip... soak your raisins in a few TBS of Rum to plump them up a bit!
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2018-12-02T20:00:19.553
helpfulCount:
0

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674134.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My memories of rice pudding from childhood involved burnt chunks of milk that darkened the pudding and added a "crisp" flavor. This was my first attempt (and I'm 45! - I guess I had been avoiding it, but then I had extra rice, so...) It was extraordinary! Someone's 1 star review suggested that it didn't set, so I realized that I needed to cook - and stir - at a relatively high (med-high) heat for a solid 15-20 minutes. I used a whisk and set up a show to watch on my ipad to help distract me because standing and stirring for 20 minutes takes a toll! I did it, though, and it set beautifully. And it tasted great hot - and no crispy burnt chunks floating about, and I am in love with this - though it is extremely rich and fatty. I did sneak a couple bites for breakfast this morning and it tastes great cold, too!  I let the pan soak a bit in hot water and it was easy to clean, so YAY! I think I'll use this for winter holidays.

text:
I always use brown rice due to the health benefits. While cooking my brown rice I add a dollop of coconut oil instead of vegetable which just adds a wonderful flavor. I also use almost half the sugar and its still plenty sweet because of the raisin. I also do 1/4 C milk and 1/4 C  orange juice instead of all milk and that gives it more sweetness and a touch of orange flavor.
It's a also super good with craysons especially with the oj.
The perfect comfort food on a cold day!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Best creamy rice pudding ever. I have been making amazing creamy rice pudding for years. It's always been a favourite but I've made it the hard way. Standing over a pot stirring while cooking the rice in milk. My flavour secret was that along with the standard cinnamon, which is common in most rice pudding recipes, I added nutmeg. The flavour was delicious. Since there was no call for cinnamon or anything other than vanilla extract, I added the cinnamon and nutmeg when I added the milk. That is the only change other than putting the salt in the water when cooking the rice. The result was fantastic enough that I will be using this recipe from now on. Thank you so much for making one of our favourite desserts so much easier to make.

text:
This is an excellent basic rice pudding recipe. You can use instant rice instead of regular...I have tried both and the finished product is the same. So a couple of tips : scramble the egg in with the remaining milk before adding them. I have read where some have had problems with an "egg drop" effect and it eliminated this issue. I added 1/2 cup more milk as well. I used pancake syrup instead of vanilla (only about 1 1/2 T). And I added more raisins. Can't have too many raisins. :)

userID:
10734363
Display Name:
Katherine
isPro:
