photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5497317.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
So the pro is that it's pretty easy to make. I never made rice pudding before and this came out pretty similar to the store-bought boxes I usually get. I did think it ended up too sweet and that's from someone who loves desserts, but that's easy to adjust with less sugar.
The big thing is I made this twice - once with cold leftover rice, and once exactly based on the recipe, cooked just for the pudding - and both times the mixture ended up being too thick and was burning up/sticking to the pan way before the time indicated in the recipe. I had to adjust by adding a lot of extra water or milk. I feel like I must have more than doubled the amount of liquid and yet the pudding is still very very thick (and sweet). The first time I thought it may be because the rice was dry from being leftovers, but the second time cooking the rice was basically no different.
Now that I know this, I feel like I can make this again and have all the proper portion adjustments and have it turn out great, but following the recipe as is would lead to some very sweet thick burnt rice.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:

text:
Absolutely the best I've ever had with a few steps changed for simplication. (There is really no need to measure the water so I just heated a big pot of water and medium grain rice, then drained and RINSED after the given 20 mins.  I worried not having the starch from the drained rice would interfere with the texture and thickness but it turned out to be needless. Thick, creamy decadent!  

The other simplification was that I beat the eggs then added to the milk with the raisins. I then added this mixture to the pan.  I believe it contributed wonderfully to the custard like texture.  
Everyone wanted the recipe.   Thank you for sharing!

userID:
24141079
Display Name:
Kyla Hopkins
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5690489.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
When making this recipe the first time, I followed it exactly (sans raisins, cause ick.)  The second time I made it, I substituted 1 cup of milk and the sugar for a can of sweetened evaporated milk. This cuts a lot of work with the recipe, and made it much faster to make. I also tempered the egg before adding it so it didn't scramble it. This thickened the pudding wonderfully. It was delicious and creamy.  If you'd like super creamy pudding, use jasmine scented rice and over cook it in too much water, till it's almost rice porridge consistency, then add that to your pudding. Make it the second last thing you add however, as it may just make the addition of the egg unnecessary. The flavor and texture profile of this make it a huge favorite of my Mom and Nana. They both asked for the recipe and it replaced my great grandmothers in the position of favourite rice pudding, and only they know her recipe.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2018-08-27T13:39:18.74

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've eaten so much rice pudding that is watery and soupy, but this recipe is so much better. for those struggling with it turning out too thin, just cook the rice/sugar mixture for a little longer. Mine never starts to really thicken up until almost twenty minutes in. 

The last time I made this I sprinkled chocolate chips on top of my hot bowl of pudding, to make a really rich chocolate version. Also another variation is to use Jasmine rice, which lends a very unique and exotic flavour.

text:
I hate when people haven’t tried the recipe and doctor it when they do but..... I realized, much to my dismay, I ran out of vanilla extract over the 4th of July (dang cupcakes). So I substituted it with 1/4 tsp rum extract, added cinnamon, and a dash of nutmeg. 
I also scrambled my egg in with the remaining 1/2 c. Milk (which I used almond milk) because I was afraid I’d get scrambled eggs in my pudding. 
All in all I’d say my version was like Christmas eggnog in my mouth which wasn’t bad, even though I will totally mAke this the right way. I would still blend the egg and the milk before adding it though.

text:
I've made this pudding twice. The first time it seemed to runny so I used 1/2 cup less milk. Once it had cooled down it was very thick and too dense for the person I was making it for to eat. The second batch I did exactly and as it cooled I stirred it to keep it light. It turned out perfect and light and creamy. I used Jasmine rice for both batches, next time I'll use plain white rice like Uncle Ben's.

text:
Many thanks to the person who shared this! Ever since I discovered this wonderful recipe about 6-8 months ago, I've made it, (almost) exactly as stated, at least once per week. (I omit the raisins, but I do that with just about every recipe that calls for raisins.) The recipe is much easier than I had anticipated, and I've (almost) always had great results. I messed it up one time so far. Still not sure what I did wrong, or even how to describe what happened to it...lol. On a side note, I can't write this review without mentioning how amazed I am that I don't have to be careful to make sure the milk doesn't separate or burn. It's weird! Pretty cool, but still super weird.

None
text:
This was amazing... just like my grandmother used to make it. Now I did make a few alterations- after the rice mixture thickened, I then took it off the stove and added the butter, raisins, vanilla and cinnamon. I mixed the milk and the eggs separately before adding to help against curdling and then slowly added that little bits at a time while vigorously mixing in between additions. I then poured the whole thing into a greased 9x13 and baked on 350 for about 15-20 minutes until the tops got golden brown and the center was custard-like... since that's how I grew up eating this recipe. IT WAS JUST LIKE I REMEMBER!!! Thank you for a great starter recipe!

text:
Tip: if you double or triple the recipe, cook the rice and milk and sugar mixture longer! It should be thick and creamy. I tripled the recipe and kept adding time until the texture was what I wanted.

Also, short grain rice (like Japanese rice, will give you a creamier, thicker, chewier consistency. 

Add fresh ground nutmeg if you have it! 

I made a ton of it for my son's preschool Cinco de Mayo party. A hit!

city:

text:
Followed the recipe but I used left over rice and it took longer than 20 minutes for it to get nice and creamy. I did not pour the beaten egg into the hot mixture directly. I poured some of the rice and milk mixture into the egg to get the temp up and then poured that into pan (seen that trick on Food Network). This avoids the eggs from scrambling in the pudding. 
I did not have raisins on hand so I used dried oranges instead.

text:
This is the best rice pudding I've ever made (I usually just get the Cozy Shack stuff). I'm a rice pudding purist, so I left out the raisins, and didn't add cinnamon/nutmeg. I used basmati rice, which was tender in only 13 minutes. I also tempered the beaten egg with the 1/2 c milk by drizzling in some of the hot rice mixture, while whisking constantly, before adding it. I usually make it by cooking the rice in the milk/sugar mixture and it never comes out right. This was perfect, and easy!

text:
It does not get any better than this, or any easier.   This was an unplanned desert.  I made a pot of rice which turned out sticky and I didn't want to use it in my entree. So I immediately went to all recipes  and looked up rice pudding because my mom loves it.  The rice was regular long grain variety.  I left it right in the pot I had cooked it in and followed the recipe.  
I gave up cows milk years ago and drink/use almond milk.  I am hesitant to use it as a milk replacement in recipes sometimes it is fine and sometimes not. (did not work in instant pudding)  It was raining and I was not going to the store so I used half/half and craisins instead of raisins. 

I followed the directions with those 3 exceptions: Regular rice, 1/2&1/2, and craisins and the pudding turned out amazing.  The texture and taste were perfect!  I will be doing it again.

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I dont use white rice, so I used brown.  The key to no lumpy egg whites is the temperature.  You cant make this on a high burner setting or you'll get cooked eggs instead of a creamy pudding.  Also, add the remaining milk (to cool temp a bit) then immediately add egg.  This also helps prevent cooked whites.  Mine took longer because I had my burner too low and had to turn it up.  The end result was amazing.  Cant wait to go to work and brag to my co-worker about making this from scratch since he loves bragging about his wife making rice pudding from scratch and never brings me any.  DEFINITELY a keeper!!!

text:
BUT! ADULT VERSION! 
I used 5 cups basmati hot rice cooked just with a TBLS of butter. Mixed a ~14oz can of sweetened cond. milk, 1/4 cup of spiced RUM, ~ 1/2 -3/4 cup of milk , ~ 1/2 to 3/4 cup BROWN sugar, and a cup of SPICED RUM SOAKED CRANBERRIES! (I put the dried cranberries in a dish, filled it with rum to about 3/4 of the way up and nuked it for ONE minute) A dash of salt, (~1/4tsp)and mixed all these OTHER ingredients together and added to the pot of rice. NO EGG. Cooked for about 5 more minutes, remember the rice was HOT from a fresh batch.  Sooo creamy, so so creamy, sweet and rum zippy! 

 So you say; "this isn't anything like the recipe!"
Yes, BUT, this is the recipe I used to get the idea!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made a few changes, I added about 1/2 tsp each of cinnamon and nutmeg.  A few reviews have stated that the out come was soupy. If that is the case, make sure you use Whole Milk or it will not set up.  As others have stated make sure you incorporate the egg mixture by adding a little of the rice mixture to the 1/2 cup milk, sugar and egg.  I added about 1 Tablespoon  at a time to the egg mixture, stirred it, added another, stirred it in.  In all total I probably did this  about 5 or 6 times.  The key is to use Whole Milk and incorporate the egg mixture.

text:
Easy & creamy rice pudding.  Better than Kozy Shack!  I have made this recipe three or four times now.  The first time I made it without raisins because I didn't have any, and it was just as good.  When I made it with raisins, I only added about 1/3 C because 2/3 C seemed like it would be way too many raisins.  Otherwise, I made the recipe exactly as directed.  I serve it warm with cinnamon & sugar on top.  YUM!!!  My family loves this recipe.  I have doubled the recipe, and it's just as delicious the next day served cold.

4725398
Display Name:
Brock Gunter-Smith
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1568026.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I simplified by doing:
1/2 cup of Kokuho Extra Franck Medium Grain Rice, cooked with 1/2 tsp of salt in 1 cup of water for 20 minutes in pot over medium-high heat, stirring occasionally.
Added 1 cup of 2% milk to pot, and continued cooking for another 20 minutes on medium-high heat, stirring occasionally.
Added 3 tsp of brown suger and a splash more milk to keep it loose. Cook for another 5 minutes, stirring occasionally.
At this stage, just add a milk of milk if it’s too thick, add salt or sugar or other flavour as you wish.
I then poured it into a blender, added a bit more milk to loosen it up and pulsed it 4 or 5 times for about 3 seconds each time, to break down the rice more.

At this stage it was the PERFECT consistency to be able to draw up into my favourite 20mL (3/4 oz) or 60mL (2 oz) syringe, for being able to squeeze into my mouth (I just had double jaw surgery so can not chew well or use my lips yet to use a spoon at all).

Awesome! This is a GREAT foundational recipe. I plan on testing with various types of rice, and also using broths instea of milk, and also trying other subtle flavors and spices. For basic sustainable that I can take eating each day with subtle variations, this is a KEEPER!!!
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2017-12-19T20:21:27.37

userID:
411324
Display Name:
Cheryl
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0

12
favoritesCount:

recipesCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614261.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I cooked 3/4 cup ofJasmine rice with1 1/2 cups of water and1tsp of unsalted butter for 20 minutes. I checked the rice to be sure it was tender (based on reviews I read before starting!). I had a cup of coconut milk leftover, so I used that plus a cup of 1% milk, 1/2 cup of sugar, 1/4 tsp. salt, and added them all to the rice in the pan in which it was cooked. It cooked for 18-19 minutes, and I added 1tbsp. unsalted butter so it could melt. Then, added 2/3 cup of golden raisins. I mixed the egg with 1/2 cup of heavy cream, then added a small spoonful of the cooked rice pudding and mixed it together. I continued to add the hot rice pudding, a little at a time, until the egg and heavy cream were warm. I poured the egg and heavy cream into the pan and continued cooking for 2 minutes. I removed it from the heat and stirred in about 1 tsp. of vanilla. I tried a taste, and all I can say is MMMMMMMMMM! I put the pudding into the refrigerator, and I’ll report back on how it cools.

country:

text:
Thank you for a tasty, easy & versatile recipe! One could use any form of milk, go with or without raisins, spice as desired. I used all the proportions except the sugar--I prepped the 1/3 cup called for, but tested as I added & ended up using a little less and it was plenty sweet. I also didn't have raisins, but am sure they'd be a nice addition.  I'm thinking you could use other dried fruits, too. We love cinnamon so instead of garnishing with it, I put it in the rice when it was cooking in milk to infuse it into the entire pudding. Only reason I didn't give 5 stars is because you can't give 4.5 and I think 1/3 cup sugar would be too much, especially if you added raisins which are sweet as well.

text:
Only change I made is that I peeled the outer layer of an orange, put half in the boiling water mix and then the other half in the rice pudding mix. Remove at the end, totally kicks up the flavor to another level. I would also warm the remaining milk, temper the egg to bring it to temperature to lower the risk of it scrambling.

text:
I modified a bit... loving Indian spices I flavoured it with cardamom, cinnamon, cloves and a few strands of saffron instead of vanilla. Though I used the recipe for amounts and timing, instead of 2 cups regular milk, I used 1 cup 2%, 1/2 cup coconut milk, 1/2 cup of evaporated milk to make it taste creamier. It turned out so creamy and amazing!

text:
It's the perfect easy homey dessert.  For those that found pieces of egg in the pudding, you always have to temper an egg before adding it to a hot liquid.  I mixed the egg, milk, and a sprinkling of cinnamon together, then tempered the egg by mixing hot pudding into it before adding the egg to the pudding.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Awesome recipe! I've never made rice pudding before and this turned out fantastic. I had some left over rice in the fridge and this recipe was a great use for it. So tasty. For those of you who had trouble with the eggs- I took a little of the hot milk out of the rice while it was cooking. You very slowly pour it into the eggs while whisking the eggs. Then, I took that egg and milk mixture and slowly added it to the cooking rice AFTER adding the additional cold milk. Make sure you keep the mixture moving and you won't get cooked eggs in your pudding :)

I added cinnamon and nutmeg because that's how we like it. Came out creamy and good.

text:
Delicious!  The ratio of milk to rice is perfect.   I used day old Jasmine rice (soft and sticky) and whole milk. Note about the egg: Just don't forget to temper it in...a must for any pudding. ;) You could cut out up to half of the sugar, depending on your taste for sweetness, and it would still be delicious! Just use your judgement. I didn't add raisins this time. It's so versatile you can add whatever you like at the end like spices or additions mixed in (chopped dried apricots, chopped dried mango, golden raisins or whatever dried fruit sounds good to you) or on top (tart cherries mixed with a bit of sugar, crushed nuts, coconut flakes). Or just have it plain as a yummy comfort food.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
REALLY GREAT! This is such an easy to follow recipe! I ended up using jasmine rice because its what I have, but I prefer having some bite left to my rice pudding so that's fine, it still came out plenty creamy. I didn't switch the rice into a new pan because I didn't want to do more dishes, and I waited about 5 minutes after adding the milk to add the sugar/salt mixture. (I also ommitted the raisins, because I dont like them. I'm sure they're delicious in rice pudding but I'll never find out)
I did add cinnamon though. Rice pudding and cinnamon are just so tasty together.

I don't really see how anyone could have difficulties because this recipe is super easy to follow and you have a lot of time while waiting on the rice to cook to get things ready. (I beat the love of Jesus into that egg.) 

For anyone still having trouble with the recipe? Use white rather than brown rice (brown rice is chewy and takes longer to cook) and beat the egg if you dont want eggy bits! It doesn't matter if you just whisk it really well with a fork! Adding the second part of milk just before the egg may help as well? I dont know... I didn't get pieces of egg I don't know how it could happen.

I cooked my rice in the microwave. ( That name brand orange box has a recipe on the side.)  This is the way I always cook rice.
Reduced the amount of cooking milk and saved for later to be mixed with the STRAINED beaten egg and hot pudding.  I quadrupled the recipe and used my deep, square, ceramic lined ban. 

 Made no changes other than to adjust the method.  It came out awesome, no sticky pan, and no scrambled egg in the pudding.   My go-to favorite recipe from now on.

text:
I don't understand the negative reviews... I have never made, nor have I ever been a fan of rice pudding. On a whim this evening I whipped this up for my boyfriend with a few minor changes. 1-I didn't have a full 2 cups of milk, so I topped off with evaporated milk to get the proper measure. 2-I didn't have any golden raisins so I used craisins dried cranberries instead (he loves them!) And finally I didn't have vanilla so I complemented the craisins with just a touch of lemon zest. I used boil in bag plain old white rice and let me tell you, it came out really amazing! It was delish, he loved it, and so did I (and as I'd said, never really been a fan...) I will DEFINITELY use this recipe again!

text:
Followed the recipe exactly and it turned out great. Very yummy and creamy :) 

Since I mixed my egg/sugar/milk in a metal bowl, I just put it over top the pot that my rice/milk mixture was thickening in, double-broiler style, to heat it up.  Whisked it a little so the egg wouldn't cook, then added it to the pot. 

Seemed a little runny so I added a bit of flour to thicken it up and it ended up being too thick, so probably won't do that next time. 

Overall, really yummy and will make again!

Perfect!  Used medium grained rice, because I couldn't find short grained at the market.  Only had skim milk, but it turned out perfectly. Also, the rice must be thoroughly cooked before you add it; otherwise, you will end up with chewy pudding.  Will definitely make this again.

Very good and simple recipe. I used 2% milk and added 1/2 tsp of cinnamon at the end. Took about 30 mins for it to thicken with 2% milk before adding the additional milk and egg. I beat the egg into the remaining 1/2 c milk and added it slowly while stirring entire time to avoid egg clumps.

None
text:
This rice pudding was so simple to make. Creamy and tasty!  Try this before you try an oven bake rice pudding recipe. The oven can dry out the texture. I soaked the raisins in a little warm water first to soften. I used long grain rice and it needed a about a half cup more water to simmer in the beginning. Keep your eye on the pot and stir often but once it is done on stove top you won't go back.  Delish !

text:
This was really easy and really yummy.
I brought the egg to room temperature by letting it sit in hot tap water for a few minutes before cracking it and adding it to the milk.  I beat the egg in the milk and SLOWLY added that mixture into the creamy rice, while constantly stirring, so that the egg wouldn't cook.
I omitted the raisins as a personal preference,
and sprinkled on some cinnamon sugar instead when serving.  I will definitely make this again!

text:
For those of you that are having chewy rice issues, I felt I might add a tip, that I haven't seen in any of the reviews. When you cook your rice, treat it as you would a slow cooker!!! You cannot open the lid to stir it! Rice needs the steam that has built up inside the pot to cook. If you open the lid, you've increased the cooking time, which will result in the "chewy rice" when cooked to the time stated in the recipe. It's a common mistake.
Review:
Rating:
5

It is a great basis recipe which can easily be modified as many have written to suit personal taste and memories.

A good comfort food that can easily be made both gluten and dairy free by using coconut milk in place of regular milk and coconut oil in place of butter. city:

country:
None
text:
Made this a few times and I gave it a 5 as the recipe is written. 

However I have tried several things from the recipe that I personally like or can suggest.  Made this with Arborio, Jasmine and a generic bag of medium grain rice = The medium grain rice worked best in my opinion. 

I made it with egg and without the egg. I love custard so I thought I would like the egg version better =  I like the no egg better. It had a lighter taste and I liked the brighter white look of it too. 

Technique = If I was wanting to serve rice and it not be sticky and see and move individual grains,  I would wash and drain, plus I would not stir it. But for this I want the opposite. I want the more starch so I stirred, I didn't leave it alone. I would have to adjust my technique for the Arborio because it got to thick on me, but it tasted good. 

I also tried it plain (without raisins), with raisins and with dried cranberries. I also made a cranberry sauce that I put a dab on.

a.) I salted and buttered my rice in step 1
b.) Used whole milk instead of water to cook rice with
c.) I beat my egg, 1/2 c. milk, and 1/3 c. sugar together and added it at the end (instead of adding sugar earlier on)
Results were wonderful! Thanks for sharing!

text:
Mix the egg in i/2 cup milk and let it get to room temp while doing pudding and even cooking rice [ always use room temperature milk or eggs etc. for baking I prefer less sweet, a 1/4 cup sugar. I used a few raisins and did not like them.  I think they need to be soaked in hot water and drained to remove some the off flavor.and make them softer.                       I cooked brown rice in a pressure cooker  and used the leftover rice, it was not chewy.  I think next time I will use only 2% milk and not any canned milk. I added 1/2 tsp. cinnamon, 1/8 tsp. nutmeg, sprinkle of ginger, allspice and cloves plus more vanilla. pretty good.  I will try again with white rice, no raisins or canned / evaporated milk.

Display Name:
HokieCosmo
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674141.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
TIP: For the addition of the egg, beat the egg with the remaining 1/2 Cup milk in a small bowl. Add a spoonful of the hot milk and rice mixture to the cold milk and egg and beat. Repeat this a few times until the milk and egg mixture is warm, then add to the milk and rice. This is called "tempering" and will prevent the egg from cooking immediately and giving you lumps of hard-boiled egg in your pudding. I also added the raisins first to decrease the temperature of the milk and rice mixture before adding the egg and milk. I'm not fond of vanilla so left it out and was still pleased with the result.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2193437.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this pudding with left over Jasmine short grain rice. It has a lovely fragrance. I used 2% milk and added the 1/3 cup sugar at the start. Added the cinnamon and nutmeg to the milk  plus 3 whole cardamon seeds (removed before serving).   I stirred the mixture frequently over a low - medium heat until thickened and creamy. Softened 1/2 cup of craisins in warm water, before adding to the mixture.  Also added 1/2 cup of the slightly cooled mixture to 1/2 cup of Fat Free half & half, for a richer taste and the beaten egg. ( to keep from curdling).   Returned this to the main pot and continued to cook for about 5 minutes. the texture was perfect and the Cherry flavored craisins were a nice change to raisins. Served in individual custard cups with a pinch of nutmeg and garnished with sliced almonds.

text:
This is a little too milky for my taste. I like more rice in my rice pudding. I think next time I will do 1-1/2 cups of milk instead of 2 cups total. I did what the other reviews said and added about 3 spoonfuls of the hot  rice and milk mixture to my beaten egg and half cup of milk before adding it to the pot. I made sure it was lukewarm before adding and stirred the rice pudding for 2 minutes like the directions said  but I till have some cooked egg white in my pudding which isn't a huge deal. However, next time I think I'll use use the egg yoke to eliminate that problem. I cooked the rice with the tbsp of butter so I didn't add it again at the end. I topped if off with cinnamon. It has a nice, light flavor. Might try a little more butter and/or sugar next time.

userID:
8750625
Display Name:
Bebe D
isPro:
False
followersCount:
1
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
1
favoritesCount:
23
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4050765.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Best rice pudding I've ever made! My former boss absolutely loves rice pudding so I'm always on the lookout for a good recipe. I was taking him and his wife rice pudding today so decided to make this recipe. It truly is the best I've made - and I've made a lot using lots of different recipes! It was so creamy but so very easy to make. I used whole milk to make it richer than skim. Also, I put the salt in the boiling water as I made the rice. After the rice was made, I just continued in the same pot and added the butter so it melted into the rice, then sprinkled on the sugar so it would be sure and melt. The only other thing I did different than the recipe was I tempered the egg by whisking it into the 1/2 c milk and then adding some of the warm rice/milk mixture into the egg/milk mixture before stirring the egg/milk into the rest of the rice and milk. That ensured that I wouldn't get lumpy cooked egg. Finally, after it was done and I poured the finished rice pudding into a dish, I sprinkled cinnamon and nutmeg on top. Incredibly delicious! In fact, after taking it to my friends, I had to also make a new batch today for my husband and me! Thanks Erica for sharing this! (P.S. after making this for us I realized it wasn't sweet enough so I added another 1/3 c of sugar. That made it much better!)

text:
I have been making rice pudding for years and this is absolutely the creamiest ever !  I will end my search.  Be sure to add some of the hot mixture into the beaten egg before you pour it in and when you do pour it stir a lot so it doesn't cook.  My family doesn't like raisins so I made it plain.  It is like a soft custard. It was important that I cook the rice correctly that first 20 minutes or it would not be the softness it should be.  Enjoy !!!

text:
I made this with long grain rice.  I liked the fact that it was quick and easy, since it's too hot to turn the oven on, but it was lacking a few key items.  I love rice pudding, but two of the best parts are the custard part and the spice.  It definitely didn't have much custard to it and no cinnamon whatsoever.  When it was done cooking, I just added some cinnamon and nutmeg to give it that "old fashioned" rice pudding flavor.  I'd make it again if I was craving a quick rice pudding, but my husband wouldn't touch it.

text:
I made this tonight...so easy! Everyone's different right to give it their own touch. Here's what I did:
I used the same saucepan instead of 2.
When I added the milk, I kept the heat on simmer and let it heat slowly and added 3 pieces of lemon peel.
I didn't put egg or raisins either.
I used jasmine rice,
turned out yum.
The tip I reckon is not to boil the milk and not to stir too much. This way it won't stick or turn out a gluggy mess. I didn't use a non-stick pan and the rice didn't stick.
I have never roasted peaches before but had a couple so halved them, sprinkle with sugar or honey (whatever you like) and roasted them to have with the rice pudding.

country:
None
text:
A really great recipe. I had no problems except for the pudding browning a bit, but make sure to keep a close eye on the pudding and stir the mixture once in a while to prevent burning. First batch I made was a success. Some tips if you are making it the first time. First I would wash the rice with cold water in a strainer before adding in the pot of boiling water.  Sometimes the rice isn't as clean as you might think. Second, make sure to constantly stir as you add in the egg gradually. This will prevent the egg from cooking completely which could leave white strings. And finally, make sure to taste test the pudding first with the 1/3 cup of sugar and if you don't  find it sweet enough for your liking, add some more gradually.

Display Name:
WarriorPrincess

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614246.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I do love this recipe. 

My suggestions: if using long grain rice more milk will be needed to achieve a creamier texture for the first addition of milk and for the second addition. I keep an extra cup/cup and half of milk handy. 

Second, the problem with finding egg bits can be corrected by lowering the temperature before adding the egg and milk. The rice before the egg addition should be at a medium/medium setting and simmering with a lot of small bubbles bursting relatively fast in it.  

Now, before adding the egg, the rice pudding should be at the highest of low settings and have only a few bubbles bursting. That means it has sit a little while until it cools to that temperature. Once it gets to that point, add the egg and milk stirring constantly and rapidly to avoid egg bits (maybe 5 minutes).   Pudding will have a uniform yellowy color.  

After about 5 minutes or so, bring the pudding back to a medium/medium heat.  Once at temperature, cook for two minutes then remove from heat promptly after. 

Add the butter and the vanilla.  

Cool for at least 3 hours if you like it uniforml

country:

text:
I've made this recipe countless number of times.  My kids beg for it.  To be clear, cook the rice first, then do the rest of the recipe.  I cook the rice, then make it in the same pan I just cooked the rice in.  I've found the key for me is to cook the rice, milk, sugar, salt mixture long enough to get it creamy.  I cook it until I think it's creamy, then I cook it 5 or so minutes more.  If I don't, it doesn't turn out as good.  Once the rice, milk, sugar, salt are cooking, I beat the egg and add it to the remaining milk.  When the rice is creamy, I temper the milk egg mixture and add it to the pot.  Delicious!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I tried this recipe to use up left over rice, and it was delicious! The only thing I'd change about the directions is, you have to temper your egg before adding it to the hot liquid. For those who may not know, tempering is when you ladle some of the hot liquid into the beaten egg to warm the egg up. Whisk constantly and add the liquid slowly. This will prevent you from ending up with scrambled egg bits in your pudding.

Now I purposely make extra rice, just so I can make this desert. Its rich, creamy, and delicious. Its best eaten warm, but you can eat it cold too.

text:
I didn't quite follow the recipe, I had about 3 cups of cooked rice in the fridge that I thought I'd get to for dinners this week and just wasn't feeling it. I used medium grain white sticky rice, about 2 cups of milk in the sauce pan and then beat the egg with the butter and vanilla adding in cinnamon and nutmeg instead of raisins. I let the rice sit in the milk for a bit before putting it on the heat and adding the sugar and once it was creamy turned the heat down and then added my egg mix.

I prefer rice pudding to be warm and can say I enjoyed it, but it's not living up to Swedish tradition with almonds that my aunt makes. So, next time I'll be adding some shredded ones in.

text:
I gave this recipe 5 stars due to the ease of making it and the creamy texture of the pudding.  It is great to whip up for someone recovering from an illness or needing to eat soft and somewhat bland foods.  I have made it twice, think I cut the sugar a bit the first time around and would recommend doing that, as the full amount yields a pretty sweet rice pudding!  Don't leave out the raisins, they add a nice chewy texture to this smooth & creamy dessert!

text:
I left out the raisins, personal preference.  While the rice was cooking mixed the milk and sugar, microwaved 1 minute to aid dissolving the sugar and added 1/2 teaspoon each of nutmeg and cinnamon.   The egg and milk were mixed in a blender.
I saw no reason for transferring the rice to a different sauce pan so I simply added the milk/sugar to the rice and proceeded following the recipe.  
Simple, easy, tasty, I'll never buy rice pudding again.

Display Name:
Christy Cooks

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I can't believe I haven't rated this recipe yet! I've been making it for years. It is excellent. I've only found one recipe that is better, but it uses heavy cream and you cook the rice in it. I usually make rice pudding when we have leftover rice from a Thai restaurant that I just do not want to waste. I love that I can pick this recipe up at step two with the already cooked rice. The short, sticky rice from the restaurant is so perfect in this because of all the starch in it which really makes a creamy pudding. I noticed some reviewers had a hard time getting theirs to thicken up- it may be that the type of rice they use does not have enough starch. I make it as directed, often using part half and half (my doctor told me to put on some weight). It is a wonderful comfort food when you are not feeling well and it goes down so easily, providing protein, calcium, magnesium, potassium, and iron. I have shared this with people who do not think they care for rice pudding and they always love it. I think it is perfect as is. I usually put cinnamon on my rice pudding, but this one's simple taste is delicious and let's the rice shine through, so I often eat it plain. Great fro breakfast, and can easily be made ahead, providing several breakfasts. I love this cold. Thank you!

I pretty much followed the recipe as written I did use short grain rice, used 1% milk and I soaked the raisins in a bit of dark rum before adding.  Very good results and I will make again.  Thanks.
UPDATE:  After the pudding sat for a while, it thickened up considerably.  Next time I will use less rice or more milk.  Otherwise it tasted great. SECOND UPDATE :  I cooked the rice in my rice cooker then made this again with more milk (I also added the leftover rum from the raisins) and, once again success!  Love this recipe - not bland at all.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I make this recipe frequently , as it is a family favorite, especially of my elderly father, whom I love to spoil. He pronounced it even better than his mother's, which is unheard of.
So easy to make and always turns out perfectly. I add my craisins at the beginning of cooking the pudding, along with vanilla beans, freshly grated nutmeg , and cinnamon. I've also made it with sushi rice or leftover rice from ordering Chinese food.
One comment I would like to make is that I feel the top negative review should be removed as it is not a valid comment, but an error on the part of the cook.. Bon Appetite lists substituting brown rice for white as #2 in it's article " The 6 Most Common Mistakes in Making Rice" You have to add more water( 1/4 - 1/2 cup per cup of rice) , so of course the recipe will not turn out! Thoroughly beating the egg into the remaining milk while you cook the rice will bring the eggs to room temperature and avoid any clumps of cooked egg in the final product.  Recipe doubles well. Great  recipe! Thank you!

text:
I made this rice pudding yesterday (with Jasmine rice) and one thing that I noticed was different than what the recipe states is that after adding the milk to the rice, it only took 8 minutes for my rice pudding to gain the thickness/consistency I wanted. I thought it was strange that the directions say 15-20 minutes so I let it cook for 2 more minutes but at that point it started losing it's creaminess so I decided to go to the next part of the directions.
Also, I substituted brown sugar for white sugar, added cinnamon at the end and also added dried cranberries to it at the same time as the raisins. It turned out amazing!
Overall a great recipe!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Excellent recipe!  I make it with skim milk and it is still rich and creamy.   One person here didn't like the result, but she used brown rice, which has an entirely different texture profile, and I suggest turning down the heat before adding the milk/egg mixture, and you must stir constantly those last couple of minuted to avoid any stray egg bits!  I beat the egg with the remaining milk to help guard against "scrambling" the egg.

I cooked my rice in my multi-cooker, so I used a separate pan on the stove, but you can make this a one-pot task.

Terrific comfort food, so easy, and much more economical than the store bought versions.

text:
I had leftover rice so I decided to try this.  It is the first time I made rice pudding and it came out perfectly.  I actually used 1 cup whole milk and 1 cup half and half because it was all that I had.  I also increased the vanilla a bit  and mixed in a little nutmeg at the end.  As suggested in other posts, I added some of the thickened rice/milk mixture to the eggs first to temper them before adding the eggs to the pan.  This was definitely not low-cal, but I wanted good rice pudding so I didn't care.  It was so easy!  I will never buy rice pudding at the store again; this was so much better!

text:
This recipe was amazing! I substituted the regular milk for soy milk, and it was really spectacular. I also added a little bit of cinnamon into the pudding, I didn't use the raisins, I'm just not a huge fan of them. The trick to not making scrambled eggs when you add the eggs to the mixture is to 1) Make sure the heat is at medium, possibly a bit less. 2) KEEP STIRRING!!!
Whatever you do, don't stop stirring in the eggs until they are 100 percent mixed in. I used medium grain rice and it turned out great. This one is certainly a keeper!

text:
I have been searching for the right recipe for years, and finally found the one that is the closest to my childhood memories of the rice pudding my great aunt used to make.
I added the sugar to the egg in a separate bowl, then slowly added some of the hot mixture to it, stirring continuously.  I kept adding the hot mixture until the egg mix was warm.  Then I slowly added it to my rice mix, stirring gently.  No egg lumps.. just a lovely creamy consistence.

Display Name:

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Instead of using regular white rice, I used sweet/sticky rice.  I rinsed the sticky rice once and let it boil with the water rather than having the water boil alone.  I didn't use another pan.  I just scraped off all the cooked rice using a spatula and combined the ingredients called for.  The secret to not having eggs bunch up is to continuously  stir the rice while pouring the beaten egg.  I skipped the butter and poured a little heavy cream instead (depends on how creamy you want it), then stirred it for about 5 minutes.  No raisins.  That's it.  The taste was very close to Trader Joe's rice pudding.

userID:
16997468
Display Name:
mmmandee97
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0

madeRecipesCount:
1
favoritesCount:
2
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674141.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Before I made this recipe, I had cooked another one that turned out god-awful! After such a catastrophe, I came across this recipe and it turned out to be my saving grace....a little slice of Heaven! I cooked rice as suggested and added my salt there. When it came to the 1 1/2 cps of milk, I used half 1% and half evaporated milk. The evap milk gave the rice/milk mixture a custard-like taste. Per advice from others, I didn't add the sugar until there were 2 of the 15 mins left on the clock and I was pleased with the creamy consistency of the rice and milk. When it became time to add the sugar, I also added a little extra sugar. We like it sweet. I used evap milk in final 1/2 c, that I mixed with an egg, and some of the hot rice I was mixing on the stove. I sure didn't want to end up with a scrambled egg in my rice pudding. Finally I added 2 tbsps of  butter, 2/3 c of raisins, 3-4 tsps of vanilla, a dash of nutmeg, and a dash or two of cinnamon!! This was unbelievably delicious and friggin' easy to make!! Before the batch was even finished, my teens had me immediately make another one!! Simply put: It was the BOMB!

text:
Followed the recipe word by word and it was good, but had some strange patches to the cooking process. Had to add a sprinkle of cloves, nutmeg, and a teaspoon of cinnamon to give that warm flavor. Oh, some other things I did different was use regular ol' purple raisins, hold the egg since my pudding was already so thick and sticky, and brown sugar instead of white, just to get that umph flavor since my mom has dubbed herself a rice pudding connoisseur and this pudding was for her itchy sweet tooth. She gobbled it up, my dad said it seems to be missing something (then again it's hard to please him... He has high expectations, growing up with delicious homemade market Amish rice pudding) but overall was tasty. I myself did enjoy it, and recommend adding in those spices or at least some cinnamon. Three stars, would make again.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
When I was growing up, rice was an uncommon side dish and any leftovers were turned into cold rice pudding (not dissimilar to tapioca pudding) served for either breakfast on a hot day or dessert anytime. I totally missed out on fried rice back then! After college, I discovered kheer, an Indian rice pudding, typically served hot, warm or cold. Neither version I've ever had included raisins and I don't have any on hand so I skipped them, though I'm sure it's a delish add.  I also skipped the butter, though it probably added richness (+calories).  Anywho, I just made this recipe using leftover (frozen!) cooked rice and skipped the first step in the recipe, as a result. I used equal parts cooked rice & milk plus the sugar and brought it to a simmer. I added the rest of the milk and egg substitute (room temp), along with double (yeah, 1t!) the amount of vanilla, plus 1t of ground cardamom, ate it at room temp and it was delicious. It’s a perfect blend of my childhood memories and my love of exotic cuisines!

I omitted the raisins and followed the recipe. The pudding looks good, nice and creamy, the taste of the sauce is good, but when you bite into rice, it's bland. text:
Very thick and creamy, not watery in texture like other rice puddings. Something I did differently was omit the raisins (just didn't have them on hand), and I heated the egg with the last 1/2 cup milk in a small sauce pan. I didn't like the idea of adding a raw egg to a hot pot of rice and milk. While the rice/milk mix was thickening, I heated the egg with milk with some sugar for some extra sweetness. Turned out great!

text:
I followed the recipe excluding the raisins (since I'm not a huge fan), omitting the salt, and substituting Splenda for sugar (at the recommended amount). For my rice, I chose Jasmine (which already has a delicately sweet nutty smell and flavor). During the addition of the last 1/2 cup of milk, I whisked the egg and milk together, along with the splenda and stirred it into the pudding, continuing to stir for the next 2 minutes as suggested in the recipe. After my pudding cooled, and for my first serving, I folded in a little bit of homemade prepared whipped cream (I use Splenda and vanilla in mine) and swirled in some sugar free raspberry preserves. Frankly, any rice will work. You just have to make sure you cook it to the desired consistency first. The Jasmine Rice works very good with this recipe. The raspberry preserves adds a little bit of sweet/tart that contrasts nicely with the creaminess of the pudding. Love it, and will make it over an over again.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
Omg! Yummy! Just like my mom made. I omitted the raisins (cause they're gross), and used skim milk and jasmine rice. 

Helpful tips:
The trick is to cook the rice, empty the pot and clean it, then measure 1 1/2 cups of cooked rice (smash it down into the cup measure) and add it to the cleaned pot. (You will probably have some extra rice let over.)

To avoid cooked egg bits, pour the remaining milk into a bowl with the egg. Let it come to room temp or close to it. When it comes time to add the egg/milk, scoop some of the already cooked rice pudding into the milk/egg bowl and stir. This will help warm up the egg so it doesn't cook the second it hits the rice pudding. Then add the mixture to the pot. Cook a few more minutes and remove from heat. Let it sit for a while to thicken.

Display Name:
Blondiemom

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674151.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have made this rice pudding a couple dozen times now. The first time I made it with risotto which was lovely and creamy. Most times, however, I use leftover rice from Chinese takeout with excellent results. First, I put the rice in a large pan and flatten out the rice, getting out all the lumps. Then I add the milk (non-fat, low fat, whole, 1/2 & 1/2, lactaid,whatever is in the fridge). After the milk has warmed, I add the sugar and some cinnamon & nutmeg. Cook over med. low heat. Then after the mixture has thickened, I add a tempered egg (very important so that you don't get scrambled eggs in your pudding; simply pour about 1/2 cup hot mixture very slowly into the beaten eggs whisking constantly). Then pour the egg mixture back into the pudding and add  milk & raisins. Let cook for a couple minutes over low heat to finish cooking the eggs. Remove from heat and add vanilla and  butter. Don't be afraid of the egg tempering. This is a great recipe and can be modified easily to your tastes.

text:
I had a lot of leftover white rice from Chinese dinners we had ordered in the past. So I decided last night to make this recipe to surprise my family with a dessert tonight. Since my rice was already cooked, I used 1 1/2 cups. Other than that, I followed the recipe exactly. 

One reviewer commented that the egg added at the end started to cook before it mixed into the mixture. It's likely that she added the egg before the last 1/2 cup of milk, and the mixture was too hot. If the milk is added before the egg, the mixture is cooled enough that the egg mixes in fine. 

At any rate, this rice pudding recipe was wonderful, and my family loved it. After I poured it into the container to refrigerate it, I sprinkled it with cinnamon.  This has become my go-to recipe for rice pudding. I wouldn't change one single thing in the recipe.

text:
I was looking for a home made and delicious rice pudding recipe. I made this just as the recipe says, no changes. I tasted the rice when I first added the milk and it was thoroughly cooked and had good texture. I added the sugar a few minutes later when it was thickened up and the taste at that point was really good, what I would expect rice pudding to taste like.  I wanted to just stop at that point but there are so many rave reviews and I decided to just finish the dish like it says, with the beaten egg and remainder of the milk. I thought it sounded strange to put egg in but did it anyway and it made the rice pudding less flavorful, a strange texture, and I honestly thought it was ruined at that point. I wish I left the egg out and eaten it without it. It would have been a 5 star dish for me then. But the way it is, with the egg, it's two stars. Also my rice burned a bitter layer on the bottom of the pot and it gave that flavor to some of the rice. All in all, I will definitely leave the egg out next time.

text:
I used parboiled long grain rice and cooked it per instruction about 20 minutes on low. (it's usually 1:2 with water). 
I didn't have sugar so I used honey.
dash of nutmeg, def used the vanilla. Salt of course.
*someone mentioned be careful not to add sugar(honey) until after you cook rice, so I listened.
when I added the milk mixture, I checked it frequently and i needed a little more milk to keep it nice and creamy.
cooked, simmered and stirred freq for about 18 minutes.
*When I added the rest of the milk, I microwaved it first for 45 seconds to make it hot, then added the butter and used a whipper to beat the egg into the mixture. (this way it won't turn out like a scrambled egg.)AFTER this was blended, I poured into the pot. (I only used one pot.)
cooked about 3-4 minutes more. stirred it up, let it set. 
added cinnamon to taste.
INCREDIBLE (and I didn't even have any raisins to use.)

None
text:
Made this recipe with my 4 y/o daughter. It came out delicious! We added some extra raisins, as per her request. I also added some cinnamon. Would definitely make again. Reviews complaining of egg  chunks in their mixture is a result of not adding the egg properly.  You are basically scrambling your eggs  You have to temper your eggs first. Add all milk required at once. When you are ready to add eggs, Beat the eggs in a small bowl and then take a 1/2 cup of hot liquid out of the pot. Mix them together in the separate bowl then slowly add that mixture back into your pot.  It will turn out great!

country:
None
text:
I have been making this rice pudding for over a year now because it is, by far, my favorite recipe.  The proportions of rice to milk seem just right, and the addition of the butter gives it a more complex, luxurious flavor. It does seem to me to speed up the thickening process by waiting to add the sugar in at the very end, when you add the butter.  For those of you who think making homemade rice pudding isn't worth the time, store bought rice pudding has nothing on this one.  In fact, they shouldn't even be uttered in the same sentence.

text:
Quick, easy and delicious!  I used left-over rice, so that really cut down on the preparation time.  To prevent the chunks of egg one person mentioned, stir a little of the hot rice mixture into the egg; then add the egg to the hot mixture.   I also added cinnamon and a little nutmeg.   My family loved it.

First of all, it's always best to use short grain on any rice pudding recipe in so that it is creamier. Very delicious and simple.

text:
This is SO easy to make!  It's a perfect recipe for this wonderful dessert.  I made only one change:  I used regular dark raisins, since I do not like the golden ones, and I used about a half a cup of them.  I think it's too much to put the full amount in.  Don't forget to add nutmeg (my choice) or cinnamon near the end.  It does need this little kicker, and the recipe calls for it!  Oh, and you're hard put to get 4 servings--maybe 2--it's just too good!

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
Love this recipe and have used it several times.  Today, however, i made a few changes involving a number of items I got from Trader Joe's.  First, used organic basmati rice, which works really well! I cooked the rice in coconut milk which helps to remove carbs from the rice and gives it a great texture, and I continue to just keep the rice in the coconut milk, adding some 1% milk for the rest of the preparation.  I use mostly Splenda, but use about 2 tbsp of the TJ organic maple sugar to complete the 1/3 c. Instead of raisins (no fans in the house), I used the honey roasted sliced almonds for a little crunch. And instead of vanilla extract, I use the Trader Joe's pure bourbon vanilla extract.  But the finishing touch (besides a touch of clove) is that instead of cinnamon, I used the Trader Joe's Matcha Green Tea Latte mix.  I love anything with green tea.  Using about 1-2 tbsp of the mix right before adding the egg works perfectly, and boy did it taste good!

userID:
15691630
Display Name:
Alissa De Los Reyes
isPro:
False
followersCount:
6

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2241439.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Easy to make, turned out great! I doubled the recipe, since I'm addicted to rice pudding! Be careful to measure out your cooked rice- yields of different types of rice vary once cooked! I used 3 cups Calrose medium-grain rice. I simmered the cooked rice in the same pan with 2 cups whole milk, plus 1/2 cup evaporated milk and 1/2 cup condensed milk. I tempered 2 eggs in a bowl with the hot rice milk from the pan, along with another 1/2 cup of evaporated milk & 1/2 cup condensed milk, whisked it all together then added it to the rice mixture. Since the condensed milk is sweet, I cut the sugar in 1/2. I used the salt, butter, and vanilla as instructed, and added cinnamon, nutmeg, and allspice to taste. It turned out very creamy, full of flavor, and is good hot or cold. No problems with it drying out or gumming up in the fridge. I really feel that using 3 types of milk made a big difference in the taste & texture. The only thing I'll do differently next time is when I cook the rice, I'll add a little more water & let it cook 30 min instead of 20- my rice is slightly more firm than I'd like- but that's probably because I doubled the recipe & didn't adjust the rice cooking accordingly. This recipe was super easy & even with my changes to it, I finished making it in 45 min with very little mess to clean up!

text:
Perfection!  I added organic vanilla powder along with extract.  I tripled the recipe so I would not have leftover rice. It was creamy and so good.  I soaked my raisins for about an hour in boiling water. I also only had long grain rice so I used it. Not sure why other reviewers said not to use it and what the complications would be. I cooked the rice in the rice cooker as indicated in the instructions for my particular rice cooker. This pudding is just perfect in my opinion. 5 stars all the way.

text:
I'm not a lover of rice pudding but this version has totally swayed me. My mom requested this when she was ill and I wanted to make a better version then the one she always tried to feed me (Betty Crocker I think). So recipe hunting I went and I actually really like this one. I used sushi rice to increase starchy creaminess, but rinsed it after it was cooked so it wasn't a pile of mush. Used whole milk, bourbon vanilla, and Demerara sugar- tastes amazing!!

text:
I was craving rice pudding and decided to give this one a try since it had such rave reviews. All of the reviews are well deserved!! I made it with medium grain rice, and followed the recipe exactly except for one little change. I used 1 3/4 cup low fat milk and 1/4 heavy cream. I added the cream because I had it on hand and I thought it would make it a little richer since I was using low fat milk. I topped with cinnamon and nutmeg. Thank you for sharing such a delicious recipe!!

text:
Very good, but for all the ones that had trouble with the egg..you have to temper the egg first, you can't just throw it in there,beat the egg in a small bowl,add some of the rice mixture into the egg..SLOWLY stirring constantly until the egg is warmed thru, this way you won't wind up with egg chunks in your pudding...

I thought it was very quick and easy with no baking needed. It also came out nice and creamy the way I like it. I didn't give it more stars because we thought it was way too sweet. I only added 1/4 cup of sugar and it was still too sweet. It was so sweet that I had to add more rice to make it edible for my husband. I wasn't able to add the raisins or nutmeg because that would have made it sweeter still. I also cooked the rice with butter and salt the way I always do instead of adding it at the end. Next time I will omit the sugar completely and then I think it well be a winner!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2501664.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Comfort food to the max! I used long grain brown rice, one large whole farm fresh egg, skim milk and unsalted butter. Lots of interesting texture with the chewy raisins and nutty flavored, long grain brown rice. If one desired another layer of texture, a few toasted walnuts would be great, but I love this just the way it is!  Thanks for the comfort of a rich and satisfying rice pudding! P.S. I find that 1/4c. is really quite enough of a serving for something this rich and sweet.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
I used non-GMO Arborio rice by Lundberg. It was outstanding! Cooked in my Dutch oven, kept an even temp.  I doubled the recipe, a risk on a first time recipe, glad I did, my husband and daughter ate it all week for desert!! I saved the extras such as; Cinnamon, Nutmeg and Golden Raisins so they could put their own in later.  I let the Dutch oven cool for 15 minutes before adding the extra milk, eggs and Vanilla, so the eggs wouldn't curdle.  With winter coming soon to these parts I will definitely be making this again.  As a kid growing up in England we poured Black Treacle over rice pudding, in this beautiful country I think Maple syrup might be nice.  Enjoy.

text:
Just finished preparing this recipe(it's in the fridge cooling off now). At first taste this is the recipe I've been looking for. Easy made with ingredients I had on hand. Yes I just happened to have short grain rice left over from my sushi experiment last week. The only changes I had to make...after adding milk sugar and salt medium heat was way too high. I let it boil then turned it down to low to simmer for just under 15 minutes. Also kept at medium low after addition of milk and egg. I believe consistency was perfect and I'm hoping it will be so after it's chilled. Keeping my fingers crossed.

Creamy comfort food. Especially satisfying served with milk.   Sugar: 1/4 c vs 1/3. Nutmeg or allspice: 1/2 tsp during 2nd phase of cooking. Omit the butter. Using 1/4 cup sour cream or yoghurt  skyrockets the flavour.  Also:  To forget the cinnamon is very wrong.

text:
I browsed several recipes before stopping on this one. Thanks to all the reviews below, I trusted it enough to make a triple amount.
I agree with one of them, to add sugar when rice is nicely cooked and to add the rice mixture (I used 4 ladles) to milk/egg mixture, stir it and then bring it all back to the pot and cook it for another 1-2min.  Then I added the freshly greater nutmeg, placed raisins on the bottom of cups, added the rice mixture, topped it with cinnamon and few more raisins... now they're cooling before going to the fridge! Thank you!!!

This was a really great basic recipe!!! It is a definite winner. You can always tweak it to your tastes.....in my case, no raisins,a touch sweeter and a little nutmeg.  I was a little concerned about scrambling the egg when I added it,but i just made sure to have it at room temperature and I beat it into the last 1/2 cup of milk which was also at room temperature. I added it gradually while stirring and had no problems at all.  I always wanted to make a really nice and creamy rice pudding and this was the recipe that did it! Awesome!!!

text:
Honestly, I had no idea what I was doing. I had extra cooked rice from supper and started looking for recipes to use it up. I dumped the sugar and milk in the pan the rice was still sitting in & mixed it up and set it on a medium burner. Then I got busy doing other things in the kitchen, so stirred it occasionally. About the time it started to look "creamy" to me, I started reading the other reviews. I started getting nervous that mine wasn't going to work out. I beat the egg and mixed with the remaining milk and dumped it in my creamy mixture on the stove and hoped for the best. This time I stood by and stirred constantly until it looked pudding consistency. I then removed from heat and put in butter. I don't normally make rice pudding, nor have much experience with it (obviously!) but I think it turned out delicious! I also sprinkled cinnamon over individual helpings.  Long story short: good recipe for beginners/never-made-befores!

None
country:
None
text:
Great recipe.

Two complaints (and they aren't huge complaints--I still follow this recipe, with few modifications, every time I make rice pudding):

1) Shocked there isn't an instruction to wash the rice before use. 

2) If you cook it for as long as this recipe says, it tends to get very thick--so thick it turns into more of a Thai coconut sticky rice! 

Tip: shave two minutes off the cooking time for a better consistency. Also, wash your rice!

userID:

Display Name:
JadesFire
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674161.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made this recipe spontaneously last night. I used Basmati rice (long grain) because that's what we had on hand. I also used coconut sugar instead of white sugar. My egg turned the whole thing really yellow and then the coconut sugar turned the whole thing a brown yellow so it didn't look appetizing at all, but it was still really tasty. I beat the egg into the remaining 1/2 cup milk and then ended up tempering the egg with some of the hot rice before adding the mixture to the rice and there were no egg chunks. Perfect recipe. Save yourself the blood sugar spike, though, and ignore anyone trying to tell you to use skim milk. The whole milk will provide some cushioning for the sugars in the dish so that you don't have a blood sugar spike.

region:
None
country:
None
text:
The only reason I made this was because I had leftover rice from Chinese food a few days before.  The rice was almost rock hard in its original container, so I heated up some water to soften the rice and drained the excess water out. Measured out 1 1/2 cups of rice and started from there.  I am gluten-intolerant, so rice is a big part of my diet, but I had never before thought of making rice pudding. I had all the ingredients, so I thought, "why not?"  My mom made it when I was a kid, but I couldn't remember if I liked it or not. In fact, as this was cooking, I wondered if it was going to be a waste of time and ingredients, because it wasn't looking all that great. I followed the recipe to a "t", except for the rice cooking directions. I was hesitant to take my first bite, but YUM! I'm eating it hot out of the pan right now! I don't think it has as creamy of a texture as it could be, maybe due to the rice I used and how stale it was when I used it, but it is still delicious, and healthy! The only thing I added was a dash of cinnamon. Besides that, followed it exactly.  Will make again. The only reason I gave it just 4 stars is because of the texture, but if I make it again with fresh rice, it will probably 5-star worthy. Thanks for the recipe!

text:
Really yummy and so easy!  I've never made rice pudding before and was skeptical, but it came out great.  I tempered the egg as other reviewers had suggested and also I cooked my raisins with the rice/milk from the start to make them nice and soft.  Additionally, instead of sugar I used 1 tablespoon of agave sweetener instead of sugar.  I used mostly non-fat milk with a splash of heavy cream.  Delicious :)

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
If i could give this ten stars i definately would. I will never buy rice pudding again when i get a craving for it. I did a few things different with the recipe. I used medium grain rice. First I washed the rice and drained all of the water off prior to adding it to the boiling water(I dont like my rice too starchy). I followed some instructions from other reviews. I added some of the liquid from the second boil to my milk and egg and let it set for a minute or so before slowly adding it into the pot, added the raisins(used dark raisins because it was all i had) five minutes before it being done and added a couple of dashes of nutmeg and cinnamon to the pudding. I am simply amazed at how easy this was to make and how delicious it turned out!! My 2.5 year old daughter really loved it too. I  will be making  this again in the future!

text:
This was so good I actually ate the entire thing myself. In one sitting. Yes, you read that right. I used super cheap long grain rice (that was what I had), 2% milk, cane sugar (not sure if it's the same as white sugar, it wasn't white), fresh ground sea salt and omitted the raisins. I only had it over med-high heat for a max of 10 minutes and it got super thick, I think my stove might run a little hot though. I think next time I'm going to try cutting the sugar down some and adding brandy. For some reason it just seems that brandy would go really well with this recipe so why not just add it in? Besides, it adds to the holiday flair, right?

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is absolutely amazing!!  At last, a great, easy rice pudding recipe with awesome results!!  For some reason, I've never been able to make rice pudding with the proper consistency or flavor before...all other recipes I've tried have bombed.  But this one is great...the only thing I did differently is used leftover basmati rice and then made half of the milk canned coconut milk instead.  This meant you had to simmer the rice and milk mixture for slightly longer, but it turned out delicious!  The secret is just to make sure that you really do cook the mixture until it starts to thicken...adding the butter at the end makes it especially flavorful and rich!  Definitely a keeper!  Glad I doubled this recipe because it's gonna be gone soon!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was delicious, all my family loved it.  The only changes I made was to use minute rice.  I cooked the rice as directed on the box, adding the salt in the boiling water, and 4 minutes before the water was fully absorbed by the rice, I added the sugar and stirred.  I then continued cooking (in the same pot) and added the milk as directed in the recipe. Since I doubled the recipe it took a little longer; about 25 to 30 minutes to thicken appropriately. When the rice was thickened, I took a few tablespoons and added it to the remaining milk and eggs as mentioned in previous reviews. I definitely would make this recipe again, it's very close to my mother's which is the best.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Best rice pudding I've ever had! I doubled the recipe. Rice was the usual long grain white (used store brand). Had zero problems. Used whole milk and half-and-half mixture. Next time I'll try skim with half-and-half. Came out super thick even after the last cup was added at the end. But thick is good! Increased the vanilla (which was whisked into the milk/egg mixture) by 1/2 tsp. Skipped the butter altogether (I was so into stirring and watching the rice pudding cooking I really forgot about it). Didn't add the raisins or cinnamon. I just mix those into individual servings if wanted. Mom had hers with milk mixed in like she grew up on. Said it was the best she's ever tasted! She's 88 and that's good enough for me. My husband had some as soon as it cooled off a little and loved it too!

text:
This is indeed, the best rice pudding recipe on this site.  I kept the recipe the same but changed the order of cooking.  

Of course, I used short-grained rice.  To me, that's the best rice for rice pudding.  I added the salt and sugar in the water while cooking the rice and let it all absorb into it.  Once all the water was absorbed, I stirred in the butter into the hot rice.  When it came to the part to stir in the milk and egg, first I added a little bit of cooked rice into the blend and let it take to the temperature change, then slowly poured it into the pot.

The only real change I made was the milk.  I'm lactose intolerant, so I used lactose free milk.

I also saw a pretty interesting pumpkin rice pudding recipe on this site.  Since I'm very happy with this recipe, I intend to use this recipe as a rice pudding base.  I'm going to see how I can combine the 2 and give birth to a new pumpkin rice pudding recipe.

Thank you for this treasure of a recipe!!

text:
NOTE: There are 2 types of Rice Pudding: A southern one, which is usually baked and comes out dryer. The Northern one, which is what this recipe is. So if you are looking for a dryer one need to find different recipe. Made this last night. Everyone loved it, did not change anything except I started out using 1 cup of the milk instead of the 1 1/2 cups like recipe stated. Add the final cup at the end. Turned out great!! Will be making this again. Will have to double recipe next time because everyone was asking for seconds and with a family of 5 recipe was just right for everyone to have 1 serving.

text:
I had never made rice pudding before and found this pretty easy.  I did temper the egg mixture with some of the hot pudding to make sure the eggs didn't scramble.  I also used long grain rice but would maybe switch to a shorter grain next time because I prefer it cold, it seemed more dense with the long grain.  I also added cinnamon and nutmeg to the pudding instead of just sprinkling it on top.  I omitted the raisins just because I didn't have any.  My husband and I ate it all within 24 hours!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I beat the egg together with some of the reserved milk before adding it to the cooked rice mixture - if you're worried about your egg cooking in lumps, this kind of step might help. I omitted the raisins simply because I didn't have any on hand, but next time I'll use them. I seasoned with a tiny bit of nutmeg and cinnamon - delicious. I was really impressed with the creaminess of this recipe and was happy that it didn't taste too "eggy." 5 stars!

Using brown rice (when this recipe clearly calls for white) is a little ridiculous. They are very different grains. Besides, if you're substituting for health ... ain't going to do much good given all the milk/butter/sugar in here anyway. Might as well try a different dessert.

text:
I saw the note about this recipe being too sweet. I agree.  However, instead of cutting back on the sugar, I cut out the raisins (actually didn't have any the first time I made this). Once it was totally cooled, I sliced strawberries on top.  The tartness of the strawberries cut the sweetness of the pudding.  Tasted great!  Saw the note about the clumping eggs.  Temper the eggs with the warm rice mixture before adding the eggs entirely into the pudding.  Thanks!

text:
This is a great base but if you are looking for a more sweeter taste with more flavor add 1 tbsp dark brown sugar and condensed milk to the 2nd step along with 1/2 cup extra milk. Beat the remaing 1/2 cup milk and egg together in small bowl before adding it slowly in the next step. Add a little more raisins 2 tbsp of butter and double the vanilla. And dont be shy with the cinnamon! You will love it :)

text:
My daughter and I loved it!  To us, it tasted just like the store bought rice pudding in the ridiculously small teaser containers. The only thing I did differently was I've never been able to cook successful rice on the stove; so I microwaved 1 cup rice to 2 cups water 20 minutes, perfect rice. And I stirred in the egg/milk mixture to the rice in a cold pot bringing it to a simmer so there would be no chance of the egg cooking and ruining the pudding.  This really made our mouth happy!

Display Name:
genie

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674152.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was easy and is delicious! I used Calrose rice (short grain variety) and it made for a creamy pudding.  I also used whole milk to ensure it was satisfying and rich.  A tip, after adding the last 1/2 c of milk, add some of the hot rice and milk mixture to your beaten egg in a bowl (temper the egg) to avoid getting scrambled eggs.  Then stir it all in to the saucepan w your pudding.  I added a couple shakes of cinnamon and a pinch or orange zest as well.  I added a few crushed saffron threads to the milk as the rice and milk were cooking, gave it a nice color and subtle delicate flavor and I sautéed my golden raisins in the butter on a skillet before adding them to my pudding.  It made them tasty!  Just be sure to scrape the melted butter w your spatula into the pudding.  OMG! Flavorgasm, enjoying eating it right now.  If you want to use a long grain rice like basmati, make an Indian rice pudding instead.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2012-12-28T19:59:37.037
helpfulCount:

userID:
9124046
Display Name:
tisla White
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
1
favoritesCount:
48
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674154.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
So this is second time trying this recipe. The first time I had some problems when I tried to double the recipe and didn't do it correctly. This time I followed the recipe as written. I used whole milk, medium grained rice, cinnamon stick and vanilla bean. What I learned from the first time is I cooked it too long. I prefer my pudding to be custardy. The first time, I cooked it till it was nice and thick, however, when it cooled down, it was a little harder than I liked. This  time, I cooked it till it started to thicken, which was shorter an 15 min. Maybe because I used whole milk. Either way, the consistency was better the second time. Also, I used the egg yolk instead of the whole egg because I learned that from somewhere. Don't remember where. The taste is great.  Some reviews stated it was too sweet, however, I noticed that after it cooled down, the sweetness was not as strong. Oh, i used condensed milk to help sweetened it the first time, 
which made it really creamy. So now the second time around,  the consistency is better and the taste is dee-lish.  I would definitely use this recipe again.

country:
None
text:
The directions for this recipe are poor.  For those people who don't know, you need to explain that when they add the egg and milk at the end, they need to beat the hot mixture very fast and add the milk and egg slowly, otherwise the egg will curdle - as happened in the case of one reviewer.  I also add some of the hot mixture to the egg and milk to heat them up slightly and further reduce the chance of curdling.  Inexperienced cooks don't know to do this.  I made this recipe with coconut milk because my daughter cannot have milk products and added 1/2 tsp cinnamon and 1/2 tsp nutmeg to spice it up a bit.  The coconut milk worked well.

text:
this is great!  for those who complain about the chunks of egg, just keep stirring the mixture vigorously the whole two minutes.  if you stir too gently then you will get chunks.  i was coming across the same problem.  also, i used forbidden black rice so there's at least a small amount of nutrition in it. it turned out amazing.  i never need to buy from the store again, yay!

text:
I have never made rice pudding before, but what I have had, had hard bits from badly cooked rice. I used some rice I had already cooked, and didn't add the salt. It was fantastic! The ingredient amounts are very forgiving. I put kinda 1.5 cups of rice and 2 cups of milk. I tasted the rice/milk and added a little extra sugar, and I don't know if it is needed for sure, but I tempered the eggs with a little of the rice mixture before I added it to the pan. Highly recommended.

text:
Yum! Doubled the recipe and used 1 quart of half and half in place of the milk. For a quick stovetop rice pudding, this is pretty darn good. I use cold leftover rice and just start at step 2. I temper the eggs by mixing in a bit of the hot mixture to warm them before I add them to the pan. (So I don't scramble them.) Sprinkle with cinnamon and nutmeg (or pumpkin pie spice) at the end. This is so quick that I am sure I'll do it again.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674167.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This rice pudding is better than my grandma used to make!  Super easy and tastes delicious!  After making it as directed I have made a few changes based on other reviews as well as personal preference.  When boiling the water I add the butter and salt, once the rice is cooked, I continue to use the same pot.  In a seperate bowl I beat the egg and sugar together (and I use brown sugar instead of white) then add the add'l 1/2 c. of milk.  I have tried adding warm mixture to bowl as well as just adding the egg mixture to the pot, I haven't had any problems with the egg cooking by just adding it into the pot (I just slowly pour it in and stir at the same time).  I also use 1 cup of dark raisins (personal preference).  My husband likes this so much I now make it twice a week to send him in his lunch everyday, he enjoys it both hot or cold.

I just love it!!! Great recipe!
My only variations: added salt to the boiling water, mixed the egg with the 1/2 cup of milk and the vanilla and then added it a bit at the time to the pan while stirring until all of it was incorporated.  Also skipped the butter and added a bit of coconut.

This recipe is so much like my grandmother's, I couldn't help but to love it when I made it.  It hs that old time flavor that brought back memories of when I was a little girl helping mom make this pudding.

Only thing I did different was I added the vanilla in while the custard was cooking to get more flavor from into the dish itself and used slightly less butter.

This has become a great dessert and a great breakfast when there's not much else to make.  I always have rice, eggs, and milk so this has become a staple.

userID:
6619293
Display Name:
BrendaJ
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0

4
favoritesCount:
78

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614256.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
AMAZING! I love rice pudding, and this is the best I have ever had! I did change it a little, by increasing the sugar to 1/2 cup and skipping the raisins.  I also cooked the rice in my rice cooker instead of on the stove, then just started out with the warm rice from there.  I used Jasmine rice, and it came out wonderfully.  I would recommend stirring constantly during the entire cooking time, as it seems it could burn or scald easily.  After the egg and milk are added, it is worth a few extra minutes on the heat stirring constantly for thicker, creamier results. Pour into serving dishes immediately and let cool for a few minutes before serving warm, with whipped topping, if desired. Enjoy!

5
