Despite all the warnings I used long grain rice (it's all i had). I added an extra 1/2 cup of water to the raw rice and cooked it for an extra 8 or so minutes, till it was mush. I haven't tried making this with a shorter grain, but thought the end result was OUTSTANDING with the long grain! This was delicious and very reminiscent of Christmas for us. The recipe made just enough for my DH and our 2 kids (4&2yrs). It does not make very much and I find myself wanting more....*sigh* although it's probably a good thing it made no more.

I am an experienced cook, but today I was tired and neglected to read the recipe thoroughly.   I also ended up not having enough cooked rice so I filled in with instant rice.    Worked like a charm.    I didn't beat the egg separately, I beat it in the pan and dumped everything else in with it.    I thought Oh! Oh!   Now I'm in trouble.  

 I just cooked everything all at once and it turned out super, super good.     I added about 3/4 tsp. cinnamon.    You can bet I will make this again.

text:
This was awesome! I made sure to temper the egg with a bit of the hot milk mixture, which helped the egg not clump up. I used 1% milk for the first 1 1/2C of milk, then substituted light coconut milk for the last 1/2C of milk. I also added about 1/4C of shredded coconut when the raisins were added. Soooo good!!

text:
This delivered way more than I expected.  Seemed too simple to be of mention but have to say the result blew me away.  I made a few changes just to make my life more difficult:  Used 1/4 cup white sugar and 2 Tbsp dark brown sugar.  Heated the milk, sugars and salt until fully dissolved and then added hot cooked rice.  I also tempered the egg before incorporating (out of habit) and I think that really helped the consistency.  Finished with vanilla and cinnamon.  Omitted the raisins and subbed some hot apple slivers cooked in brown sugar and butter.  Absolutely loved the base recipe.  Thanks for this!

text:
I love this site since you get to read the reviews of the people who actually tried the recipe. Reading their thoughts helped me make this pudding a five-star winner in my house. I used Arborio Rice and cooked it with the salt, as it is hard to season grains after they are cooked. I used slightly more sugar as well; that is our family's preference. Top this off with a sprinkling of cinnamon sugar and nutmeg and it doesn't last more than one night in our house! Thanks SO much Erica G. for sharing this keeper!

userID:
3783843
Display Name:
Loidys
isPro:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674138.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I'm Lactose intolerant.  So I used Vanilla Soymilk instead of regular milk.  It came out great!  Although, I did reduce the sugar to 1/4 cup because the soymilk is already very sweet.  I also reduced the vanilla to 1/4 teaspoon because the soymilk already tastes like vanilla.  I also put a stick of cinnamon while it cooked with the milk and the sugar and the salt.  I actually tried the recipe twice and succeeded on the 2nd try.  The first time I made two fatal mistakes.  The first one being that the rice was not cooked throughly and it was too hard for a pudding consistency.  So make sure you cook the rice enough so that its tender.  The other was that I let the rice cook with the milk too long and it was WAY too thick.  I believe the reason you have to use two pots is because you don't want the rice that gets a little crunchy on the bottom of the pot to be a part of the pudding.  It's an easy recipe with a delicious outcome!  Enjoy!
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:

text:
This was my first time cooking rice pudding. I liked this recipe because it didn't require baking it in the oven. Delicious! will DEFINITELY be using this recipe again, all my family members keep asking for it!

text:
I had some left over cooked Jasmine rice and was craving a quick and easy rice pudding. This recipe is very quick and delicious. I waited to add the sugar until I added the second part of the milk and beaten egg then I stirred on low for about 10 minutes more instead of only 2 min like the original recipe calls for. It turned out so creamy and rich. I substituted cinnamon since I didnt have any nutmeg on hand. 5 stars for sure. I will be making this again when the weather cools down.

text:
I made a small change--substituted about 3/4 of a cup of coconut milk leftover from a pie for an equal amount of the regular milk.  It cooked up just fine but with an interesting hint of coconut :)  I used short grain rice and the cook times shown were too long, so make sure to watch well if you use it too!  I gave it 4 stars because next time I would put a little more salt to play up the flavors more or follow the other reviewers advice to cook the rice in salted water.  I wouldn't call it the best rice pudding but it is a quick and easy dessert that comes together from items I have in my cupboard, so it's a keeper for me!

country:
None
text:
This is my go-to recipe for rice pudding. It has never NOT turned out. I have made it exactly as written and it turns out delicious. I have also tweaked it a little. We use fat-free milk at our house, so that is what I have on hand. It can make the pudding a bit anemic and not set up as much as I like(but still great). I started using half fat-free milk and half evaporated milk. It definitely gives it a smoother, richer texture and taste. Before I tried this recipe, I tried about 10 different rice pudding recipes. This is fool-proof and I will never have to try another rice pudding recipe again.

This was super simple to make. I used 1% milk, and it still came out very rich. pianoman1976

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/407048.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Such a great recipe to augment and make healthy without loosing and taste!  Substitute brown rice for the white rice.  Substitute 8 tsp xylitol and 1/8-1/4 tsp pure stevia extract (Kal brand is by far the best, and the only brand I will use) for the sugar.  Use 1% milk  Substitute 1/4 cup egg white (cage free! - Trader Joe's) for regular egg.  Substitute Smart Balance Light or Brummell & Brown for the butter.  The cooking time for brown rice will take twice as long.  Make sure the rice is cooked really well.  Xylitol and stevia are non-chemical natural sweeteners.  Far better for you than Splenda and the others.

I just made this with brown basmati rice!  Amazing. Has the texture of barley or oatmeal. text:
I'm not a big rice pudding fan, but this is a good one!  I used brown jasmine rice and cooked it about 5 minutes longer - just until the water was absorbed.  I also added the salt and butter at the beginning instead of later.  No need for a second pan, just add the milk (skim) and sugar to the cooked rice.  I also used Craisins instead of raisins.  Finally I sprinkled the top with cinnamon sugar.  The brown rice makes for a slightly chewier texture, but a MUCH healthier rice pudding.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/357334.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Awesome recipe ! I have made this rice pudding 3 times now. The first time I made this recipe was the first time I'd ever made any rice pudding. After adding the egg and milk mixture at the end, I cooked it until it was a thick, creamy consistency (the consistency I thought it would stay at). What I didn't know was that it continues to thicken after you stop cooking ! It turned out like oatmeal once cooled. The next two times I made it I added the egg and milk mixture to the rice mixture and only cooked it for 2 minutes and shut it off immediately! It thickened to the perfect consistency during the cooling stage. I made this recipe for the third time today, however again it was a little too thick after cooling for about 15 minutes. I added a bit of milk and sugar to thin it out and it turned out great !

text:
best rice pudding I ever made! make sure to use short grain rice for the creamiest texture. I use 1 cup raw rice and 1 can of evaporated milk for the 1 1/2 cups of milk, I added cinnamon and nutmeg as well. I temper the egg as well by adding some of the hot rice mixture into it, whisking it until warm then adding to the pot, with the pot off the heat.

text:
Nice and creamy! I had to make a few substitutions though.  I used brown rice because I didn't have any white rice and I added the salt to the rice as it was simmering.  I also used almond milk because I'm sensitive to dairy, but it was not thickening as it should so i had to add a tablespoon of flour (would have used cornstarch if I had it). I also decided to use evaporated skim milk for the last half cup because it wasn't creamy enough. I also traded out the sugar for splenda.  I didn't have any raisins to add but it was still good. I also added cinnamon, nutmeg, and extra vanilla to try and mask the flavor of the brown rice. Very good recipe.  Next time I will use white rice and raisins though!

4784904
Display Name:
Anthony E Croucier
isPro:

followersCount:
1

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3078133.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Erica, thank you for the lead on this recipe. Being that I’m Cuban and that I’ve had the opportunity to have Arros con Leche from a child to adulthood, believe it or not, I wasn’t sure how to achieve the right consistency since I wanted to make it different. My mom and sister’s version is good, but a bit runny and too sweet. With your recipe, I was able to achieve a real rich consistency that really brought out the flavors.  Rice in a Cuban household is a staple, like is potato to Americans. Normally, we use leftover rice to start rice pudding, as rice pudding is considered move of an afterthought or a very inexpensive comforting desert…I on the other hand started with cooking my medium grain rice in my rice cooker. I made about two cups of rice and I did salt it (two table-spoons) and as well added about (two table-spoons) of canola oil. After my rice was ready, (wet and fluffy) I transferred the rice to a pot, added about two cups of 2 percent organic milk and 2 cups of unprocessed sugar. String constantly, 5 minutes later I added the raisins and then added another half a cup of milk and the vanilla and one teaspood of cinnamon. Now having the right rich consistency, separately I whipped up one egg and added another third cup of milk to the egg…whipping to a milky substance, and then folding it into the rice pudding while still cooking. I did not use the butter, but frankly I just didn’t feel it needed it. Wow, what a finish! I loved it!  Thank you again! Tony

Super easy, even for someone who has never made rice pudding and doesn't know how it's supposed to look, taste or smell. text:
Really good recipe, here's my tweaks: 1. Use Calrose (med-grain) rice, 2. Use 1 12-oz can no-fat condensed milk and 4oz no-fat regular milk, Smart Balance instead of butter. Egg optional -tastes better with egg but if you have issues with eggs then omitting it still produces a great result. Very easy, tasty, and healthy snack. Mix in some fresh organic blueberries just after you take off heat.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Just tried a variation of this recipe tonight using skim evaporated milk and doubling all quantities to serve my huge tribe. Used arborio rice and stayed stirring the recipe almost constantly to prevent potential for sticking. Result was a thick custardy vanilla rice delight that was devoured in a flash - heated last addition of milk and the eggs to near simmer point before adding to main rice content to prevent egg scrambling and after draining rice reused the same larger pot. Suspect would be almost as good with regular skim milk cooked slightly longer - will cut down on sugar when making it next as the plump sultanas I used in place of raisins added a beautiful sweetness of their own (added sultanas at point of adding milk as I like them to be really plump). A very good recipe as is or for someone who has made this before a great one to tweak to your personal preference.

text:
Made this today for the first time, but with a few changes.   I used med. gr sushi rice for the higher starch content, omitted the egg, salt, butter and a 1/2 cup of milk.  I also added a dash of pumpkin pie seasoning and cinnamon during the cooking.   Pudding came out FANTASTIC! Very smooth and creamy. Very quick and easy.   ....as a word of caution, it's best to stir constantly as the mixture will reach a boil and scald very quickly even on low heat.

Tasty basic recipe that is easy to make. This is a good base recipe for experimenting. If you are using skim milk like me, reduce the cooking time or the rice will stick to the bottom of the pan.  I added chopped dried cherries and crushed almonds.  The egg and butter is optional, but probably makes it more tasty.

text:
This is the best rice pudding I've ever made. I only had long grain brown rice in the house and didn't want to wait until I could get white rice. I doubled the batch and used skim milk. I too added some cornstarch to the milk mixture. First I cooked the rice, then mixed up the eggs/milk/sugar/spices.(I used cinnamon, nutmeg and vanilla) I decided to cook the milk until thick and then add to the rice, which worked quite well. Mmmm. It's yummy, creamy and I will make this recipe again!

text:
I don't like rice pudding but I really liked this pudding. My husband adores rice pudding and I been trying for 10 years to find a recipe he will like but he hates everything. He only wants to eat Kozy Shack. I followed the directions perfectly, I changed nothing except I left out the raisins and I doubled the recipe. I made this with medium grain rice because I believe using long grain rice was one of my down falls to all the failed recipes of the past.  My husband tasted it on Christmas Day during dessert time when we were all stuffed and cookied out. He said he wasn't crazy about it - the next night however he had some and liked it the consitensy but he did say he wished it were sweeter. He ate it again the following night so I am going to say he liked it or he would never eat it again. So I gave it 4 stars because for a non-rice pudding lover I liked this recipe and he liked it not loved it. and that was better than anything I tried in all our ten years together! Thank you I do think this is a good recipe.

None
text:
Very Good!  Having some left-over rice from dinner, I doubled this recipe and started at step 2 using 4 cups of cooked rice.  I used extra rice because I was using 2% milk and thought it would help to thicken it.  Also, I thought it would cut some of the sweetness.   After beating the eggs, I added them to the milk; then I slowly added the mixture to the pudding.  I topped each serving with cinnamon and served warm but it was just as good served cold.  Thank you Erica for sharing such a yummy recipe.

text:
Sorry, but this was not the recipe I thought it would be. There was not much flavor so I added cinnamon (1 tsp) and nutmeg (1/4 tsp). My family likes their rice pudding cold and when I let it sit in the fridge first before serving, it lost all of it's creamy texture as the rice soaked up any remaining liquid and it became less of a pudding an more like rice.....I must have done something wrong in the cooking. Will try and again with some modifications and re-review it! Thanks!

text:
This was so awesome. I loved it. I used some of the other reviewers tips. I tested the rice for tenderness before adding sugar. I used medium grain rice. I salted the water to cook the rice, and added butter in this step as well, instead of later. I also took some of the warm mixture and added it to the bowl with the milk and egg in it before adding it to the pot, to avoid the egg dropped effect as other reviewers have said.  I would like to know how to serve second day after it being in the fridge? It was not as creamy when I reheated, and was more lumpy. Any tricks would be appreciated.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Couldn't ask for a much easier recipe for rice pudding than this!  I was trying to make a healthier version so I used brown rice, skim milk, and used part white and part brown sugar.  It turned out great and better than you'd think with a brown rice.  I just made sure to cook the brown rice with a little extra water and cooked it until it was as tender as I wanted the final product, but it still soaks up some milk as well.  Per some other reviews, I also added the sugar later, and tempered the egg mixture with the cooking pudding.  I added a dash of nutmeg and cinnamon, and regular and golden raisins.  Wonderful!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677173.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I tried this recipe and it just didn't work out for me, it didn't thicken and the eggs scrambled despite the fact that I tempered them. I redid this recipe with advice from a friend and used Arborio rice (because it has a high content of starch that will help thicken the rice pudding). I also added corn starch to the recipe like this: I mixed 2 tbsp of corn starch with 1/2 c of milk and then added the egg in and beat the mix lightly with a fork and it formed this light frothy and foamy texture. Then I added that into the mix and that helped to thicken it up.  It worked out so much better this way!

Very easy recipe and extremely adaptable for everyone in the familys tastes.

Excellent - creamy, sweet comfort food. I mixed the egg and milk in a separate bowl, then added a few spoons of the rice mixture and mixed it in, before adding it all to the pot. This prevents your egg from scrambling. I also added a dash each of cinnamon and nutmeg to give it additional flavor.

text:
This is a wonderful rice pudding recipe as is, but I make one little change that brings it from delicious to decadent, in my opinion. I substitute the first 1 1/2 cups of milk for coconut milk. I then add 1/3 cup of shredded coconut. For the remaining 1/2 cup of milk I use one part coconut milk and one part half n' half. You can keep the raisins but I omit them (personal preferance), and sprinkle cinnamon ontop. Mmm!

userID:
3749247
Display Name:
BruingtonChef
isPro:

1

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674145.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have been looking for years for a creamy rice pudding recipe that will keep for a couple days without getting all runny/milky after the first day or two. I have finally found it! Thank you very much for sharing this recipe, it was delicious, economical, and my entire family loved it.  My changes to the recipe were that I needed to alter the ingredient quantity because I was preparing 20 servings. I omitted raisins (only because I don't like them) and when I served to my family and "pop over unexpected guests", I topped with cinnamon sugar at the time of consumption and everyone loved it.  As for the outcome of making such a large quantity, it came out perfect and this recipe, alterations and all delivered on the final product. One of the best recipes I have come across in a long while. Thanks Again!
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2009-05-20T19:27:51.977
helpfulCount:
0
userID:
3747603
Display Name:
anglii
isPro:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is perfect the way it is. A great gluten-free comfort food! I have Celiac Sprue and make it at least once per week. I use 1 part Basmati rice (long grain) to 1 part milk (2%) and don't save any milk to add later. I add the sugar at the beginning as recommended-I feel it helps to thicken the end result perhaps because sugar increases the cooking temperature. I also find that adding a large scoop of the heated mixture into the beaten egg before adding it to the pot is important to prevent hard boiled egg chunks. Mmmmmm

text:
This was my first time making rice pudding from scratch---this recipe is a great base. We like strong flavors, so I jazzed it up with shredded coconut, ground cardamom, ground ginger, and a generous amount of cinnamon. Also, I blanched some roasted cashews (soak them for a few minutes in boiling water to soften them) and tossed them in with the raisins. We loved it.

text:
this is delicious and easy to make...i boost the 'healthiness' factor by using brown rice (usually leftover from dinner), soymilk and/or buttermilk, and then i add toasted walnuts, dried fruit (cranberries, raisins, blueberries, goji berries, etc.) and a teaspoon or two of pumpkin pie spice (or similar individual spices).  i've found i can skip the egg and the butter without sacrificing flavor or texture.  it's a more guiltless version we can eat for breakfast or dessert!

userID:
3390235
Display Name:
Phoenixgirl too
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614246.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Love this recipe. What would I ever do without All recipes? Thanks to many reviews I had no problems. I cooked 1 cup of jasmine rice (my personal favorite) which gave me exactly 3 cups of cooked rice so I had the double recipe I needed for company. I added the salt and butter when cooking the rice. Added 3 cups of milk to the cooled rice in the same pan and cooked until rice was very tender about 15 minutes and then added the sugar and cooked another 5 minutes.  In a separate saucepan I warmed 1 cup of milk and whisked in the two room temperature eggs and then streamed it into the pudding while stirring and cooked another 5 minutes. Removed the pan from the heat and added 1 teaspoon of vanilla 1/8 teaspoon nutmeg and a generous 1/2 teaspoon of cinnamon. Yummy!  Left out the raisins, a matter of personal taste. This is the method I use to cook Jasmine rice. In large saucepan bring 1 3/4 cups water, 1/2 teaspoon salt & 1 tablespoons margarine or butter to a boil, slowly stir in 1 cup rice, bring back to a boil, reduce heat, stir gently, cover and simmer for 9 minutes or just until rice begins to stick to bottom of pan. Gently fluff with fork and remove from heat and let stand uncovered for 10 minutes.Perfect Jasmine rice every time.

None
text:
Delicious and much easier than I thought rice pudding could be. The only things I would suggest are:  1. Add the cooked rice after the sauce has been cooked. This way you can add less rice if you want a thinner consistency. 2. Add a cinnamon stick to the milk mixture while it's cooking. 3. Add the beaten egg very very SLOWLY while constantly whisking to avoid getting scrambled eggs in your pudding.

text:
Excellent!  Following previous recommendations, I added the butter and the salt when I was cooking the rice.  I also added some of the warm rice mixture to the milk/egg mixture to make sure the egg didn't cook/scramble.  I used skim milk, and added 1.5 tsp cornstarch to make it thicker.  I also mixed in cinnamon and nutmeg.  The nutmeg made all the difference for me!  Delicious!

Thank you so much for the delish and satisfying recipe!

text:
I made this with some modifications.  I used brown basmati rice and substituted 3/4 of the milk for skim.  I also added cinnamon at the end and dried coconut.  I used olivio instead of butter and only used about half of what was called for in the recipe.  Delicious.    Be careful when adding the egg-next time I'd mix it with the milk to avoid getting any pieces of cooked egg in it or let it cool and add it.

text:
Yum-my.   I give it 4 stars because it calls for a lot of sugar and does not need the butter (or raisins, not my thing). But that is a matter of taste, instruction-wise it's a 5 star recipe-- if you really want a buttery or sweet rice pudding, go for the straight up recipe. If you're like me and like it with fruit, try it with less sugar (I used 40 grams-- about 2/3 of what it called for) and no butter. It will be great.   Also delicious: 1/2 brown rice and 1/2 white rice.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/243550.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was really good!  I also liked that it was easy to make and not too time consuming compared to some other rice pudding recipes.   A word of caution: I strayed away from the directions a bit and made the pudding in the same pot I had cooked the rice in, unlike the directions instructed.  Bad idea!  Some rice had stuck to the bottom, and as I continued cooking the pudding, I smelled something burning.  It was the stuck-on rice cooking even further and sticking to the pan.  I ended up having to transfer the mixture to another pan anyway, which I should have just done from the start.  I was trying to avoid using two pans, but I still ended up having to use two in the end, and the difference is now one's sitting in my sink waiting to have the burnt rice scraped off of it.  You can try making it all in one pan, but next time I will definitely follow the directions and use two from the start.

Display Name:
Amber

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614259.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The best in a recipe: easy and delicious. I used a can of evaporated skim milk for the first 1 1/2 cups milk called for, then used about 1/4 cup granulated Splenda (measures cup for cup like sugar) in place of the sugar, which I added after the rice and evaporated milk had cooked for about 15 minutes. I didn't add any additional milk with the egg so it was super thick immediately served hot, then when I reheat leftovers I add a little milk and heat on the stove. I also added a bit of cinnamon and nutmeg with the egg (no idea how much). Honestly I was a little surprised at the great flavor and texture. My toddler loves this rice pudding, and made with evaporated skim milk and Splenda, I guess you could do worse for a snack.

Wow! I hadn't made rice pudding in ages. This was easy, and my three kids loved it! So did my hubby! I used 2% milk, real Mexican vanilla and the added cinnamon and some fresh nutmeg at the end as others suggested. I do agree that it is so rich that a small serving is all you need. I would suggest a fruit cup, or about 1/4 cup. We even dizzled a bit of Hershey's syrup on it. Still yummy. The kids want me to make it again!

city:

country:
None
text:
This is a great recipe. I took the advice of a few others and decreased the sugar to 1/4 cup, decreased the raisins to 1/3 cup (I didn't have golden raisins so I substituted "regular" raisins), and stirred in a sprinkling of both nutmeg and cinnamon. Like others, I tempered the egg by stirring a little of the hot rice liquid into the beaten egg and then stirred the egg into the hot rice mixture. My family liked it, and the kids said it "tasted like Christmas" ....on a very hot August day! LOL! Thanks for a nice recipe.

text:
I haven't had a rice pudding this good since I visited my grandmother in NY 4 years ago.  Thank you for sharing this great recipe!  Now on to my notions:  I used Splenda to substitue for the sugar as was suggested and found that only 1 tbsp is needed.  You can always add more, but you can't take it back out. I also used 2% milk and added a pinch of cinnamon and a dash of nutmeg as others have.  This is a real keeper, even my mom was impressed with how well it turned out.

text:
Wow Erica G! I love it! I was looking in a magazine and came across this advertisement for rice pudding, taste buds took over. Being that it was too late to go to the store for "premade" rice pudding. I gave your recipe a try. This was the best I have ever tried & made, and I have tried and made several only to disapoint my taste buds. I got online & your recipe was the first to come up in my search. Read the reviews, and there was a lot too. I had some left over cooked white rice, so I started with warming up the cooked rice in 1 1/2 cups of milk & proceeded from there. Add the vanilla after you have taken it off the burner, that way the vanilla doesn't pick up a bitter flavor from over cooking. Also used fresh nutmeg at the end too. This is a keeper for us. It brought back sweet childhood memories for me! Just like my Noni made.

text:
I’m a diabetic so I made some changes to this recipe to make it more suitable for me to eat.  First, I substituted same amount of Splenda for the sugar.  Second, I substituted equal amounts of Hood Calorie Countdown 2% milk for the regular milk to cut back on the carbs and third, I didn’t add the raising to cut back on more natural sweetness.  Other then the ingredient substitutes, I followed the recipe exactly and it came out FANTASTIC!  My family members could not taste any difference in this recipe with the changes I made and it was great warm and cold.  Loved it!

I love this recipe. I made it for dessert, and while I was cooking dinner I left it on the counter, and couldn't help having a small taste of the pudding every once and a while. 
When I made it, it came out really thick after sitting a few minutes. I guess i let the milk evaporate a little to much. But after adding more milk it made it more pudding like and thinner. It also made it a little less sweet, which I liked.

This is a great recipe!
Thank you!

I've made this 3 times now. Delicious!!The past 2 times, I've cheated and made it in the microwave because I didn't want to stand in front of the stove for that long. I cooked it about 10-12 min until thick, stopping to stir every 3 minutes. Then I added the final egg/milk mixture and cooked another 1-2 minutes. The pudding's consistency seemed the same to me, and it was a lot easier.

I gave 3 stars because the cooking instructions were easy but I had to change a few things to make it more tasty.  I added used 2/3c sugar instead of 1/3c.  Also, I added approx 1/4t cinnamon and a pinch of nutmeg.  Since I only had skim milk available I added 2T of butter instead of 1T.  After those changes, the recipe was awesome.......If it still counts as the same recipe.

Delicious.  Rave reviews all around the table from the toddlers and their dad.  Followed the recipe as written with a few substitutions/additions. I used 1 1/2 cups leftover brown Jasmine rice and added plain soymilk and sugar.  Had cooked the rice with salt, so omitted the extra.  Probably because the rice was brown, it took more like 25 minutes to get it creamy.  Added more soymilk and tempered the egg before adding as many others recommended.  Used regular raisins  and added a sprinkle of cinnamon at the end.

country:

text:
I made it but doubled the recipe. I added the salt in the water and rice as it came to a boil instead of later as someone suggested. I also added the vanilla, a hint of nutmeg, lots of cinnamon, as I was boiling the rice and milk mixture before adding the beat eggs. My husband test tasted it and said it still wasn't sweet enough so I added about 1/4 to 1/3 cup of sugar. (to taste. It is really nice and creamy but has to sit after you take it off the burner and let it sit and cool in order to let the raisins soak and absorb the liquids more. It it excellant, yummy and reminds me of the real old fashion made by grandma rice pudding!! Delicious!!

text:
YUM!! Very good and easy to make.  I like my raisins as soft as possible so I soaked them in the egg & 1/2 cup milk mixture for about an hour with cinnamon.  And I like my rice pudding cold (just seems the way I've always eaten it!) so if you like it cold, I suggest cooking it for a little less time so it's a little more liquidy (is that a word?) because mine from the fridge is more solid than anything.  I highly recommend!!

country:
None
text:
Rice pudding is one of my all-time favorite desserts. I often make a traditional Mexican arroz con leche. But I am also addicted to Kozy Shack, so when I read the reviews for this recipe I was pretty excited. I thought I had finally found a recipe to satisfy my craving for a custard-type store bought rice pudding. The recipe is super easy to prepare (I almost always have leftover rice on hand) and it smelled delicious while cooking. However, the final product just didn't live up to my expectations. I found it to be quite rich and not milk-y tasting like Kozy Shack. I might make it again though, if I was craving rice pudding and wanted it FAST!

I don't feel fair giving this a rating, because I made huge substitutions. I only had jasmine rice and vanilla soy milk on hand. I also chilled the finished product, cause my husband likes rice pudding cold. With these subs, this was not very good. The texture was sticky and very solid (not at all creamy). The flavor was decent at best. I just wanted to warn others not to try what I did with what seems like it should be a great recipe!

Quite yummy.  I used left over rice that was in the fridge for a few days, so I had to cook and stir on med heat longer (25 or 30 min or so) before it got thick and creamy because my rice was very cold to begin with.  It was a little too sweet for my taste, but all in all it's pretty good.

text:
I am living in South Korea.  I am always looking for things to do with my excess rice (not to mention it is one of the few things I can cook thus far with the ingredients available).  This is wonderful!  Just a few things I'll do different next time: use 1/2 the raisins (we used regular instead of golden, and I think the flavor is a bit more potent), try to get my hands on some nutmeg (we used cinnamon which is definately a must!).  I did notice the first bite was a bit bland, but once my overly spiced (Korean food!) taste buds adjusted, it was just right!!  Nice treat, though much too sweet for a breakfast food (as one reviewer suggested), though I guess Americans eat doughnuts for breakfast sometimes, don't we?

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I took a chance and doubled this recipe.  It was awesome!  This is what I did different:

I did not add the salt.  I kept the rice in the same pot.  I added cinnamon in with the beaten eggs & milk.

I ran out of milk so instead of adding the extra 1/2 cup of milk (1 cup for me as I doubled the recipe) I used 1 cup of heavy (whipping) cream.

I also threw in a few drops of butter flavoring even though I added the butter.  I didn't have the golden raisins so I used the regular dark ones.

This was so creamy any yummy!  My DH loved it, he had been pining for rice pudding.  We had 2 small bowls ... wait make that 2 small bowls each (LOL) before dinner and the rest of it is in the fridge cooling now.  I don't know how thick it will be when it cools ... if it is too thick, I'll just add a touch of 1/2 and 1/2 to it.

Thank you Erica for this great recipe.  I'd definately make this one again.

text:
Good base recipe, however I found I needed much more milk than the recipe called for to get the rice to release enough gluten to be more puddinglike and less like a creamy rice dish.  I wanted my rice more broken down, I guess.  Unfortunately I didn't figure this out until after I'd added the sugar and egg, and it's difficult to go back to 'cook' the rice some more.  Overall this recipe was tasty and since I'll be using more milk (at least a cup more, maybe more) I also will increase vanilla and sugar.
